I played Battlefield 2042 with a buddy for a few months at launch, and despite the game being extremely buggy and the vehicles being wildly overpowered, that chaos was a big part of the fun. The early experience delivered unpredictable moments and ridiculous vehicle plays that everyone loved, even if it wasn‚Äôt polished.

A few months later the patches toned things down. The vehicle changes removed a lot of that launch-era craziness, and while the gunplay was decent, it felt more arcade-like and less true to classic Battlefield roots. After that, I stepped away from the game for about a year.

Coming back right before BF6 released, the game was in a much better place. It felt more balanced, more stable, and surprisingly captured the Battlefield vibe well enough to hold me over until the next game dropped. Overall, Battlefield 2042 became a solid stepping stone for the series‚Äîrough start, but it eventually grew into a fun, respectable experience.

Game now is much better compared to the beginning. I cannot complain about the gameplay or the style that they chose for this one. It's a strange departure from the old ones, but still, you can have fun! The only problem is...the servers become unplayable when someone flushes the toilet! Oh, your neighbor sneezed? Well, that means the server needs to cool down after that excitement! You feel some bowel movements and it seems that you will release some gases? Well, the server needs to prepare, so... you know... server slowdown. A potato is a better server than the ones they have! Heck, even a Samsung fridge is a better server. EA's greed and putting all the eggs in EA Sports, in the end, something needs to break... and at this point, it's my patience.

Battlefield 2042 is a first-person shooter developed by DICE and released in 2021. Set in a near-future global conflict, it abandons the series‚Äô historical and modern-war settings for a high-tech battlefield featuring advanced gadgets, dynamic weather, and massive player counts. It was designed to showcase next-generation scale and chaos but launched with significant issues that affected its reception.

The game features 128-player matches on large, open maps, emphasizing vehicle warfare and player freedom. Traditional classes were replaced by a new ‚ÄúSpecialist‚Äù system, where each character has unique abilities and equipment. This shift aimed to encourage flexibility but diluted team roles, reducing the tactical coordination that defined earlier Battlefield titles.

Core gunplay and movement feel fluid, with improved weapon handling and traversal mechanics. However, balance problems, inconsistent weapon tuning, and erratic hit registration plagued the launch. The map design, while visually impressive, often felt too large and empty, leading to disorganized gameplay and long travel times between engagements.

Graphically, Battlefield 2042 demonstrates the full capability of the Frostbite engine. Massive storms, tornados, and destructible environments create dramatic visual moments. Weather systems and map-changing events deliver spectacle but sometimes interfere with gameplay clarity. Sound design and atmosphere remain strong, maintaining the immersive audio identity of the franchise.

At release, the game lacked a single-player campaign, focusing entirely on multiplayer modes: All-Out Warfare, Hazard Zone, and Portal. All-Out Warfare provides the classic large-scale experience; Hazard Zone blends extraction-style mechanics with tactical objectives; and Portal allows players to create custom matches using assets from Battlefield 1942, Bad Company 2, and Battlefield 3. Portal became a highlight due to its flexibility and nostalgia value.

Performance and stability were major concerns early on, with bugs, UI issues, and server instability dominating launch feedback. Over time, DICE released extensive patches that improved optimization, restored classic class structures, and overhauled maps to increase combat density. The post-launch updates gradually transformed the game into a more stable and coherent experience.

In summary, Battlefield 2042 began as an ambitious but uneven experiment that traded structure for scale. While its launch was rough, consistent updates have made it more enjoyable and closer to the series‚Äô roots. It remains visually stunning and technically impressive, but its design choices divided fans. For players seeking large, chaotic, modern battles with evolving support, it has matured into a solid‚Äîif unconventional‚Äîentry in the Battlefield series.

Battlefield 2042 had been in my library for a while, but I had never got around to play it until after the Battlefield 6 Open Beta. At First I didn't really enjoy it, maybe because it was so different from what I'd been used to, or maybe because I wasn't good. But once I continued to get a couple more hours in I started to like it. The gun play is smooth and fast, while also managing to feel semi realistic (unlike cod). If I had unlimited storage I would definitely continue to play even though I already own Battlefield 6. Even if Battlefield 6 is better game in almost every way, Battlefield 2042 is still a great game and an even better, cheap alternative.

Well worth a buy on sale if you like tinkering with game modes.
I like the Portal experience where i can make my own game and rules.
Like WW2 US soldiers versus Modern RU for example.
Another cool feature is projectile speed that can be changed ,so a bullet flys at half speed.
I also like to tweak soldier health and vehicle health too.
I think the default vehicle health is too high -
realistically a couple of Rpgs should take out a vehicle - so I reduce this health value.
You can make the game 2 shot kills if you want for infantry ,maybe 1 for snipers and shotgun slugs.


Runs OK on older laptop -just limit fps to 57fps and play at 720p ,this will reduce CPU heat a lot. In a similar vein i made a User.cfg to use only 2/3rds of my cpu cores and threads -this also reduces CPU heat.
The only problem I think without doing these 2 things is the high CPU heat when playing game.
The GPU does not seem to overheat at all.
If managed then the game is great.

BF2042: The Underrated Titan of the Battlefield Franchise

Honestly, BF2042 has evolved into something special ‚Äî F2042 delivers some of the best core gameplay the series has ever seen.
Best movement, best weapon handling, best vehicle handling, great spotting, and great maps ‚Äî alone, those five points make it a dream to play for anyone who values the classic Battlefield feeling refined to perfection.

Add to that better weapon customization and modification, maps spanning nearly every Battlefield era, vault weapons and vehicles, and the freedom to jump into ANY (classic) gamemode ‚Äî all while enjoying constant events, a ton of easter eggs, and hidden secrets scattered throughout. It‚Äôs the most content-rich and flexible Battlefield to date.

Most importantly, it‚Äôs now a complete, fully functional, non-buggy, premium FPS ‚Äî and you can grab it for just a couple of bucks. That‚Äôs insane value for what you‚Äôre getting.

After experiencing how polished and satisfying BF2042 has become, it‚Äôll be a long while before I feel like dishing out cash for an overpriced, monetized BF6.
BF2042 has earned its redemption and is high value giggles

‚óè‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‡Æú€©€û€©‡Æú‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚óèBattlefield 2042‚óè‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‡Æú€©€û€©‡Æú‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚óè
Quite different from previous Battlefield games, and as controversial to say it, I like this game. Many people say this game is full of bugs and glitches but from the time I played, I haven't found any. just funny rag-doll physics
‚óè‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‡Æú€©€û€©‡Æú‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚óèPositives‚óè‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‡Æú€©€û€©‡Æú‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚óè
- Different Eras: The game offers guns and such from different eras, including Battlefield 3, and Battlefield World War II. so it's pretty cool to have them mashed up
- Massive maps: There were some pretty big maps in other Battlefield games but I feel like this game has bigger maps than before. 
- Weapons: As before, this game offers guns from the other series, so whilst there isn't my personal favourites in the game, I still find myself switching to different guns because of how much I like them.
- Action Packed: Despite the large maps, there's still a lot of action in even small lobbies. There might be some times that there isn't anyone to kill but if you keep searching you'll definitely find someone
- Satisfying kills: I've played the other Battlefield games (I own all besides 6), and it's nice to get kills in those, but weirdly I find it's more satisfying to get kills in this game than the other games. Maybe I'm being biased but I can't help but to think how smoothly I killed someone.
‚óè‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‡Æú€©€û€©‡Æú‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚óèNegatives‚óè‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‡Æú€©€û€©‡Æú‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚ñ¨‚óè
Some negative things I've thought of counting as a positive but from personal experience with them, I'm still at a cross
- Specialists: I love having different characters to choose from, it's pretty fun and each character brings something new to the battlefield. However, as much as I like having them, it's also a major downside. It breaks what Battlefield had in my opinion. Classes defined the person you had, not operators and their abilities. With some having shields, it feels like they took a page from Rainbow Six Siege's book. People Blitz rushing you with shields is really annoying and unless you think of something quick, there's not really a way to counter them either. 
- Small lobby limits: As someone who plays Team Death Match the most, it only allows up to 32 players at max, which sounds like a lot but it's not when you have massive maps, especially when a lot of players love to camp in one spot.
- Money hungry taking over fun: Another reference I'm going to make to the game, the idea of customizing your specialist and with bundles just makes it feel like Siege. While yes it's nice to have something to customize to your liking, it also costs a lot of money, and it's not like this game is cheap anyways.
- Dropped like it was unwanted: I love the Battlefield series so I was excited to play this game when I bought it, although as soon as they announced Battlefield 6, that's when this game became irrelevant. It was as like they said "well we got our money from this game so onto the next one.". This means, the glitches and bugs other players reported, won't get noticed for a very long time, and that hackers will likely to take over servers here soon.
- Spawn can be iffy a lot: I can count some instances where I spawned on top of something that killed me, and no I didn't move right away, the game spawned me on it. First, I spawned on top of a claymore, the game might spawn you randomly, but why there? It was both weird and annoying to die a millisecond of spawning in. and second, I died to spawning in on top of fire. Iwo Jima has some on going fire on the map and I just so happen to spawn on top of the fire, it didn't kill me but it did take a lot of HP, which then someone killed me within seconds of getting away from the fire

A lot of people told me that Battlefield 2042 was trash when it first came out, but I decided to make my own opinion instead of just listening to others. And honestly, I‚Äôm glad I did.

At launch, the game definitely had problems ‚Äî tons of bugs, missing features, and it didn‚Äôt really feel like the old Battlefield everyone loved. But after all the updates, it‚Äôs a completely different game now. The gunplay feels great, the maps are way better, and the new specialists system actually makes sense once you get used to it.

The large-scale battles with 128 players are insane in a good way. When everything explodes around you, helicopters flying over, tanks rolling in ‚Äî that classic Battlefield chaos is back. The graphics and sound design are also top-notch, as always.

Of course, it‚Äôs not perfect. Some maps still feel too big or empty, and matchmaking can be a bit slow. But overall, it‚Äôs way better than what people say. I think most of the hate came from the early days, and people just never gave it another chance.

If you‚Äôre into big, chaotic war games with awesome visuals and teamwork, Battlefield 2042 is definitely worth trying in 2025. It‚Äôs not the disaster it used to be ‚Äî it‚Äôs finally the Battlefield it was meant to be.

Battlefield 2042 delivers massive, chaotic battles that feel epic and intense. The huge maps, vehicles, and dynamic weather effects make every match unpredictable and exciting especially when playing with friends.
While the game had a rough start with bugs and balance issues, it has improved over time. Some changes, like the specialist system, are still controversial, but overall it‚Äôs a solid and fun shooter for those who love large-scale warfare.

BF2042 had a poor launch, coupled with bugs and unpolished maps. This more or less doomed it commercially because the internet has swift, brutal reactions and rarely deviates from initial judgments. 

Fast forward a couple years, and this game is polished, smooth, and extremely fun. I would argue the internet slept on this game, because it has been the best shooter on the market for several years, with great gunplay, squad gameplay, and a variety of maps and vehicles. The movement is fast-paced and quick, which makes gunfights extremely chaotic at times; the movement style is reminiscent of Titanfall or Apex Legends. I think this game gets a lot of undue hate because it dared to be different than other Battlefield games. It is less realistic and allows itself to be a little more silly than other Battlefield entries, but that quirkiness adds a much needed element of joy and fun to the game (the entire "story" with the no pats is frankly amazing in a silly, 1980s action movie kind of way). The reality is that most of the criticisms levied against it by the "hardcore" or "older generation" Battlefield fans are illegitimate when you break them down (or think critically for more than 0.2 seconds). E.g., 2042 gets a lot of hate for being "less realistic" than other Battlefield entries, but no one making this criticism actually wants realism, they [i]want[/i] to have a reason to hate this game. 

If you have a chance to pick it up on sale--which should be easy these days--consider giving it a shot. If you like modern games or movement shooters, you will probably enjoy this. Possibly more than BF6; considering BF6--at time of writing--feels and plays like a game from 20 years ago while BF2042 is more modern.

I tried this game after all the content updates, and I still cannot recommend it as a lifelong battlefield fan.  Classic "one step forward, 2 steps back" situation.  I played it long enough to get all the "Road to Battlefield 6" unlocks and not 1 match longer.  

Pros
+Weather system adds a random chaotic element that I enjoyed (Tornadoes in particular were thrilling)
+The vehicle call in system was good at preventing players from wasting time in the re-spawn screen for vehicles
+Great vehicle variety with interesting twists on every form of transport

Cons
-Horrendously clunky and awkward movement/gun-play
-Character designs scream "Modern Audience", completely ruining the Battlefield aesthetic
-Audio is the worst in the series and voiced lines were all cringe inducing

Right now is a good time to play Battlefield 2042. If you can't afford the premium price of Battlefield 6; 2042 has the least amount of AI bots plaguing the multiplayer compared to Battlefield V and Battlefield 1. In addition, I recommend you get a free software to automatically clear RAM buildup every 30 minutes so you don't have to force close the game every 60 minutes. Otherwise, your game will crash from a large buildup of RAM cache. Reddit recommends ISLC but I use Wise Memory Optimizer. Some maps have large memory leaks, so you want to make sure you deal with that or else :/. Also I suggest you force Dx12 so that the game doesn't use Dx11, which is poorly optimized.

After putting almost 100 hours into Battlefield 2042, I‚Äôve spent most of my time in the Engineer role ‚Äî repairing vehicles, holding objectives, and keeping the team moving under fire. There‚Äôs something satisfying about being the backbone of a squad, making sure our armor stays operational while dishing out damage with launchers and gadgets.

I‚Äôve also leaned into being a taker ‚Äî pushing aggressively to capture points, secure vehicles, and turn the tide of fights. Whether it‚Äôs locking down a sector solo or coordinating with teammates, those moments of chaos and control make the game rewarding.

On top of that, I‚Äôve logged plenty of time in the skies as a pilot. Mastering helicopters and jets has been a huge learning curve, but flying support runs, evading missiles, and delivering precise strikes feels incredible when it all comes together.

Altogether, the experience has been a mix of teamwork, skill, and sheer adrenaline ‚Äî and even after 100 hours, Battlefield 2042 still finds ways to surprise me.

For $80 this might not make sense, however, when you can pick it up for a few dollars at a Steam Sale this game offers a fantastic multiplayer experience. I actually enjoy the mix of maps that offer both open and closed concept fighting experiences. The guns also pack a punch and the more arcade style movement was a fun change of pace. It is not so fluid and the gunplay not so clicky to become something akin to COD given that the game still has weight to it. I think the game is over hated and I have had a lot of fun with it. At the same time the lack of a campaign and unintuitive way of unlocking guns can be a bit frustrating. At the moment though this is my favourite FPS multiplayer experience.

I've played this game since the beta and played for 970 hours, (832 on the EA launcher plus 138 on steam), along with 100% the game. I have watched the devs work and add to the game to make it a decent Battlefield game, they only promised 4 seasons, we got 7 with some mini ones, and a bonus Battlefield celebration season out of nowhere which was super cool, so thank you so much for all of that. Is it different from other Battlefields sure, did it lack a story mode yes (In which is really sad, the lore in the CODEX was super cool, and it's a shame all the lore and the story is reduced to that and seasons.) But at the end of the day, it's still a decent FPS. Movement and gunplay feel great, some maps were good, and the specialists were ok, different yes, but I didn't have a huge issue with them. But if you ask me if I regretted getting a physical PC copy for like $25, and then buying it on Steam for $5, I'll say no, not at all. I really had a great time with 2042, and I'm sure I always will.

I bought Battlefield 2042 expecting a next-gen war simulator. What I got was a $60 tech demo where helicopters moonwalk and bullets take gap years before hitting anything.

At hour 1, I thought, "This is rough, but it‚Äôll get better."
At hour 1000, I thought, "Any update now..."
At hour 5000, I lost hope but stayed for the emotional damage.
By hour 9834, I realized I was in a toxic relationship with a game that peaked in the tutorial.

Some say insanity is doing the same thing and expecting different results. I say it's playing 9,834 hours of Battlefield 2042 and still believing in patch notes.

Would give it 2042 stars if I could. Out of 100,000.

What's wrong with this game:

-The maps are so goddamn horrendous 64 player Conquest is essentially unplayable

-128 player Conquest is straight up just unplayable because the servers piss and shit themselves so hard that everything teleports at all times

-Vehicles are hilariously overpowered. The TRANSPORT Helicopter got re-classified as an attack helicopter because it has 4!!!!!!!!!!!! gunner seats on it?????? And essentially every other transport vehicle also has 4 gunner seats, making the transport vehicles the strongest attack vehicles for some godforsaken reason.

-Portal is dead and purely afk xp farms

-The extraction shooter gamemode thing is entirely dead so no clue if that's worth anything because you just cannot find a match

-Seriously the maps are so bad in so many different ways it's hard to even describe the ways they fail

-It's *alright* if you only plan on playing breakthrough but even then, with how overpowered vehicles are and only attackers getting them every single round will be an attacker stomp unless you play on one of the maps without vehicles.

-No ability to exclude certain maps from matchmaking

-The spawning system is amazingly bad, putting you in no-man's land 50 kilometers away from any objective with no cover literally anywhere so good luck!

-Mouse inputs simply get dropped at random

-Destruction barely exists

Overall just go play battlefield 6 and let this game die.

I wasn't here for the shitshow that was the launch - I bought this in 2023 for 9 Euros - money very well spent! I always had a lot of fun, unpopular opinion: 64 vs 64 is friggin amazing! Maps were pretty good too, vehicle gameplay is clean and rewarding, in the correct hands it might seem OP, but that's BF for ya, if you are playing with friends you can definetly take any vehicle down with the right strategy. Also lots of really well balanced guns, you could have a lot of fun trying them all out.
The only real point of critique I'd have is the hero-style cringe skins and cheezy lines, but once you get used to it you don't even notice. Extremely underrated, especially after it got all fixed up.
Shame most people left for BF6, rest in peace sweet prince.

I've enjoyed Battlefield 2042 but it wasn't as great as others such as Battlefield 3, 4 and 1. The gunplay felt a bit too quick, feeling more like a Call Of Duty then the average battlefield experience. The game is overall fun though and I did enjoy some of its weapons feeling absolutely broken to play with once you put the right attachements. 

To me, some of the most fun games I had were with the 128 players conquests games. Even if it felt like you were dying on repeat and couldn't solo flank an objective, the pure chaos of it was really fun! Def hoping some gamemode of it can be available on BF6's Portal mode.

Now one of the things I disliked in this game was the Hazard Zone gamemode. Ngl, it felt like a pathetic attempt at an Extraction Shooter. The gamemode isn't dead-dead but there is a really small community, so when you'll play it you might always be playing with the same people in your lobbies. It also felt dull with the goal of getting devices and them being really easy to get (only stacking up to 5, could have been better if you could get unlimited from looting people).

Anyways, overall it was an OK shooter game but it wasn't a great Battlefield. Id recommend getting it on sales, but before playing it I'd play Battlefield 4 :P

I pre-ordered Battlefield 2042, and to say I was disappointed at launch would be an understatement. The game felt unfinished and directionless. But as time went on and the developers kept updating it, the experience slowly started to grow on me. While it never reached the memorable heights of Battlefield 3 or Battlefield 4, 2042 eventually found its footing. Still, it always felt like the odd one out, kind of like Battlefield Hardline. Now that it‚Äôs reached the end of its life cycle, I can say Battlefield 2042 served its purpose. It was never meant to be the next great Battlefield, even though it was hyped as one. In the end, it feels more like a stepping stonea placeholder that gave DICE time to prepare for what fans truly wanted, which we‚Äôre finally getting with Battlefield 6.
 2042 ended up being... alright. Not great, not terrible, just a chapter in Battlefield‚Äôs evolution.

[h1]This is the worst battlefield ever made.[/h1]

I honestly didn‚Äôt think it was possible to make a Battlefield this bad.

When the game first dropped, I skipped it. I came back to it later, already having played almost every BF (except Hardline, and I barely touched BF1). And man‚Ä¶ after BF5 and the open beta of BF6, this one - Battlefield 2042 - just feels awful.

And I‚Äôm not even talking about graphics or visuals - no, that‚Äôs fine. The gameplay itself is just straight-up terrible.

Yeah, there are massive 100-player modes, but the maps are so stretched out and empty that you spend forever running in silence with nothing happening. They‚Äôre so wide open that most capture points are completely dead - zero action, zero fun.

Weapon and vehicle balance is a joke. Gunplay has no feeling at all - every weapon feels like a laser gun, no recoil, no weight, nothing satisfying about it.

Vehicles? Same deal - total letdown. I love rolling in tanks, and in BF5, when you and your buddy roll up to a point, you feel that power - the tank feels heavy, impactful, dangerous.
Here? You‚Äôre just a slightly tougher SUV. Everyone can shred you, and the physics... it‚Äôs like driving on melted butter. No weight, no detail, no realism at all.

And what they did with classes and specialists - absolute cringe. Classes should be fixed. Assault has its weapons, Support has theirs. When everyone can pick whatever, it turns into a total mess.

No story mode either. That short intro cutscene when you first launch the game - that‚Äôs it. They might as well not have bothered.

Honestly, I couldn‚Äôt even force myself to finish the battle pass for the BF6 skins - I uninstalled after 17 hours.

This game is a total disappointment. You can tell by how the community reacted - everyone just went back to older titles. For a while, BF1 from 2016 even became the most played again.
Then after BF6 came out, 2042‚Äôs player count completely died again.

Sure, Battlefield games usually launch broken - that‚Äôs nothing new. But after a few months, they get fixed, and people end up loving them. Not this time though. Four years later, Battlefield 2042 is still one of the worst games in the series - and rightfully so.
The community sent a clear message to EA: rush jobs don‚Äôt fly anymore. They somehow managed to screw up even worse than BF5‚Äôs launch.

Rating for BF 2042 - 4.5/10

Let me add this - when the action actually does happen, it‚Äôs pure chaos.
If you were hoping for some hardcore mayhem in the middle of explosions and gunfire - yeah, that‚Äôs exactly what it is.
But it‚Äôs not the good kind. It‚Äôs like watching a Brazzers scene - intense banging, but zero emotion or feeling behind it. Just noise and chaos.

Thankfully, they finally got the memo - the BF6 beta and release were actually solid!
Apart of unbalanced vehicles it was a pretty good game. Definitely would not pay full price.

[h1]Battlefield 2042: Scale but no Substance.[/h1]
‚Äé 
[i]2042[/i] is a game that they wanted to be a long lasting title in the franchise with the main focus being multiplayer which was made apparent in the marketing but what we got was a striped back almost beta-like game, especially on release. 
Years of updates have dragged the game into a serviceable state, but by the time things improved it was already to late, the damage was done. On top of that, microtransactions and a heavy emphasis on cosmetic skins and collaborations felt out of place and only added to the sense that the game prioritized monetization instead of the community.
I believe that disdain for the game in general was necessary for the franchise to improve, which is hopefully what we are seeing with Battlefield 6.
‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé 
[b]Price Paid:[/b] [i]A$ 139.95.[/i]

[b]Achievements: [/b][i]Most come as you play, though some are extremely grindy. Portal can speed things up, but the hardest ones are probably in Hazard Zone, good luck finding a match.[/i]


[h1]Recommendation:[/h1]With [i]Battlefield 6[/i], there‚Äôs very little reason to pick up [i]2042[/i] at this point. And even then, previous entries in the series still have active player bases and arguably offer better experiences.

[hr][/hr]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3582079857
[h2]Story.[/h2]
‚Äé 
A sequel to [i]Battlefield 4[/i], set 22 years in a climate-ravaged future, you play as the ‚ÄúNo-Pats‚Äù ‚Äî mercenaries hired by global superpowers to fight their wars. The premise had potential through gameplay with environmental collapse and destruction shaping the maps, but the game barely does anything with it. There is no single-player campaign which is a real disappointment as the single player was something I enjoyed a lot when I was younger. All the lore and worldbuilding that exists is scattered through the official website, community wiki, and what people have pieced together and shared on reddit. The game itself tells you almost nothing, except for what you may be able to surmise from trailers and maps. 
The writing for the Specialists, or No-Pats, is some of the most awkward and forced I‚Äôve heard. The lines feel like they belong in a hero-shooter rather than coming from soldiers in the middle of a war, and yet even with all the quotes and their design they lack any actual personality. 

[h2]Gameplay.[/h2]
‚Äé‚Äé 
The ambition with [i]2042[/i] was clear, but the execution leaves the core gameplay feeling stretched thin. Even with 128-player battles, maps can feel enormous and empty, where you can end up running for some time with little happening only to get gunned down by a jet or sniped by a tank which is especially bad when you are primarily an infantry player. Majority of the time, at least in OCE, full 128-player lobbies are uncommon, and most matches are filled with bots and the classic 64 player matches being the most popular, for good reason. 

Tornadoes and storms rip through maps in [i]2042[/i], which is impressive and exciting the first time you see them, maybe even the next few times. But the novelty quickly wears off, and they become more of an annoyance than anything disrupting your HUD, interfering with electronics, and tossing you around. 

The introduction of Specialists felt like a step backwards. Instead of creating more freedom and flexibility with loadouts, they ended up reducing team play. Even after the reintroduction of a semi-class system, individual character gadgets still felt like the main focus rather than team roles. While weapon access was opened up, DICE tried to justify class-specific weapons through small proficiency bonuses, for example, Assault players getting three extra magazines. However, this did very little.

Portal mode is easily the best feature to come out of[i] 2042[/i], offering a sandbox where players can build and share custom game modes using content from past [i]Battlefield[/i] titles. While it‚Äôs not something I personally spent much time with, there‚Äôs a featured game mode that rotates weekly on the home screen, often created by community members or even YouTubers and streamers. The mode also includes a server browser, allowing you to find and join populated lobbies, though usually with reduced XP gains.

Hazard Zone is an attempt at a ‚Äòhigh-stakes‚Äô squad-based extraction mode, [b]often compared to Tarkov[/b] ‚Äî though it‚Äôs not on the same page let alone in the same book. You and three squadmates are dropped into an OG [i]2042[/i] map against multiple enemy teams, tasked with collecting data drives while fighting AI and other players. After gathering enough drives, you have two chances to extract via VTOL, which almost always turns into a fight over the extraction points. Very few people play this mode because it doesn‚Äôt offer much, and even when you do find players, it‚Äôs common to encounter campers that purely just sit at extract points. It‚Äôs an exhausting experience, and to complete achievements, I had to use a VPN just to find eight players for a single match.
‚Äé‚Äé 
[h2]Difficulty.[/h2]
‚Äé‚Äé 
Since [i]Battlefield 2042[/i] is primarily multiplayer, the challenge in PvP matches depends almost entirely on your skill and who you get matched with. The game also offers AI bot modes, which range from just shooting sitting targets to surprisingly tough opponents who are better than most players. Or, if you prefer, you can just sit in a tank an entire match like a Jackass.
‚Äé‚Äé 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3582080556
[h2]Visuals.[/h2]
‚Äé‚Äé 
Visually, the textures, models, and effects in [i]2042[/i] are all solid.[b] The problem is the art direction[/b], everything looks too clean and sterile, lacking personality or distinctive detail, which makes the game look worse than it actually is. They did attempt to rectify this over time by adding more debris around the maps but it did very little to improve the overall bland style. That said, some of the map releases later on were better designed and offered genuinely solid experiences.
‚Äé 
[h2]Audio.[/h2]
‚Äé‚Äé 
Audio is a downgrade across the board compared to previous entries. While it has improved since release, the overall range still feels limited, certain sound effects come across as compressed, and directional audio is unreliable. Footsteps are often difficult to track or simply fail to play entirely, tanks can sometimes just sneak up on you with little warning. 
[b]The soundtrack is equally forgettable[/b]. It lacks identity and comes across as generally generic. While it may fit the game‚Äôs theme, it fails to stand out or add any real emotion to the gameplay, unlike, dare I say, the previous titles.
‚Äé 
[h2]Performance and Bugs.[/h2]
‚Äé 
I‚Äôve seen a lot of complaints about poor performance, but [b]honestly my experience has been the opposite[/b]. The game runs smoothly, stable frame rates even in 128-player matches, and no stuttering or crashes on my end. I still ran into the occasional bug however, even after years of patches. Being disconnected from the server randomly, my character just floating next to the vehicle and broken animations when downed.

I‚Äôve been in the U.S. Navy long enough to know when the tide‚Äôs about to turn‚Äîand brother, Battlefield 2042 isn‚Äôt just a game anymore. It‚Äôs a prelude. A simulation of the chaos I can feel building in my bones. Every round I play is one step closer to the inevitable headline: ‚ÄúWorld War III Begins ‚Äî Gamer Was Ready.‚Äù

When I boot up 2042, I‚Äôm no longer in my barracks. I‚Äôm deployed to a near-future hellscape where drones scream overhead and the air tastes like copper and adrenaline. I‚Äôm in the zone. My pulse syncs with the gunfire. My brain‚Äôs rewired to the rhythm of war. I can practically hear the reactor humming in the distance as I mutter, ‚ÄúGod help the first Ivan who crosses my crosshair.‚Äù

The devs probably didn‚Äôt intend for this to be psychological warfare training, but here I am, a sailor stationed halfway across the Pacific, using every match to sharpen my instincts. When the bullets start flying, I‚Äôll already have 400 hours of combat experience‚Äîsure, it‚Äôs digital, but so are most modern targeting systems.

The game‚Äôs chaos feels real. Jets screaming through the smog, hovercrafts drifting across skyscrapers, medics reviving me like I owe them back pay‚Äîit‚Äôs beautiful carnage. It‚Äôs the kind of environment that forges warriors or breaks them. My squadmates may be 13-year-olds yelling ‚ÄúEZ‚Äù into their mics, but in my head, they‚Äôre comrades in arms‚Äîbrothers and sisters of the digital front.

Sometimes when I‚Äôm on watch duty, I‚Äôll catch a reflection in the glass and see that 2042 thousand-yard stare. My CO asked me once what I was thinking about. I told him the truth:

‚ÄúSir‚Ä¶ I was thinking about flanking the Russians on Kaleidoscope.‚Äù

Battlefield 2042 isn‚Äôt perfect‚Äîyeah, it‚Äôs got bugs, lag, and the occasional tornado that eats your GPU alive‚Äîbut perfection doesn‚Äôt prepare you for the apocalypse. War isn‚Äôt pretty. It‚Äôs messy. It‚Äôs unstable. It‚Äôs Battlefield.

10/10 ‚Äî Training complete. My Steam deck is my rifle, my monitor my radar. If the day ever comes when the Red Bear wakes up angry‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll be ready.

Battlefield 2042 That Was Pain. I didn't plan to play it, but after the BF6 beta, Zampella was like: ‚ÄúNope, I'm not finished with you‚Äù And all of that just for the Battle Pass. I wasn‚Äôt an exception.

It was rough: you play not because you want to, or because you enjoy it, but because you have to. There was zero fun in that. And on top of that it‚Äôs still BF 2042. Sure, it‚Äôs not the same game it was at launch. They‚Äôve patched it up a bit, and now, in my opinion, it‚Äôs in a slightly above-average state.

This last event is like the final point of Battlefield 2042, its last performance on stage before leaving forever.
And yeah, it was tough, but I wouldn‚Äôt say it was completely awful. Yes, the game is still rough the recoil feels awkward, the guns feel like plastic toys, and shooting is pure RNG, with terrible hit registration. As for optimization, I can‚Äôt complain. I‚Äôve got a powerful PC, so no issues there.

One big plus: lots of new players joined during the event, and matches were found instantly.
Also, some maps with weather effects were genuinely cool. Yeah, that was supposed to be the feature of this Battlefield, but now I finally get it, when a tarnado starts and you're right in the middle, it's awesome. The new Iwo Jima map is fun, and I finally managed to properly play Hazard Zone. Course, I was already tired of it, but I couldn't help but be happy after five wins in a row or successfully exiting 25 times it wasn't easy. This game is way better with friends ‚Äî you‚Äôll get far more enjoyment than playing solo. Although, to be honest, I doubt many will play it.
At least the game looks good on ultra settings.
It‚Äôs not Battlefield 1 with its stunning visuals, but if you don‚Äôt compare them directly, BF2042 actually looks fine.

In the last two weeks, I‚Äôve played around 80‚Äì90 hours, while before that I only had about 14‚Äì15.
Now I‚Äôm sitting at roughly 150 hours.
And yeah, for some reason I decided to unlock every single achievement‚Ä¶ Don‚Äôt ask me why.

Originally, I planned to write this review after finishing the Battle Pass, but if I had done it back then, it would‚Äôve looked like this: ‚ÄúThis is absolutely terrible. I‚Äôm never coming back‚Äù

But I decided to play for my own enjoyment, and I actually found some positive sides not many, but still.

Will I return to Battlefield 2042? Definitely not.
And honestly, I‚Äôm pretty sure the player count will drop even lower tomorrow ‚Äî October 10 ‚Äî when Battlefield 6 releases.
The game got its last chance: many people tried it for the first time thanks to the 95% discount ‚Äî it was just $3, ‚Ç¨3, or 30 kr.
Some old players even came back, and that was great because the servers were filled with life. Many were sitting on PORTAL maps farming XP.

But the event is over and the game is slowly dying and it will continue like this.
Anyone who played during the last Battlefild 2042event winessed a unique event the last flare of a dying star before it faded away forever. Battlefield 2042 is not the best entry in the series.

There are still a lot of problems that remain. But it had one last chance a chance for players to enjoy it, at least a bit, before it becomes a completely dead game.

Personally, I have mixed feelings about the whole thing. Too bad Steam doesn‚Äôt have a 50/50 rating, because that‚Äôs exactly what this game deserves.

In the end: Battlefield 2042 isn‚Äôt a great game.
It has its flaws, but I still managed to have some fun with it.

It's a game. Not a Battlefield game but it is certainly a game that feels like it's inspired by it's predecessors. It's trying to be a million things at once while also trying to convince you it is just only one step up from BTF5. It works, it runs and the guns shoot, that's about all you can gather from it. 

The absence of a single-player takes away a massive core-identity of BTF games and you have no choice but to go head first into multiplayer PVP. If you have come from any of the previous games this will feel nothing like them and will likely bore you very rapidly if you are a stickler for the core tenets of the series. 

If you're reading this after the release of Battlefield 6, don't even waste your time downloading this game unless it's free. This game will forever be remembered as the game that wanted to be so much more but just ended up being known as a place-holder game for impatient players waiting for BTF6 to release and nothing else to do. 

I would say it was fun while it lasted but if I'm being objectively open about the game, you would have more fun and memorable times in BTF4 player hosted servers than anything portal could possibly offer. Save your time and money, this will likely never be a game any significant amount of players return to at any point in time, especially when compared to the longevity of BTF4, 1 and 5.

Well that was it Battlefield 2042. A game that started and ended with mixed emotions.
But believe it or not, as a big Battlefield fan, I gonna defend this title until the end, also because I felt some of the criticism unjustified. Why? Well you gonna find it out:

I played this game since the Beta and played almost every Season, so I have a very large opinion about this game. It‚Äôs so large that my review gonna be in bullet points to not make it too long.


Positive:
-Battlefield 2042 from all, the best conquest mode. Now it‚Äòs almost impossible to capture one objective just by yourself in a 64 vs. 64 match. So I totally disagree that teamplay got worse, it got better. Good luck defending an objective by yourself when a transport vehicle comes to you.
-Due to the large scale maps, you are now just a small soldier on a big battlefield. That means in conquest you try control more an area of the map than the whole battlefield. This type of gameplay I could only experience on hardcore shooters like Hell Let Loose or Squad. But Battlefield 2042 proved you can get this great experience also on a casual shooter.
-The big maps are awesome with their diverse areas to play. I played them sooo much and still I haven‚Äôt seen enough. There are just so many places to explore. The other good thing of these map is, that they give freedom for every playstyle. For example in the old Hourglass map, you had so many possibilities. If you wanted to snipe, then go to the roof of the skyscrapers. If you want more of CQC like in Operation Metro, then go to the stadium.
-The plus system is awesome. Now you can modify your gun on the run if your combat situation changed. So no force to change your loadout on the menu anymore.
-The guns are balanced very well. Each category fulfils it‚Äôs purpose. Also Shotguns can finally be used outside of close combat thanks to the increased range. It‚Äòs not the fault of the long area anymore, it depends of your tactic.
-Although I can agree that it sucks that we have specialist instead of classes, their gadgets like the wingsuit or ballistic shield, are just too much fun to dislike them.
-Even if you want to travel a long area of the map, you either pick a vehicle nearby or call a vehicle via your tablet. I never understood those people who complained that they needed to run minutes just to get to another objective. I always needed less than one minute moving on another objective. Even the tornado can be also used as a quick transport which looks cool at the same time.
-As an Battlefield 4 enjoyer myself, I can finally go another route against those elevator campers.
-Battlefield Portal is great.
-Almost all matches had a good team balance.
-The most most most important one: With my +750 hours playtime I witnessed maybe two or three cheaters, unlike Battlefield 5, where it was an every day situation.


Negative:
-Back in the day you felt, and sometimes still feel the problematic development for BF2042. On launch, the bugs really made Battlefield 2042 look unfinished and when they started to fix and update it, some new problems arrived and it got even worse. Now it is in a way better version, but it still feels a little bit unpolished like trying to redeploy when two squad members are close by or that Casper can‚Äòt deploy a drone in a smoke because of whatever reason.
-I agree that the specialist having names and identities damaged effect to let the soldiers blend into battle. Now it gets more obvious that the same character models appear over and over again.
-No ‚ÄúAssist count as a kill‚Äù anymore.
-You also feel BF2042 identity crisis. Some map reworks and especially everything after Season 4 was like EA Dice saying: ‚ÄûHey players, yes Battlefield 2042 is total garbage! And because of that we gonna remove those features that made this game special or change them to more normal mechanics!‚Äú. C‚Äòmon we can all agree that BF2042 did not completed all their expectations but still it had new cool and fun things. Yes some people wanted a more classical BF experience but they would hate the new mechanics anyway.
-One thing that no one really talked about: Battlefield 2042 doesn‚Äòt feel like a worthy next step after Battlefield 5. Many changes that were good in the previous title, didn‚Äòt returned and it sucks. The ping spot instead of a 3D spot was great and way less annoying.

Those were all my points I have in mind.

TL;DR : Yes Battlefield 2042 had a rough start and yes BF2042 is not that polished like the other entries, but I liked this game‚Ä¶ hell I love Battlefield 2042! From all games I played since Battlefield 4, this the Battlefield with my most playtime. Yes, and it‚Äòs because the most "battlefieldest" game of all. If Battlefield for you means large scale combat, then Battlefield 2042 did and focused on exactly that. Great game, totally recommend it!

I did want to rate this positively, because it's honestly not as bad as a lot of people make it out to be. But over these last few weeks leading up to BF6, I've had terrible crashes, in one specific spot. When you load into the main menu, your character spawns in and does a cool badass turn and walk towards the camera. Wow, so fucking cool and sick. Except... if you're like me, your game will crash as soon as they start walking to the camera. This isn't just an issue of it crashing when you load in--when you finish a match, you get a screen that shows you all of your unlocks from the last match. When you click through that menu and return to the main menu, your game crashes as your character walks at the camera. Doesn't matter how long you're in that initial rewards menu; you crash when the character model loads in. Awesome.

To make matters worse, this game relies on the tumor that is the EA desktop client. For NO fucking reason. And sometimes, the EA desktop client will simply refuse to connect to their servers, even though you're able to connect online with LITERALLY EVERY OTHER APP on your computer, even as you're in Discord VC with other people in the SAME STATE who are connecting to the EA servers no problem. Reset the EA app? Clear the EA app cache? Restart your PC? Uninstall the EA app and reinstall? Verify integrity of game files? UNINSTALL THE ENTIRE GAME AND REINSTALL IT? NOTHING WORKS. What does get it working again? Re-launching it for the 100th time, having changed NOTHING AT ALL, after trying to get in the game that you PAID MONEY FOR for 30 minutes... I'm not exaggerating when I say that the EA app may be the absolute worst piece of trash software I have ever had the displeasure of experiencing, and I used to play League of Legends.

If Battlefield 6 requires you to launch through the EA app, I legitimately may request a refund. It is so shit.

Team Deathmatch stands out as one of the most enjoyable modes in Battlefield 2042 because it keeps the action focused and intense. The smaller-scale combat helps mask the game‚Äôs biggest weakness, which is its large, often poorly designed maps.

Unfortunately, the squad-based system limits coordination in larger public matches. With squads capped at four players, organizing as a single, cohesive team is nearly impossible. This restriction takes away the large-scale teamwork that Battlefield has always been known for.

As a group of ten friends, we can‚Äôt all join the same match like we could in past Battlefield titles. Unless we use custom Portal servers, we‚Äôre forced to split up, which really hurts the experience. Sadly, it seems this design direction may continue into Battlefield 6, which is disappointing for fans who miss the franchise‚Äôs classic large-squad coordination.

Battlefield 2042 can still be fun in the right mode, but its restrictive squad system make it feel like a missed opportunity for the series.

[h1] Battlefield 2042 - It's improvements over the years doesn't stop it from being easily the worst Battlefield of all time. [/h1]

[h2] Pros: [/h2]

. They have made some positive improvements since it's launch in 2021. I think the way they integrated the traditional class system into the operator system that this game introduced is a great idea, giving more roles outside the basic Recon, Support, Engineer and Assault and creating some more diverse gameplay.

. The Portal mode is also a nice idea; bringing back old maps whilst mixing in weapon loadouts from all eras of Battlefield, such as using weapons from 1942 on a map from Battlefield 3. Or just straight up an old map using loadouts from the game it was from. It creates some interesting matchups that can actually be quite entertaining.


[h2] Cons: [/h2]

. The base game's maps are HORRIBLE. Almost every map is way too big and empty with absolutely no flow or consistency to them. The level terrain makes the maps feel disconnected, and also makes most maps an absolute sniper's paradise. If the enemy team has several decent snipers, then you can forget about having fun.

. The spawns are EVEN WORSE. If the enemy is on an objective that you choose to spawn on, then 9 times out of 10 you will be spawned either way too far away (sometimes even being spawned closer to or on other objectives), or right on top of enemies (which can also happen regardless of where you spawn) leading to worryingly high amounts of spawn killing.

. The weapons and vehicles are horribly unbalanced, especially choppers and snipers. If you have decent players or sweats using either, then they can easily single you out and decimate you regardless of where you are. That and if the enemy team know how to take advantage of the layout and gameplay, then it can lead to unfair and one-sided matches.

. Hazard Zone...a mode so infamously bad EA gave up on it and shut it down, but unfortunately they couldn't be asked to remove the play option from the menu. Pressing the option just softlocks you into an infinite loading screen. Be aware of this if you were this of playing this mode.

. Despite the improvements, this game is still very buggy. Packet loss and lag can be abundant if your PC is doing anything other than running the game (Don't have anything in the background while playing this game). The game is also very susceptible to crashing. Hackers are also a problem in this game.


[h2] Final Score: 6/10 [/h2]

This game is a tried-and-true aim down the sights FPS. And its the battlefield format. I personally had a lot of fun in this game as someone with above average FPS skill, who was trying to both aim train and also warm myself up for the battlefield format in preperation for the new game. 

The battlefield format is not something I am the most experienced in; I put around 250 hours into Battlefield 1 over the course of that games lifespan and it was really good! There was a lot of variety and the class system made sense. That game had its own host of issues with EA's notoriously bad publishing and arthouse descisions when it comes to monitization. Overall, it had some great and bad maps, along with great and bad guns. Vehicles were kickass and it felt like there was a ton to do.

Battlefield 2042 is the 2022 installment of the battlefield franchise - the modern adaptation of the battlefield format. This game still boasts a full $60 pricetag, for a really lackluster overall game experience. I put in the majority of my hours into this game in 2025, after all 7 seasons worth of content for BF2042. I had lots of fun farming clueless players with some of the most overpowered weapons I've ever used in any online FPS. The AM40 outclasses basically every other AR and SMG in class, The Rorsch-mk4 is a hitscan, no drop-off railgun weapon which makes snipers and sightlines basically irrelevant, from any distance, which is still mind blowing to revisit. There was offline modes where you can earn XP and custom made AFK XP lobbies for people who don't want to play this game. The maps were shitty and there wasn't a lot of them. I would rather gouge my eyes out with a shard of hard plastic than play one round of Conquest on any of them. Breakthrough was a ton of fun because every map is a gradual hill where overwhelming force can only be done from the top of said hill. At least there is plenty of combo kills to get, attachments to grind out, calling cards to achieve, and any arrangement of situations you can put yourself in with no class weapon restrictions and the limited combo of vehicles and aircrafts available on some maps.

This game is rated at 48% overall reviews. If this game were free, I'd say that is completely disagreeable. For what you get though, the only things that kept me playing this game were its kind of strange weapon unlock system, the extremely overly long battle pass, and the brief potent hits of dopamine I get from frying an entire platoon of people in one of the very poorly designed chokepoints. I dunno. It's mid. But it's kind of good. Its good mids. Avoid this if you are replaying the entire battlefield franchise. If you were stuck on an island, and you had this game, it wouldn't be the worst. As a modern multiplayer experience this is another disappointment in a line of them. Battlefield 6 Hype carried all 100 of my hours.

This Battlefield was the biggest disappointment since BF existed. I bought it Day 1 for 99‚Ç¨ on PS5 because I expected special treatment as a hardcore fan. I hate the FOMO Battle Pass! 
I have like 10h per week to play. Enough to progress through the weekly missions to get the unlocks I want or even need. But I don't want to spend my preciuos time playing a game in a way I don't even want to play it. There are other games I want to play also, so curse you FOMO mechanics! 
But important specialist and vehicle unlocks need you to complete some BS tedious weekly missions just to get some points because grinding these points with regular gameplay takes forever. 

Yes you had the chance afterwards to unlock them with some missions like in BF3 but I never understood when they released because I was long gone and there were even weekly missions you couldn't complete because you hadn't unlocked the weapons in the battle pass before.

I liked the BF3 system better. Yes you had to grind through some objectives that were tedious but you could do it whenever you felt like it and after that you had your unlock.

Do I think it will be fun in a year? Not really because EA has a track record of killing franchises: Need For Speed, Mass Effect, Dragon Age, Command & Conquer, Dead Space, Star Wars Battlefront,...

After 95 Hours, It's Time for a Review

The game is now in a state it should have been at release.
It needs some work and balancing nothing major, but sadly it's at the end of its supported time

Maps:

Many maps need some work done, nothing major, but adding things here and there. 

Some of the big maps that were reworked aren't enough; they just shrunk the map and added some extra crates and other stuff to hide behind. That's a good start, but not enough.

In the map rotation are some BF5 maps, which worked well in BF5, a game with fewer explosions and a mechanic to rebuild defenses. An airfield with lots of barracks is now, after 20% of the game, just an open field with a capture point but no defenses.

Balancing:

Weapon: weapons balancing is mostly fine; some are a bit OP, but nothing major. Only snipers need some bullet drop and suppressed status when under fire. 

Vehicles: Tanks and other cars some weeks ago vehicles were nearly unkillable and had an extreme amount of firepower; now they have an extreme amount of firepower and are made out of paper. When you are in a tank, you can easily kill 10 people, but when someone has a rocket launcher, you are dead.

Hacker:

Wallhacks: are not easy to prove because of all the spotting gadgets, but I'm often in situations where it's really strange how they know where people are, because in my team they often don't like to spot people, and they have need really good teammates that are helping them.

Aimbot: I've seen more than once people on my team aim and look at enemies behind walls or above them on the roof when they were not spotted.

Performance:
Grafik und PC: its good nothing bad here
Connection: mostly good

As a long-time Battlefield fan, I can recommend this one, but I can't justify buying it all full price. The game still lacks polish in numerous areas, and it does not hit the highs of past entries, but I have had plenty of fun in the various modes.

Overall, I would rate it around a 6.8 out of 10. Here's why:

Where it shines:
The maps are large and visually impressive, and when the chaos kicks off it really does feel like a classic Battlefield game. Explosions, vehicles, and squads wrestling for the objective still create those unforgettable ‚Äúonly in Battlefield‚Äù moments. Gunplay feels pretty good, and levolutions are still here. Playing with friends absolutely elevates the experience. 

My main critiques:

Maps: The maps are vast and gorgeous, but sometimes they feel a bit too big for their own good. Certain modes, especially Breakthrough, suffer from balance issues. Some maps are super fun whether you are attacking or defending, but others are so lopsided that it is better to just leave and find a different match.

Specialists: On paper they sound cool, but Battlefield has never been about operators. It is about squads, teamwork, and chaos. You do not need hero characters for that, and any older Battlefield attests to this. I would rather be nameless machine-gunner #72 than a specialist with a gadget that anyone could use.

Class system: Letting every class use any weapon waters down the identity. You could argue it is flexible, but when I can sit back in spawn as Support with a sniper, ammo box, and shield, it just feels cheesy.

No campaign: The entire story is drip-fed through cinematics and codex entries. Killing off Pac, a beloved BF4 character, in a short film before the game even starts was weak. His death felt meaningless and lazy, especially when you consider he was with you for almost the entire campaign of BF4.

If none of these are deal-breakers for you, grab it on sale. There is still lots of fun to be had blowing stuff up with friends, just do not expect it to live up to the Battlefield legacy.

|‚Äé ‚ò¢Ô∏è Performance & Technical‚Äé‚Äé‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé|‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé‚Öß‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé ‚Äé|‚Äé
+---------------------------------------+---------+
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚Äπ‚Äπ Gameplay ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫ [10/10]
‚Äé ‚ÄéBattlefield 2042 has a good and smooth gameplay. Like all classic Battlefields, the Conquest and Breakout modes are very entertaining and have maintained their identity well. In addition, it has an interesting and somewhat mining mode called Hazard Zone, which is also entertaining in its own right. The variety of weapons is also good, but one of the negative points of this game is having different classes that take a while to get used to because previous versions of Battlefield only used four classes, which I think the old versions are better in this regard. But this cannot be considered too negative, but changing the structure of the game, which is popular for its simplicity and realism, is not very interesting.
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚Äπ‚Äπ Graphics ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫ [8/10]
‚Äé ‚ÄéThe graphics have always been beautiful in different versions of Battlefield and have always had a realistic atmosphere. In Battlefield 2042, they have also tried to maintain a realistic and logical environment in the future, and in this respect it has been good. However, having simple textures in some environments and having weak destructibility made this game less than expected. It must be said that one of the signatures of Battlefield is the destructibility of the environments and their effects on the gameplay, but unfortunately it performs poorly in this case. Of course, there are natural disasters in this game such as hailstorms and hurricanes, but these are not very interesting.
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚Äπ‚Äπ Sound & Music ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫ [6/10]
‚Äé ‚ÄéThe music in this game is not very interesting. Just a few sound effects that you hear from time to time, even one is not that impressive. If you listen to the music of Battlefield 3, 4 or 1, you will fully understand the weakness of this version of the game.
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚Äπ‚Äπ Story & Narrative ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫ [0/10]
‚Äé ‚ÄéAs a fan of the Battlefield franchise, I was really disappointed that this version didn't have a campaign or story mode.
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚Äπ‚Äπ World and Atmosphere ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫ [8/10]
‚Äé If I were to talk about the atmosphere of the game, it is really good and acceptable. The game environments are very well designed and large, and since the game is set in the future, we see logical and realistic structures (unlike Call of Duty). The game's weather is natural and the light colors of the environments are well preserved. I personally like the rainy and gloomy environments very much, which are well done in this case.
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚Äπ‚Äπ AI & Challenge ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫ [10/10]
‚Äé If you have played the custom modes or the portal mode (with AI), you will realize how good AI is in this game and it is kind of enjoyable because it gives the feeling of real players and performs exactly as you expect. Regarding the challenges of the game, I must say that it has challenging and completely fair challenges and completing them is quite enjoyable, whether to get cards or unlock attachments and guns or battle passes.
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏è‚Äπ‚Äπ Performance & Technical ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫ [8/10]
‚Äé The game has good performance and can be played with relatively old systems to some extent. But the game has some bugs that apparently have never been fixed and will never be fixed. For example, when playing, you will definitely encounter lag during animations or when structures are destroyed. Some of the game's animations have problems and of course there is also getting stuck somewhere on the map and sometimes it is really annoying. Most of the time, there is a problem with loading the game's textures and it takes a long time to load.
‚Äé 
‚ò¢Ô∏èBattlefield 2042 is a good and fun game, but it has some differences from what you might think of as previous versions, and this may not be satisfactory for many. Of course, this version does not have a single player mode or a story mode and is completely online.

Battlefield 2042 had a terrible launch and it deserved all the criticism it got but after putting in hours, I‚Äôve come to appreciate what it eventually became. It‚Äôs not on the level of Battlefield 3 or 4 which are still my top picks but there‚Äôs a solid game buried under all that mess. The gun-play feels good, squad play can still deliver that classic Battlefield chaos and some of the updates genuinely improved the experience. It still has its flaws, like weak map design and questionable balance but if you go in with tempered expectations, there‚Äôs fun to be had. It‚Äôs not the Battlefield we wanted but it‚Äôs no longer the joke it started as.

As Battlefield 6 approaches in couple of days, 2042 is worth revisiting only if you want to appreciate how far it‚Äôs come and how far the series still needs to go.

This game is almost good. It's infuriating, because most of the problems stem from the idiotic decision to design the entire game around Specialists and throw out the original class system back at launch. Why EA thought a hero shooter formula was a good fit for a game with 32 players per team is completely beyond me, but it feels like they wanted to prioritize the extraction royale Hazard Zone mode over the rest of the game at first, which flopped immediately so instead we were just left with the traditional Battlefield style scale balanced with a 4 player squad extraction royale in mind.

Granted, the game is in a far better state it launched in and a lot of the issues have been at least mitigated or addressed in some way, but there are still some serious problems. Gadget variety is pretty terrible since every specialists brings their own gadget to the first gadget slot, which isn't interchangeable at all. Want to run AT mines and a launcher? Too bad, you can only do that with Lis and have to deal with a super unmaneuverable TV guided missile launcher, the other two engineer specialists simply have turrets meant to counter infantry. A lot of the more powerful gadgets simply don't get used because the specialists they're tied to aren't fun to play or can't compete with the passives of another specialist.

Vehicle balance is pretty horrendous since the majority of conquest maps give both teams 2 Jets, 2 Attack helicopter, and a transport helicopter, and vehicle respawn is on a per player basis so you're just getting spammed by air for the entire match. Ground vehicles are oppressively mobile and omnipresent, and people don't seem particularly interested in coordinating AT launcher fire to counter them instead just preferring to run and gun against other infantry players, which was always a problem in BF but reached new heights with this game.

Player visibility across the board is pretty bad and oftentimes you'll just have to rely on looking for the orange dorito above people's heads to tell if someone's just being a bush wookie. And even if you do see someone, both teams use the exact same specialists and skins so you can't just tell at a glance what side someone is on without seeing their red lite-brites or seeing their red name above their head, which can be a problem. Which is funny because the infamous bots used to fill out servers have defined faction appearances and class designs which look a lot more interesting and cool than any of the basic default specialist skins. But apparently DICE thought we didn't want to play as soldiers, just zoomer mercenaries and old folks straight out of the retirement home.

Most guns are very low recoil and have very little spread so getting caught out by someone usually means very quick death even from a distance. Maps are far too open even after the passes made to tighten them up and add more cover, leaving you with classic Battlefield situations where sniper sightlines can just dominate the entire map and leave huge stretches of ground watched by vehicles that infantry just can't do anything about. Smaller scale modes like TDM and Rush suffer from poor map layouts that have the exact same issue of just too much open ground watched over by rooftops and long sightlines.

And then of course, no campaign. That's not a dealbreaker but you're undeniably just getting less content than other games that have some sort of singleplayer campaign on offer. All the lore is explained through calling cards (of all things) and a codex buried in the menu that nobody reads, and whatever voiceover both teams announcers give at the start of a match. And the story itself on display, what little there is, isn't very good. Blackburn is a eugenicist tech magnate obsessed with making cyborgs or something (????? how the fuck do you go from stopping New York being nuked to that?), the factions from 2142 are being established with the Mandate of Nations being the new EU after the old EU collapsed and lead to the No-Pats, and the Thousand Petals Coalition being the early incarnation of the PAC. The No-Pats themselves have basically formed Outer Heaven out of South Africa. It's just a mid story told in the worst way possible.

There are times the game really shines and feels like a real Battlefield game but everything just described severely holds it back. I don't think I'm ever going back to it after BF6 releases and I doubt anybody in this fanbase feels differently.
I feel sorry whoever spent money on this absolute "FUN" game. There is more issues than fun in it. Mindblowing how they released this and thought it was polished game.

Just completed every achievement in the game without even trying too hard ( the 25 hazard zone extractions was a grind ) but I finished everything in 160 hours just casually playing. I am a huge Battlefield fan, and when the game was first released it was super buggy and glitchy. 

But now ( 10/2/2025) honestly, it was not too bad of a game. Some of the map designs were silly, but that is over shadowed by the immense playablilty of this game. From conquest to rush, from tank to air superioirty, to hardcore, softcore, and even to hazard zone: there are so many game modes to play! 

I was a fun experience going from Battlefield 2042 to 1942 to Bf2 and so many classic maps that have been redesigned to be in the frostbite engine. I am waiting until BF6 comes out, but this is not a bad option to play until then. 

Only downside is there is no single player. But tons of Co-op and 4 man squad gameplay to run! 

I recommend playing this game.

Buying this game full price would be bonkers, but for $5 this is an okay amount of fun. I didn't dislike the time I spent getting the BF6 cosmetics. It's one of the games of all time. It has guns and shooting and stuff. And on Oct. 10th 2025 I'll prolly never think about it again.

I think just like anyone else who has made a recent review of this game, I only have this game because I wanted the Battlefield 6 exclusive items. But do I think this game is good? It's complicated. I don't think it's terrible but it's... meh. Especially after experiencing the BF6 Open Beta, the drastic difference in quality is uncanny. 

This game got so many things wrong and it's sad because in my personal opinion, this is the most interesting concept of a Battlefield game that isn't BF1. Sometimes the game is actually fun to play but most of the time, it feels like a slog. ESPECIALLY because most of the maps are awful. Most of the 64 player maps feel like it was made for 128 people, and the 128 people maps feel like 256 people maps. The maps are just WAY too big. And even if you do get to the enclosed maps like REDACTED (which is my favorite map on this game), the game turns into a glorified Call of Duty which isn't too much of an issue? The bigger issue is that this is a Battlefield game and for a Battlefield game, this is a disappointment.

I can't in full confidence say that this game is worth your time and I feel like if it wasn't for the BF6 exclusive cosmetics, I would feel like I wasted my life which to an extent I did. I appreciate the effort on the devs trying to turn around this mess but the damage was already done. And I am glad they learned their mistakes with this and now BF6 is turning out to be really promising. Though with the new EA deal that happened with the Saudis... it might blow over. Might.

BF2042 was 3 dollars though so it was kind of worth it.

Still, most matches are a sweatfest, just like any other shooter game post-2015ish, but a majority of matches only had a handful of sweat squads while the other 20~25 players are your typical "controller Fortnite Timmy" players, so that's something at least.

While BF2042 initially had a very rough launch, it's an incredibly fun game. It is more akin to COD than Battlefield, but if you don't mind that, it's a beautiful mix of BF and COD.

You know what, BF 2042's not as bad as folks made it out to be.  

Sure, it's absolutely on the COD-twitchfest side of gunplay and rewards more manic movements instead of tactical movement/positioning and such, and it took a bunch of updates and gameplay overhauls to reach this point, but I actually enjoyed myself while playing and grinding the free season pass leading up to BF6's release. 

It's obviously not a wise idea to grab this game at full price anymore though, especially since BF6 will no doubt absorb most of the playerbase and leave its servers considerably empty.  But if you happen to see a steep discount and wanna recreate those meme "Only In Battlefield" stunts, or like comp-stomping the AI bots?  Might not be too bad of a purchase.

This game is just okay.

It isn't too good nor bad, but it's just in the middle.

Before I start though, I wanna say that I'm actually fine with most of the stuff I'm going to talk about, since it won't really matter in real games. I just want to alert to the idea of what they were trying to and do and what they did do and how it kind of killed the games atmosphere and idea in general.

CAMPAIGN:
uhhhh
there isn't one

Multiplayer:
This is the only gamemode there is for 2042. That doesn't mean its bad just because its MP only, but anyways.
The guns are actually fine, there is a lot of attachments for different scenarios and combined with the quick attachment changing thing  you can use the same gun for a variety of different scenarios. Is it realistic? Not really, but it is helpful.
2042 also brings new modes like hazard zone which i haven't played but I assume its like EFT or MW22s DMZ. It also brings 128 player conquest, which is just conquest but with double the people. 
Probably my biggest issue with the game is the operators. What the FUCK were they thinking adding this. After having a perfect formula with BF3, 4, 1 and 5 they throw it out the window for some reason. It's not even like they were copying anyone significant since the popular games in 2021 were COD (MW19, BOCW, Vanguard) and fortnite, NEITHER having operators (that had different skills). If anyone, they copied BO3 and 4, but 3 was 2015 when they had 4 and hardline and 4 was around the BF1 and 5 era. 
Anyways, there's operators but to add salt to the wound you can use ANY gun on ANY class. Tbf this was the thing with every other game but at least they were shared weapons like SMGS and stuff, not any gun for anyone. The operators though I will admit are useful in their own ways, but I don't know about some grappling hook or wingsuit bullshit (I wish I was joking but these are deadass in the game), like this isn't Just Cause 3 (peak game btw buy it)

Then the skins, oh my lord the skins. They have:
COD type bullshit skins (at least not nicki manaj but whatever) 
Stupid looking gun skins
And just in general too much colors. 
I would much rather play an unknown soldier, not some celebrity operator with superpowers to not die. I would even accept the aforementioned weird gadgets if we could use them with their respective classes and without a specific operator. The operators don't even look cool or anything but they sound so fucking annoying.

With all of that said, this isn't a bad game. It's actually a pretty good game if you don't listen to the operators and don't cry about the gadgets like I did (I actually love the gadgets it just feels unrealistic). You can probably ignore the weird op skins too, but again it's just about the idea that they did this stuff.

Out of all Battlefield games this is the second one I ever played extensively. For the record, last FPS I played the heck out of was CoD:MW2  when it came out years ago. 
I heard of BF6 beta, installed it and were in for 3 days of absolute onslaught. I loved it. 
So much so, I figured I wanted to check out something else before BF6 release. I found BF2042 having the largest active player base at the time. Got lucky, it was on Steam on sale. 
I love it, its fun, it's what doctor ordered. I like the specialisms, the gadgets, the combat approach, being able to use ground and air vehicles. Following the news in the analog world I became aware of valiant Bradleys, and St.Javelins few years ago already... having discovered it in a game was a treat! More importantly it got me back into the frenzy of CoD:MW2 -- endorphins.
I would have loved to see this game to be more realistic, more gory, with enemies laid waste on the battlefield uncleared. 
In the end this is just a military themed sports multiplayer, it could have been football or hockey -- alas the last two are not my cup of tea. 
Wholeheartedly recommended. Lots of fun. Battlefield 6 is next when it comes on sale on Steam or scalper shops. Cheers!

while there is a lot about this game that is quite terrible, it does offer a unique experience that we'll never get again in a battlefield game.

the maps are pretty afwull, especially the open maps with plenty of space for snipers to just use a sniper rifle with bullets that have no dropoff and kill you from 750 meters away, these large maps also facilitate many very powerful vehicles like the blackbird helicopter and many weapons platform tanks and surprisingly few ways to fight them if supported properly.

the heroes are a terrible idea, it creates such a powergap, some heroes are just far better then others because they can do more on their own, the girl with the wingsuit and rain grenade outshines all other assaults, the recon with the hacking thing is just straight up more useful then the anti-targeting/tracking or little scout bot that only works for your squad.
for medics the girl with the healing gun is rediculously better then all others, and for the engineers i think the bald black guy with the deployable minigun is the strongest.
as you can see i don't remember any of their names.

on the vehicles, there's too many at once on any given map, if anyone is  good at flying the helicopters there is just no way to be rid of them, AA rocket launchers are a joke because a lot of heli's have re-chargeable flares, there's no limit to how many times they can just recharge the ability, and if push comes to shove, fly low and avoid any and all rockets while still mowing down hundreds without risk, yes i'm very salty  about blackbirds coming up next to my ear and whispering how fucked i am as they proceed to pinpoint accuracy shoot me with rockets, i tried it myself but i'm not an alien so the controls didn't make sense to me. i'm sure the guys who are great at flying them are having a great time though.

despite all that i am having a decent time with it, i got the game for 3 bucks so i definitely got my money's worth and has soured my experience with battlefield to the point where battlefield 6 will feel like such an improvement i'll be over the moon when i get to touch that, at this point i can no longer recommend the game as a lack of singleplayer content deems this game completely absolete in a week.
