This game is truly a mixed bag. Overall, I feel that the game is just flawed at a fundamental level.

First the good. The ability to customize your weapon while on the ground is awesome. Being able to change your weapon's attachments for close and far range engagements made the game more dynamic and fluid. Portal is a really great feature that they are expanding on in BF6. Being able to play my favorite BF3, BF4, and Bad Company 2 maps is just chief‚Äôs kiss. Lastly, and more personally, the easter eggs and love they gave the game with its final battlepass made me believe there are still some people who really care over at DICE despite all the crap we give them (and the crap they do to themselves in their work culture).

The bad, however, far outweighs the good. Gone are classes that have been a core to Battlefield, replaced by a range of characters that was merely made to fulfill a marketing diversity checkbox. Gone are weapons being exclusive to said classes, replaced with a half-assed class perk system that you‚Äôd hardly even notice is a thing. For some god-awful reason, they separated vehicle upgrades by faction and there are technically THREE of them: US, Russia, and personal. Gone is the destruction system to be replaced by 128 player matches which did not add to the experience whatsoever. 

Finally, XP farming for their battlepass is a fundamental issue. Why play assault at all when you can just play recon and rack up points with spotting assists? Why play engineer when you can run around reviving and giving people supplies as support? Why play at all when you can just join an AFK server and gain the points needed while you play other, more worthwhile games? This goes back to vehicle upgrades in that you must spend HOURS to upgrade your vehicles and that is just for one faction. If you want a SPECIFIC faction, you‚Äôre better off making your own portal server with rules that allow you to switch sides (thank God Dice allows you to do this for free).

So no, I do not recommend this game. BF6 will have many of the problems listed here delt with, but you can bet it‚Äôs not going to be a smooth ride and that is just part of the journey at this point.

This game is not at all worth full price. If you managed to get it on sale for $3 like I did, it's a pretty fun time waster, but I would definitely still say this is the weakest Battlefield game. It is infinitely better than it was on launch but still not amazing. If they put it on sale for $3 again or similar price, I would definitely say it's worth the price of admission. Though, with 6 right around the corner, I wouldn't be surprised if the playerbase for this game tanks rapidly, as I imagine most people playing right now are either grinding out the BF6 battlepass unlocks or are similar to me, new players from the $3 sale.

Very Call Of Duty styled weapon handling and gunplay. Recoil is negligible on most guns compared to BF norms, snipers are insanely powerful and easy to use, and Carbines are missing entirely. Pistols feel like shit other than the Magnums. 

Operator abilities range from hilariously broken to nearly useless, and battles can swing very fast as a result of a single operator. Falck in particular can revive nearly instantly, heal herself like Assaults can, and revives at full HP regardless of defib charge, meaning that you can gun down an entire group of enemies and then watch them all get right back up fully ready within 10 seconds. Meanwhile Paik has a detection gadget that is worse than the T-UGS that any recon can equip and reveals her own position, alongside a passive ability that is basically useless.

Map design is questionable at best, with very weird sightlines and strangely cluttered areas mixed with nearly barren ones. A lot of individual objectives seem well designed but overall map layouts feel very off as a returning player.

Portal is really cool but not worth the price of entry and it can be hard to find servers populated with modes you would actually want to play. Most portal servers are either crazy one-shot-kill super hardcore servers where if you step out of cover for a second you get nailed from miles away, or are weird EXP grinding servers where you can't actually play the game. Maybe if this game hadn't been such a disaster on launch Portal would have taken off more?

Overall, stay away for full price. If it still has a healthy playerbase after 6 releases and you can get it on a huge sale, it's worth the sale price.

Despite all of the fixes, map changes, balance passes and "immersion" updates, 2042 is not only the worst battlefield game, but probably one of the most tone deaf shooters I have ever played.

Weapon balancing that makes Hardline go weak at the knees.
Lore that might as well be from another game that is much better than this shit.
Worst of all, probably one of the most gut-wrenching renditions of the Battlefield theme, along with it's own exquisite selection of wet farts for music.

Just because this game goes on sale for 3-4 dollars does not excuse all of it's issues; you can buy Battlefield 1, 5, 4, and 3 for the same prices on their sales. Hell, you can even buy Bad Company 2 and play online with community servers.

The only legitimate reason to buy this game is if you [b]really[/b] don't have any other shooters to play, or you like burning money on whatever.

Even if Battlefield 6 is a disaster, there is genuinely no conceivable way it could be worse than 2042.

Forcing Secure Boot just to launch a game is absurd. It‚Äôs not a feature, it‚Äôs a liability. You‚Äôre asking players to risk their hardware stability for the privilege of playing a shooter that, frankly, isn‚Äôt worth the gamble. Battlefield has never been the kind of series that justifies putting your PC on the line, and it certainly isn‚Äôt now.

Then there‚Äôs the brag. You announced that 330,000 cheaters were banned during the beta, as if that number proves strength. In reality, it proves the opposite. If Secure Boot was supposed to be your great wall of defense, then how did hundreds of thousands of cheaters stroll right through it? That‚Äôs not a flex‚Äîit‚Äôs a confession that your ‚Äúsolution‚Äù doesn‚Äôt solve anything.

And here‚Äôs the kicker: by forcing Secure Boot, you didn‚Äôt stop the cheaters‚Äîyou punished the legitimate players. You created risk for the people who actually wanted to play fair, while the people breaking your rules carried on anyway. That‚Äôs not security, that‚Äôs incompetence.

So let‚Äôs be clear: Secure Boot didn‚Äôt protect your game, it didn‚Äôt protect your players, and it didn‚Äôt protect your reputation. All it did was prove that you‚Äôre willing to gamble with other people‚Äôs machines while pretending you‚Äôve got control. I‚Äôm not risking my PC for a franchise that can‚Äôt even secure itself. Battlefield isn‚Äôt worth it, and no amount of PR spin will change that.

PRETTY FUN

SBMM is completely broken, the desync in this game is by far the worst I‚Äôve ever experienced, and you're constantly matched with awful teammates while being forced to fight players who've been grinding since Day 1.

Seriously, the desync is so bad it makes me want to rip my hair out. The game shows a ping of 30ms almost all the time, yet I'm still getting killed while clearly behind cover.

Your team rarely plays the objective and is too scared to push 90% of the time. Solo queueing is unbearable. With the way health and gunplay works, unless you catch someone off-guard or you're in the top 1%, you‚Äôre likely not clutching anything.

For some reason, shotguns can kill you from 50 meters away. I've lost count of how many times I‚Äôve started shooting someone with a marksman rifle, only to get one-tapped in the head by buckshot. It‚Äôs ridiculous. I‚Äôm so sick of FPS games turning shotguns into jack-of-all-trades weapons. COD is guilty of this too‚Äîarguably even worse. Shotguns shouldn‚Äôt dominate most gunfights. If I‚Äôm shooting someone at range, I should be able to outgun them. But right now, you can‚Äôt.

The enemies you fight are unbearable. It‚Äôs always a squad of snipers with 1,000+ hours, or someone in a helicopter with the same. It‚Äôs rare to find a match where you‚Äôre not sweating every second just to stay competitive.

This game is also missing so many core features from previous Battlefield titles. There is absolutely no reason I should have to requeue after every match. You grind for 10-20 minutes depending on the mode, and then you‚Äôre forced to sit in a queue again before starting all over.

Players don‚Äôt even play their roles properly. Snipers run around like they‚Äôre using assault rifles, and assault players are too scared to push past the first objective. Medics rarely heal or revive; your squad will watch you bleed out and run right past you like you don‚Äôt exist.

The map variety is pathetic. Maybe it‚Äôs because I don‚Äôt have the Ultimate Edition and there are DLC maps I‚Äôm missing, but after 20 hours, I feel like I‚Äôve played the same five maps over and over. And yes, I know there‚Äôs more content in Portal‚Äîbut I‚Äôm playing Battlefield 2042 to play 2042. If I wanted Battlefield 3, I‚Äôd just go play Battlefield 3.

Overall, this is by far the worst Battlefield game ever made. The HUD color scheme is ugly‚Äîit looks like a mobile game with all the bright light-blue highlights. The guns don‚Äôt feel right; it often feels like I'm firing non-lethal rounds. There are a million attachments for each gun, most of which offer little to no noticeable difference. There are like three different suppressors, compensators, and grips, and I can't tell them apart except for the visuals. Also, thermal scopes don‚Äôt work through smoke‚Äîwhich, correct me if I‚Äôm wrong, is the entire point of a thermal scope.

Thankfully, Battlefield 6 is on the horizon, and it looks like they‚Äôre finally learning from their mistakes. All we can do now is pray.

[h1] The Good, The Bad and The Worry for BF6 [h1]

BF2042 is a rough ride. At launch, it was miserable ‚Äî constant disconnects, unbearable lag, and kills that felt like finding the Holy Grail. I walked away, especially when the game leaned into live-service trends like battle passes and seasonal grinds. Recently I gave it another shot during double XP weekends, hoping it had improved before BF6. It hasn‚Äôt. I still don‚Äôt enjoy it, and I‚Äôm worried that some of its worst elements might bleed into the next game.

[h2] The Good [h2]

Visuals & Maps: The maps are beautiful, even if some blend together.

Portal: A creative mode that allows for unique war sims and scenarios, often as engaging as full-priced titles.

Weapons: A large arsenal, letting you find a favorite (though balance issues make many weapons pointless).

Weather Effects: Tornadoes and sandstorms are gimmicky but fun, sometimes more enjoyable than the game itself.

[h2] The Bad [h2]

Map Design: Most maps are far too big, a sniper‚Äôs paradise. For AR and SMG players, it feels awful. Even at a 70 FOV, spotting enemies is a blurry mess.

Portal Abuse: Once a highlight, it‚Äôs now plagued with AFK grind lobbies and restricted XP, making it pointless.

Community: Toxic, camp-heavy, and more like COD than the Battlefield of old. Veterans dominate with ‚Äúmeta builds,‚Äù leaving newcomers frustrated.

Squad Play: Playing with friends is unreliable; one of you often gets kicked mid-match.

Music: Grating and out of place, distracting more than immersive.

 [h2] Why I‚Äôm Worried About BF6 [h2] 

Most fans already know the issues with specialists and progression, so I‚Äôll focus elsewhere:

Customization: Battle passes make everyone look the same. Let players personalize their characters.

Map & Spawn Design: Both BF2042 and the BF6 beta suffer from poor spawn points and oversized, empty-feeling maps. ‚ÄúBig‚Äù doesn‚Äôt have to mean ‚Äúvacant.‚Äù Give us large, but meaningful, maps with good flow and fewer cheap deaths.

BF2042 had potential but squandered it with poor design and live-service baggage. I can only hope BF6 learns from these mistakes.

Battlefield 2042, like its predecessors, has always been a sandbox-like FPS. All the gadgets, vehicles, and their abilities allow each player to approach the battle in different ways with a lot of freedom and this is what, for me, separates the series from other FPS like CSGO or CoD. The modern vehicles add a lot of variety and chaos to matches and are quite well balanced, as they can influence the tide of battle without being too OP or having too much health. A tank without infantry escort, just like in real life, won‚Äôt last long.

Players move really fast, opening up many tactical opportunities, but there are drawbacks. By making the pacing so fast, you get that adrenaline rush from the game, but it also means you may be attacked from any direction. This translates to a lot more deaths and what often feels like a meatgrinder; you spawn, rush to the point, die 15 seconds later, and start spamming the respawn button again. 
Also. some maps are also way too big, and both teams end up spreading everywhere, turning the entire play area into a no man‚Äôs land.

Unfortunately, the game practically removed environmental destruction except for a few large-scale events. That, at least for me, was a big selling point of the previous titles, not only is it fun to ‚Äúblow things up,‚Äù but it also adds strategy by opening new paths or exposing camped enemies.

I instead really liked Portal and the custom server modes. With Portal, you can play with content from many older BF titles while also creating custom rules for your own matches. 
For example, you can invite a friend into your private lobby and play a co-op PvE match set in WWII with uniforms and vehicles from Battlefield V or even the Vietnam DLC from Bad Company 2. It‚Äôs not at the same level of a Halo forge but offers a lot of possibilities.

[h3]Conclusions[/h3]
The game was an incomplete, broken mess at launch, and many features like QoL and Portal were added later, making a lot of people (myself included) change their minds. That‚Äôs why I strongly advise not to be afraid of its bad online reputation and just give it a go, maybe with a friend, since it‚Äôs often on sale. 
It won‚Äôt ever be the best Battlefield, but with time, it has become a somewhat great and enjoyable game.

This should be a "mixed" review, but steam doesn't have a mixed rating for individual reviews. 

Let me preface this by saying that I actually hate pvp shooters, and the only way I'd really play one is if a friend joined me on one. So maybe take what I say with a grain of salt, especially since i first played this long after the garbage launch this game had. What brought me to this game ironically enough was both the sale of it being for only 3 dollars, and watching gameplay videos of the BF6 beta and seeing how much people praised it, so i decided to pick this up. I've actually never played a BF game before so this is actually my first endeavor into this series. First impression of this game was weirdly good, for a 3 dollar game discounted from 60. Several hours later, the biggest problems with this game started sticking out like soar thumbs. The biggest one being, the god awful map design that makes it easy for someone to equip snipers and spawn kill everyone from the enemy team spawning in from a somewhat far but close location. The other big problem is the borderline nonexistent methods of countering the tanks and fighter jets, worsened by just how straight up OP they both are. The only counters are the anti tank mines that some of the tanks have, and the RPGs that the engineer class has, and even then it's not a guarantee to bring ether of them down with them, so it just leads to someone with a tank easily shreading a group from an enemy team to bits. Being constantly faced with those 2 problems in most matches simply lead to me deciding I've had enough of this game and decided to uninstall it and just not bother with the free battle pass. Which is such a shame because I actually liked the gameplay loop that mixes together co op and pvp togehter that this game (and other BFs) have. I put in 30 hours in total, so I did end up getting my 3 dollars worth of it, and that is probably all what this experience is worth, not 60. To end this off, this game did one good thing, which was entice me to want to try the older BF games the next time they go on sale. Let's just hope EA/DICE learned their lesson from this game and NEVER makes a game as bad as this one ever again.

Oh, Battlefield 2042‚Ä¶ what a disaster you started out as.

I originally bought the game on PlayStation back in 2021. While I managed to put in around 70 hours and had some fun, it was impossible to ignore how disappointing it felt. For a franchise that‚Äôs so close to my heart, it was clear that the game lacked many of the qualities that made earlier entries shine.

Recently, I decided to reinstall it thanks to a discount and some unlocks for BF6. To my surprise, much has been improved, and I ended up sinking another 60 hours into it.

The game still feels a little soulless and generic at times, but there‚Äôs definitely fun to be had. One of my favorite aspects is the sense of scale that comes with 128 player Conquest. The addition of weekly missions pushes me to experiment with different weapons and tactics, which keeps things fresh. Text and voice chat have finally been added, and some genuinely great maps too. Plus, the cringey voice lines? Gone.

Final Verdict:

Launch: 6/10

Now: 7.5/10

I‚Äôm cautiously optimistic about Battlefield 6, but I can only hope EA doesn‚Äôt crush those dreams‚Äîas they‚Äôve done before

Now that I've finally finished the free pass and unlocked all the skins for Battlefield 6, I can honestly say without a doubt that while the game is definitely better than when it first released...that's not by much.

Lets start with one of the worst aspects. The net code. You are guaranteed to get shot around corners constantly, shots will often go right through enemies (as if their hitbox is non-existent), or sometimes it feels like it takes an entire mag to kill one enemy. That works both ways though. Sometimes enemies put an entire mag in you and you shoot like 5 bullets and kill them instantly. The amount of times I've eliminated enemies who were around a corner already and no longer in my line of sight is CRAZY.

The operators are dumb, their powers are even dumber. The irony that this game takes place in 2042 and is for some reason far more futuristic than Battlefield 2142 that came out in 2006 but is somehow in the same universe makes ZERO sense. I feel like a good 80% of the abilities are just made to annoy you. Dozer's shield, Paik's wallhack, Boris's sentry, Crawford's deployable turret that has infinite ammo (but can overheat and cool down quick). Funniest operator's ability is Casper and his drone. Talk about untested. The drone's hitbox is massive for such a tiny drone. Its hilarious.

I think the only real fun I had in the game is the phantom easter eggs and playing with friends because they enjoy it and its quality time to spend with them. Playing this game alone is torture. The biggest blessing was uninstalling this off my drive permanently and I can guarantee once BF6 releases, most players will not look to come back to BF2042.

Genuinely the worst Battlefield game ever made. (Battlefield Hardline runs circles around this game)
All of my playtime on this steaming pile of shit has been to unlock items for Battlefield 6, and it has honestly been a nightmare.
I purchased this game well over a year ago for $2.50 and played less than 1 hour at that time, only to realize that the game was complete shit. And that was back then. Guess what, nothing has changed.
This game is riddled with bugs, hit registration issues, and flawed mechanics that cause players to feel only frustration and grief. "Hero" style playable characters only retract from the typical Battlefield experience. Making unique characters has somehow had the opposite effect and makes everyone feel less important. Most of these characters have borderline useless abilities or they are only applied in very unique scenarios that require specific maps or conditions to be met before they are actually useful.
Battlefield is primarily a multiplayer experience, but without a campaign you are left with only a PvE bot-mode that gives reduced experience and no battlepass progression.
Maps are easily forgettable and lack any kind of interesting or unique features.
Nothing about this game is actually good.
After Battlefield 6 comes out, I think I will either hide this game or remove it entirely from my Steam library to hide my shame that I wasted so much time for such pointless cosmetics IN AN ENTIRELY DIFFERENT GAME.
Nobody is actually going to purchase this game after the time I post this review, but it still deserves to have a low review score.

Objectively the worst Battlefield title, I have heard 5 was worse but I never played it so 2042 gets that title instead. I've been around this series since like '08 so I feel like I can judge it pretty well. 

This one is kind of fun and sort of okay here and there but it really just handles like one of those free to play FPS games that were all over the place in the late 2000's early 2010's. You might like that, it's not my thing, and it's not a Battlefield thing. It's like playing a knockoff of itself, kinda like BF:Play4Free except that was free. I could nitpick the problems like the lame gunplay, weak map design, busted spawn system, etc., but there are other reviews that do that a lot better.

I got my pass completed, EA got their cash grab and boosted player count to tell the suits their worst game did great, and they also got an honest review. If this isn't on sale for free don't bother, unless you like not-battlefield battlefield games I guess? Even if you do, though, don't pay full price. It's pretty janky and there's a cash shop in it.
Even if it were free, this game would still be unworthy of your time.

I'm not really a Battlefield veteran by any means, but I've played a lot of BF1, a bit of BF5 and BF6 Beta, so here is mine "newbie to BF" opinion after 160+ hours. 

Let's start with positive things first, it won't be long lol:

Still Battlefield. Despite all the hate after release and even now, game still offers large-scale warfare, "only in Battlefield" moments and vehicle sweats of course. Take 128 players conquest for example, there are mini battles everywhere around the map. A unique experience.

Movement. It's somewhat of an improvement over BF5 and especially over BF1. There are different elements like slide cancel, jump peek and bunny hopping. I would say that you need to master movement to use it efficiently so it adds a skill depth to the game.

Graphics. Although game has forced TAA, it still looks nice even on low settings. DLSS 4 helps a bit with overall TAA blur, but it's still there. But no FSR/XeSS unfortunately.

Gunplay. There are a lot of guns to try out, some of them are definitely meta, but overall it's a balanced experience. TTK is okay, I guess.

Portal. Great idea actually, some of the custom experiences are fun (if you can find them), brings somewhat of a nostalgia playing BC2, BF3 and 1942 maps.

But, there are some negative moments:

Some of the "future" gadgets. 
Since I mostly try to flank enemy, I definitely like being spotted by Boris's turret, recon drone or "Ranger" the robodog. Nothing is more pleasurable than spending time to shoot them down only to reveal your position and die. Nice.
Mounted Vulcan? That portable minigun with a shield??? Don't even get me started on this.

Pushing using smokes? Forget it. You have thermal sights in the game which you can swap on the go, by the way, and Rao, who can hack you and reveal your entire team around you in the smoke. Oh, let's add Mounted Vulcan spam and Scatter Grenades. You shall not pass!

Some of the maps are great, some of them terrible for infantry. Imagine you have captured an objective close to your base and what do you do now if objective captured by enemy is on different side of the map? You run, maybe for a minute, two or three only to get sniped or killed by vehicle sweat.

Destruction is definitely lacking compared to previous games, it's there, but not really a scale of BF3 or BF4. I would like to see levolution more than weather effects, which do nothing in this game, only get annoying.

Mouse input problem haven't been fixed, it's still there, it's broken and you there's nothing you can do about it. Engine level issue. 

Performance on my end is not really great. Yeah, I get high average FPS, but game suffers from frame pacing issues. I can definitely notice poor 1% lows and frametime dips even on 5700X3D. And no, upgrading to 9800X3D and DRR5 won't fix it, it just how the game works.

Specialists should be gone from Battlefield. There are mechanics in the game that involve using specific specialists to counter them, it really sucks when no one in your team plays Rao for example and I have to play it just to get rid of the annoying vehicle sweats even though I have enough engineers in my team.

I have little to say about sound design, but it's not that good compared to other games. It's fine, I guess, but I've heard better.

Vehicles? Couldn't care less, I'm an infantry enjoyer.

Conclusion: BF2042 has its own pace that similar to BF6 and that's why many people are playing it or have played it. Previous BF games are different in terms of play style, so if you're not a fan of BF1 and BF5, but you still want modern Battlefield, there's nothing else right now. I think that's the main reason why people play it. There's nothing else. 

But if we throw all this aside, it's definitely not the best FPS. BF6 is better in terms of gunplay, sound design and overall vibe, it's pretty evident in comparison.

This game launched as a broken, underwhelming mess, and while the devs have done their best to turn it around, the core design flaws (64v64, specialists, oversized BR-style maps) still drag it down. Vehicles are fun and varied, but the gunplay, attachments, and especially the maps lack depth, the latter being the biggest offender with huge, empty spaces that just feel bad to play on.

Some post-launch maps and updates are decent, and overall the game has become a pretty casual Battlefield experience that can be fun in short bursts. I don‚Äôt see it staying alive once BF6 arrives, but revisiting it to unlock the free pass content was a decent time.

BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP.... BEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEP... MISSLE INCOMING! DUMP FLARES, DODGE "LIS"SILE, RINSE REPEAT.  

As a BF player since BC2, not only is this a disgrace to be called "Battlefield" but the overall experience is completely lackluster on all fronts. The lac of class lock is an abysmal decision by every aspect of Battlefield's core game play. Nothing feels rewarding because its either easily countered by cheese operator kit's or the game's optimization or lack of. The guns feel no different across the board, the full selection is nice to have if they didn't copy paste every single weapon with a re-skin of a past BF game, the selection is nice. 

Side note, I play BF to fly. With that being said, there is little to no chance of making any significant effort in a game with the selection of all operators in a single game being engineer. Most games, 75%-80% of the team are engineer and that's being generous. Couple that with the amount of AA weapon kits across foot and vehicles, it is borderline impossible to do anything worth while in a rotary wing aircraft. Not only that, the only way to make the aircraft worth anything is by leveling it up. So if you don't want to hop into an AI match to farm bots to level the kit up, you're stuck dumping flares, falling back to cover, rinse repeat without a chance to kill anything, because again, there is zero optimization for any of the weapon's. 

Terrible hit registration for both ground and vehicle weapons. The Apache (all weapon systems minus the gunner) are quite literally useless. Dumping 10 rockets on a single ground operator is overkill. I get that's why there is a gunner and IRL, that's how it is. But don't give the opportunity to also fly/shoot and it be like I'm knitting sweaters and tossing balls of yarn at them. The little bird is really the only rotary wing aircraft that has any value. 

I have never in my life wanted to suck start one of their marshmallow shooters so badly but because of the hit registration, I'm sure it'll rubber band into the ceiling. 

Thanks EA, you've sure made another heaping pile of "IDGAF, GIVE ME MONEY"

Went from on release being by far the worst Battlefield game ever made to one of my favourites with the huge caveat that it took them years and years to actually fix the game into something worth playing and it still bears the scars of the mishandling and abuse of DICE by EA that forced them to truncate so much in the pursuit of trying to force the game into becoming something it's not. (Hero shooter battle royal pee pee poo poo lame ass shit that took years to walk back.) Result being that its best moments are in the games twilight years. Which is a shame because I think this current version of the class system is great and it has some amazing maps, Exposure, Kaleidoscope and Redacted being the standouts for me with some of the most verticality this series has ever had. Exposure especially I will be thinking of for a long time. It also has by far the most vehicle variety in the series. Especially with this recent update adding even more vehicles into the game. 

Battlefield Portal was an amazing Idea that because of the game flopping meant we never got any extensions to it like BC 2 Vietnam being added or 4. The story mode and lore sounded really interesting with returning characters from both 3 and 4 making a comeback like Blackburn for example and then serving as a bridge to 2142 but it was scrapped and reduced to a series of text logs in the compendium. This game gives me a feeling so complicated because of how fun it is to play now but how much we lost. I weep for what could have been is all.

Game crashes every 10-20 minutes. You need to have EA open and steam to play so its resource heavy. I have Researched, uninstalled/installed and repaired my way to madness to try to get it to stop crashing to no avail. It has so many problems that I'm losing hope to play BattleField 6.

I bought this solely for the BF6 rewards. It was on a 95% off sale, and I got an extra 10% off with my EA play subscription. Hence, I have very little invested in the game. 

Even so, I don't think it's very good. Whilst there is still some fun to be had, the sheer abundance of unacceptable core problems sap most of that enjoyment away.

[b]Gunplay[/b]

It's decent, for the most part. I have noticed plenty of instances of terrible hitreg however, particularly when hip firing. If the entirety of my crosshair is overlapping with the enemy player right in front of me, I should expect the majority of my shots to hit. I should not expect to see no hitmarkers and be killed by that enemy after a few seconds of shooting at him.

[b]Matchmaking[/b]

No persistent servers. You have to requeue after every game. This would be fine expect the matchmaking is fairly slow, sometimes taking 3 or 4 minutes to find a game. I also struggled to find matches for close quarters conquest, and I have yet to find a match for 128 player conquest. I was frequently dumped into matches that were either finished or a few seconds away from finishing so I'd have to requeue immediately.

[b]Vehicles[/b]

Being in a vehicle is fun. Not being in a vehicle is not fun. Very difficult to fight back against a moderately skilled chopper pilot, even with guided missiles. I shouldn't need to play Engineer every round just to stand a chance.

[b]Spawning system[/b]

On multiple occasions I came very close to punching and breaking my laptop screen. The spawn system in this game is complete bullshit. I was regularly, CONSISTENTLY spawned in direct line of sight of enemies, sometimes even in the exact spot they were already firing, so that I died before I'd even gained control of my character. This is unacceptable. It doesn't help that choosing where you spawn is extremely inconsistent (If I pick C, I should spawn at C. I should not spawn next to B so that I have to walk to C. If I wanted to spawn at B, I would pick B) and sometimes doesn't work (you often can't spawn on your teammates for seemingly no reason, even if they're not in combat.

[b]Map design[/b]

Way too big, way too open, way too much walking around. This plus the spawn system means a lot of wasted time each game just trying to get to where you want to be.

[b]Other stuff[/b]

I will admit that for all the bullshit, I did still have some rare moments of fun. There were a few 'Battlefield' moments, where everythings exploding and the entire team rushes the point together. Those are cool. But they'd be cooler in any other Battlefield game.

I intend on playing 2042 until I unlock the remaining 2 rewards for BF6. After that, I will likely never touch it again. There are better ways to spend your time and money.

Having been a huge fan as a kid of Battlefield 2 and 2142 and hearing about the release of 2042 I was genuinely very excited. Now, having been years later I will say that I do think the game has improved immensely, but... I'll admit I'm still rather salty we never got more direct usage of prototypes going into the futuristic warfare and losing the 64v64 game mode.

This is a great Battlefield game to play but that wasn't originally the case. The game didn't have a very good launch, as it was initially plagued with technical bugs and gameplay imbalances. Since then however, it has been improved upon to the point that it now offers a great gameplay experience. As with previous Battlefield titles, this game provides an outstanding immersive experience thanks to its great graphics, sound effects, and gunplay.

As its title suggests, the game's events take place in the year 2042. After several environmental disasters and global societal collapse, only 2 superpowers remain: the United States and Russia. While the game focus is on their worldwide conflicts, it doesn't have any impact on gameplay since both factions have access to the same weapons and equipment. Even though both sides possess some faction specific vehicles, it doesn't matter again since they share similar characteristics to promote balanced gameplay.

You can count on Battlefield games to offer an incredible immersive experience and Battlefield 2042 is no exception. The graphics look amazing. The sound effects are incredibly realistic sounding. The gunplay is responsive and fluid. Some maps even have scripted weather events like tornadoes and sandstorms which impact gameplay. You can get caught in a tornado if you get to close to it.

Break. There are a large number of different weapons classes in the game. Assault rifles. LMGs. SMGs. Sniper Rifles. DMR's. Shotguns. Crossbows. Pistols. melee attacks and executions. RPGs. Anti air weapons. However, there are so many weapons in each class that it leads to overlapping characteristics among some weapons.

There are also many different vehicle classes available for use. tanks. Jeeps. infantry fighting vehicles. jets. helicopters. quad copter. hovercraft. While there aren't too many vehicles in each class, they share similar characteristics as to promote game balance.

However, there are some negatives to the game. it's common for vehicle sounds to sometimes cut out as a result of so many game sounds running concurrently. This can lead to tanks inadvertently sneaking up on unaware players who didn't hear these ordinarily loud vehicles. the game's building destruction is inconsistent, with many buildings having limited or no destructibility due to map design. Battlefield 2042 features various levels of environmental destruction, from micro-destruction of small objects and debris to large-scale destruction that allows players to create new paths by blowing holes in walls.

In closing, I think Battlefield 2042 is a great game to play. It offers gamers a consistent battlefield gameplay and immersive experience that they've come to expect. And that's why I gave this game a score rating of 8 out of 10.

I bought Battlefield 2042 because I wanted to experience the future of warfare. The future, apparently, is 127 people running around like headless chickens while I get sniped from across the map by a guy named ‚ÄúxX420NoScopeJesusXx.‚Äù

Highlights of my career as a soldier of tomorrow:

Spawned in, immediately died to a hovercraft doing donuts on a skyscraper.

Called in a tank, crushed by my own tank. Respect the circle of life.

Tried to revive a teammate‚Äîhe gave up mid-revive and bled out while staring directly into my eyes. Haunting.

Climbed a 50-story building for ‚Äútactical advantage,‚Äù got hit by a tornado, ended up in Narnia.

Discovered the wingsuit. Spent 2 hours pretending I was in Just Cause 4. Killed no one, had the time of my life.

My specialist shouted a quirky one-liner right after I got blasted by a rocket launcher. Very immersive.

The game promised ‚ÄúAll-Out Warfare.‚Äù They delivered. Just not sure if it‚Äôs against the enemy team or my own sanity.

In its current state, there‚Äôs little to complain about regarding the performance of Battlefield 2042. The game runs smoothly and without major issues. However, the design choices behind the maps leave much to be desired. Most of them feel like vast, empty fields with very little cover, making gameplay repetitive and uninspired. Even in team deathmatch, the maps are often either far too large or far too open, which hurts the pacing and intensity.

Spawn points can also be frustrating, sometimes placing players miles away from the action. Another strange design choice is the flow between matches: instead of seamlessly moving to the next round, the game kicks you back to the main menu before starting again. It feels unnecessary and disruptive.

On the positive side, the weapon mechanics are solid, the vehicles feel fine, and performance is great, the game runs buttery smooth. Unfortunately, good performance (now after 4 years) alone isn‚Äôt enough to make the game feel like a true Battlefield experience. Destruction, a defining feature of the series, is almost completely absent. Most maps lack personality or atmosphere, with only a few exceptions that manage to stand out.

Another major issue is how heavily casualized the game feels compared to its predecessors. The introduction of operators and their cringe voice-lines at the end of a round, which were later forced into loosely defined class systems, was probably one of the biggest mistakes the developers could have made. This change stripped away much of the tactical depth and identity that Battlefield was known for. Often, the maps and overall atmosphere feel strangely empty, more like a knock-off set in some alternate Rainbow Six Siege universe rather than a proper Battlefield game.

And then there's the soundtrack, which, with all due respect, is probably one of the worst I've ever heard. After just one hour, I turned the in-game music off entirely because it was more of an insult to the ears than an enhancement to the atmosphere. Whoever was responsible for the soundtrack should, frankly, never be allowed anywhere near the development studio again.

Overall, while Battlefield 2042 performs well technically, it falls short in nearly every other area. From uninspired maps and poor design choices to its disastrous soundtrack, the game fails to capture the soul, atmosphere, and identity that once defined the franchise.

The only reason anyone would play this game now is to get the cosmetics for BF6, which is what I'm doing. Good for EA/DICE getting some goodwill back. How messed up is it that we're looking EA of all companies to save FPS games?

Anyways, do not get this game. I don't know if it's an AMD issue or what but this game is constantly crashing. My friends have Nvidia and still suffer crashes but mine seem to be way more frequent. Blue screens, complete crashes, you name it and 2042 does it. Alt-tab? Crash. Watching a video on the side? Crash. It's embarrassing that a game and an anti-cheat is this unreliable. I hope it'll be more stable for BF6.

But outside of constant crashing, the game is also just not good. Open weapons feels wrong in a Battlefield game. That isn't to mention how abysmal the maps are. They are the worst part of the game. Want a map with a giant boat in the middle with sniper spots that have a complete 360 unobstructed view of the entire map and nothing else? This game has 2 maps like that. In fact, every map suffers from giant centerpiece and unobstructed sniper spot. It's terribly designed and there's only so much fun you can have on those maps.

Look, this isn't a bad game (and I only paid four dollars for it) so I won't give it a negative review.  (Give us a "mid" rating, Steam.)  "This is Battlefield" to those who like this formula so I'm not gonna spit in the face of the players who enjoy this.  ... that's just it, though.  This doesn't feel like a BF game to me.  This feels more like a hero shooter with Battlefield's DNA written all over it.

I'd probably be more into that, if it didn't feel like I was required to learn a whole new layer to this franchise.  A game that usually doesn't include this level of... customisation.  It's like someone reached in, placed a few extra key-binds with various gadgets/equipment, gave us huge fuck off maps with mechanics + vehicles no one asked for and went, "That'll do.  They'll all love this!"  You can like that all you want, that's 100% up to you- this just isn't what I'd usually look for in a BF game.

When I play BF2042, I'm essentially looking for a game that's nowhere near an ARMA game or a CoD game, a SQUAD or an *Insert 'Generic Hero Shooter' here.*  I'm looking for an experience worthy of the title "This is Battlefield." Title: Battlefield 2042 - The Future of Disappointment

Review:
Do you like paying full price for a tech demo? Do you dream of weapons that sound like Nerf guns, maps the size of small countries but with the action density of a retirement home, and ‚Äúspecialists‚Äù who all look like Fortnite interns on casual Friday, 128 players running marathons across empty maps, guns that sound like airsoft toys, Then boy, do I have a product for you.

This game promised ‚Äúthe future of Battlefield‚Äù and delivered‚Ä¶ a futuristic PowerPoint presentation where bullets are optional, and patch notes are the real endgame.

Pros:

- The uninstall button works flawlessly.
- Pretty clouds.

Cons:

- Everything under them.

This Battlefield... It‚Äôs not a bad game in itself, far from it, but it suffers from major problems that spoil the experience, especially for the purists of the series:

Random and unstable ping: It‚Äôs the nightmare. During a game, my ping can suddenly reach 150 ms and get stuck like that. It‚Äôs all the more frustrating when on BF1 and BF5, I have absolutely no problem. It seems that EA and their servers have a complicated relationship...

Unbalanced maps: Some maps cruelly lack balance, which can quickly become boring.

Unintuitive interface: Compared to the clarity of BF1 or BF5, the interface here lacks readability and is less ergonomic.

Limited destructibility: It‚Äôs a major disappointment. One of the essences of Battlefield is the destruction of buildings. It‚Äôs a shame to see this feature so neglected.

(Optional) Absence of a real single-player campaign: Even if it is not the heart of the game for everyone, the lack of a scripted story, as we could have had in BF1 or BF5, leaves a taste of unfinished.

So, why recommend it anyway?
Despite these big flaws, I recommend this game for a simple reason: its price on promotion. For 3 euros, it would be a shame to miss it. We won‚Äôt complain too much at that price. It‚Äôs a title that allows one to let off steam and unwind when everything works out (which, let‚Äôs be honest, is not always the case).

I sincerely hope that EA will be able to set the bar right. They have an exceptional license in their hands, but it is unfortunately tarnished by decisions that seem more guided by pocket filling than by real skill in the video game. Courage to the developers...

I've played a lot of Battlefield over the years, and after all the updates, Battlefield 2042 has finally earned its place among the greats. Yeah, the launch was rough ‚Äî no denying that ‚Äî but credit where it's due: DICE has turned things around in a big way.

The scale of the battles is still unmatched. 128-player chaos, vehicles flying past, tornadoes ripping through the map ‚Äî it‚Äôs the kind of madness only Battlefield can deliver. Portal is a sleeper hit too. Being able to play classic maps with new weapons and rulesets adds a ton of variety.

Specialists took some getting used to, but I actually enjoy the flexibility now. The game feels more like a sandbox where you can play your way, and it works. Movement feels great, gunplay is tight, and the map reworks have improved flow a lot.

If you bounced off at launch, it's worth giving it another shot. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs fun, and that‚Äôs what matters. Especially on sale.

I never played 2042 outside of the beta till the BF6 rewards came and the game was on sale for 1.99 USD but even for that this game still cost to much. I have never in my life outside of UE5 game seen a game so poor optimized. For Reference I have a 3080 12G edition, a Ryzen 5600x, and 32 GB of Ram at 3200 CL16, all the while running the game at medium settings. This game will sure be at 144 FPS which is the refresh rate of my monitors, but holy hell this game sit a max CPU utilization and even with the the community config file that's meant to help with this it still sits there. God forbid I have anything you have anything in the background open it crashes my computer due to CPU utilization spikes, even if those programs have low priority in Task Manager. I have not played any other game that has caused this issue. NOT EVEN STALKER 2! I genuinely don't understand how the minimum specs are what they are because if my system is struggling I don't even want to imagine how this game runs on hardware like that. 

TL:DR This game, regardless how you feel it does Battlefield fails to even run well on a system over the 'Recommened Specs', I could never in my heart recommend something like this to anyone just on performance alone.

I've played this game for a decent amount of time, and I can say one thing, is that I do actually have fun with this game. However, I still have a lot of problems with it despite that. Like, I can list things that I specifically do and don't like;

Negatives:
- Most of the maps range from decent to horrible, and I can only think of two maps that are decent. Pretty much all of the maps just have really questionable or terrible design in general. I mainly play Breakthrough, and I can say that just about all of them are pretty bad. The Oil Rig one is the absolute worst, it is the most awful design period. Also, almost every map is just big open spaces, very little areas for meaningful close combat. And the one map that IS more close quarters is just a grenade fest that would make Halo weep, so...
- Gunplay is really questionable. Compared to previous BF games that I've played, this one's gunplay is just plain weird. Also insane recoil on a lot of guns, and you're gonna have to get a LOT of kills to actually get good attachments to make it less painful.
- Weird Class System, where there are "Operators", and it has that weird same vibe as like a Hero Shooter or something because instead of being a nameless Soldier, you're playing an actual specific character with a certain Gear and Ability tied to them. So you're running around with 64 people, clones killing each other basically, and it just is weird for a Battlefield game in my opinion. And some of these characters have better stuff than others, but it's not really that bad to me, it just is a bizarre direction that didn't really need to happen, in my opinion. Oh yeah, and these characters have English and Russian voicelines, which is just so odd, it just only makes me question this design choice even more!
- Driving in this game is terrible if you aren't driving a Tank or Heavy land vehicle. The Camera sways like crazy while turning and controlling vehicles just feels so awful, particularly the faster ones. But like I said, Tanks don't have this issue very much.
- UI And Menu reeks of CoD Ick. When I first booted up this game, I almost felt like I bought the wrong game, because the Main Menu feels like Call of Duty in how it looks and feels. Basically, I'm not a fan. It's completely different from any other BF game I've played. But it could be worse, I guess, so not my biggest gripe.
- It has Microtransaction. Yeah, full priced game with microtransaction. Not my biggest complaint, but this is also a deviation from the norm of BF. It's pretty ignorable though, since its purely cosmetics.
- The Gimmick of being able to switch the attachments on your gun while on-field is nice, but is a rather forgettable feature. I can guarantee you most people probably don't even know it's a feature or actively use it, especially since most people probably just do that after they die.
- There's a weather system... I... guess? There's tornadoes, but they're more of a major inconvenience that doesn't add anything good to the gameplay other than being slightly intimidating the first few times. I thought the marketing for this game before it came out focused a lot on the unique weather system or something, but there's literally just tornadoes... that rarely even happen on maybe two maps. In fact... I haven't seen a tornado in a while now...
- There's Environmental Destruction, but it's not very impactful and doesn't offer that much strategic or tactical advantage, since most things aren't even destructible to begin with, or minimal at best.

Positives:
+ I like that Vehicles are ludicrously loaded out with 2 to 3 gunners on top of the drivers, so 4 people can just be sitting in a tank and just be a menace. I say that because that's me. I like being a menace. But it's pretty easy to die with a Tank/Heavy Land Vehicle if you're not careful so it's not overly oppressive, in my opinion. (As long as your teammates aren't brain damaged and actually contest the vehicles, that is)
+ I like that the support classes beyond Assault kinda have their own niche and you can get high on the scoreboard without getting that many kills as long as you're being useful. This is more of a personal thing for me.
+ There's a lot of guns. But you do have to unlock most of them.
+ There's plenty of progression, such as with the (Current) Battle Pass, Player Levels, and more so, with unlocking attachments and new weapons, so there's at least stuff to work towards while playing.
+ It's decently optimized, had very little technical issues with the game. With that being said though, this "positive" only comes from the fact that the game is about 4 years old at the time of this review, so I'd be shocked if they failed to optimize the game at all in that entire timeline. But my experience may not be the same for others. This is PC, after all.

Most people will probably NOT be coming back to BF 2042 once BF 6 comes out, because 2042 doesn't really offer a good enough or unique enough experience to warrant having it's own dedicated fans, compared to previous installments in the franchise. And also, at least from the Beta, BF 6 plays significantly better, and has significantly better maps, fixing two of my biggest issues with this game. So I really hope they don't somehow fuck up that release, because they have a good thing going with it currently.

Overall though, even if I have fun with the game, I can't exactly give this a thumbs up. My biggest gripes, being the Maps and the Gunplay do affect the core of the gameplay, and they are not great. And having played the Battlefield 6 Beta before picking up this game (It was on a $3 sale), yeah, that just made it harder to give this game a "good" review. If I could just give a "Mixed" rating, I would. But I don't particularly feel bad for giving this game a thumbs down either. The game was worth it for $3 though, it's good enough until the next game comes out. Definitely would not have shelled out $60 for this though.

No, very big No. I played for the Battlefield 6 skins, didn't realized how miserable of an experience it would be after playing the battlefield 6 demo. 

The audio/Sound design throws me off, sound is muffled and can't accurately tell where the people are coming from. 

Trying to get into actual servers is a horrible experience, good luck trying to get into the servers you want, you're better off creating ai servers to play, that's assuming you can, there is the possibility that the servers are capped with xp grind servers and you may not even be able to create a server to begin with. 

The battle pass itself was ridiculous and excessive, the amount of xp needed to complete the battle pass is too much, best method is to do missions, which I understand if you want to prolong the pass, and you're probably thinking you can take advantage of the 2x-3x XP weekends, fantastic idea, right? BUT you are capped on experience... the game will outright cap you if you're doing well even in double xp, why?!

Guns didn't feel responsive at times, not sure if due to server issues or if the game is just clunky. Same with bullet registration, there are times where the bullet registration isn't working right and either you can't hit anything or you're hitting when you really shouldn't be, once again can't tell if it's game clunk or server issues. 

Either way I would not recommend, I got it for the battle pass for the skins and in the end just spend extra money to get out of that pass. Thank god they're not using this formula again.

I will say I did have [b]SOME[/b] fun playing this with friends, but the overall experience is [b]STILL[/b] garbage and this is with Years of updates trying to patch the game to be playable which is at most mildly enjoyable to insufferable between the grind and horrid 
I decided to challenge myself a little bit by getting all the achievements (Which is a grind that you can cheese about 70% of them for), before this game goes completely dead when BF6 comes out 

But to give a brief overview of my 138.7 Hours playing this mess I have
1. Unlocked all Weapons (Including getting the [spoiler]2142 Prototype[/spoiler] Easter egg weapon they just added)
2. Got all achievements (Which includes getting Tier 1 Mastery with a Vehicle, Weapon, Specialist, and Gadget, and playing Hazard zone) This was the worst of the grind.
3. Completed a progressively more grindy 60 Tier Battlepass that I only chose to Grind for The battlefield 6 cosmetics, which the only saving grace was the fact they are doing 2XP on every weekend until 6 comes out. 

And I should note that with 4 weeks of the freebie weekly challenges that give you about 5.5 tiers a week. Each 1/10th of a tier was taking 40k, or 400k xp for an entire tier towards the end of the pass if you were actually grinding the pass like I was. Mind you I am doing this in my free time when I get off of work from my ACTUAL Full time job, to come home and do this as a full time job in itself.
I can say I had fun with the Iwo Jima 24/7 playlist, but that went away pretty quick once they realized people were having fun.
I do not care if it often goes on sale often for like 3 dollars you will be wasting your money and time if your actually trying to play the game, plus its almost guaranteed this game will be dead as hell after 10/10/2025.

TLDR its bad, don't waste your time, for anything other than the BF6 cosmetics if you really want them that bad.

Battlefield 2042 ‚Äî Nearly 4 Years Later

Nearly 4 years of ‚Äúlive service‚Äù and this thing still can‚Äôt even manage basic matchmaking. Want to squad up with friends? Good luck, maybe half of you will get in, maybe none, maybe you‚Äôll just stare at the menu while the EA overlay kills the launch entirely.

Performance? Graphics still glitch like it‚Äôs a beta, FPS drops for no reason, and the game feels like it‚Äôs being rendered on a toaster.

EA‚Äôs effort here is so bare-minimum it‚Äôs almost art. They‚Äôve had years and still delivered‚Ä¶ this. And now they‚Äôre pushing people back into it just to make BF6 look like the second coming. Spoiler: it does ‚Äî only because 2042 is that bad.

Pros:

Makes Battlefield 6 look incredible.

Cons:

Everything else.

Final Verdict: 2042 isn‚Äôt a game. It‚Äôs a warning label.
Possibly the worst game ever made.

The last time I played Battlefield was Battlefield 3.  Battlefield 2042 doesn't have the extra special sauce that Battlefield 3 once had, but it is still fun and chaotic.  There are still moments that: make me chuckle, hold my breath, grip my controller tighter than I should.  In short it is still Battlefield.  Not being able to search for servers is a bummer but I still play it.  I started playing because of the Battlefield 6 demo, and still having a good time.
It's EA.

I've been afking 100 hrs for battle pass xp while playing other games. Great value. 

Battle passes are so great addition for gaming in general. Adds a lot to gameplay.

I'll start with the good:

The gunplay is great, movement is fluid, graphics are nice. It really plays well, the positives are just heavily outweighed by the cons, even to this day.

The very, very, bad (the absolutely AWFUL):

The maps in this game are, without exaggeration, the WORST maps ever made for an FPS game. Playing on any of the BF2042 original maps is so bad that it isn't even fun. All of them have no thought put into them at all and encourage the most shameless camping and one-sided games, to the point where the outcome of the games depend on which team camps a central high position the most, even in TDM. If you play TDM and get placed into the team that has the worse spawns, the other team absolutely will camp the best positions the entire game and win, every single time, and there is absolutely nothing at all you can do about it. You will see that on certain maps, the winning team will always be the same because of this. The only fun to be had in this game is playing on the maps that were originals in other games, like the BF3 maps and others.

There is no teamwork, nor is there any incentive to play this game as a team. Nobody revives, and there is no incentive to revive. You will get ran past by 10 medics and not one of them will stop to revive you. Nobody that plays this game can hold a position, so even if you have 10 teammates around you, there will be an enemy that runs in and kills everyone because your teammates weren't paying any attention. Every game mode is just TDM/FFA, and the vehicles just have free reign to go anywhere in the map with impunity. You will have people spawn basically on top of you and kill you instantly, meaning, there is no protection at all once you've taken a command post. You could be 2 objectives back from the "frontlines" and still get lasered 5-10 seconds after spawning. There is no safety anywhere. In TDM it doesn't matter where you spawn. There's a 70% chance you die within 5 seconds of spawning just because there was already someone there.

Time to kill is absolutely insane for vehicles. It takes upwards of 5 AT shots to kill a tank, or any armored vehicle. The helicopters are broken since TTK is so high. They simply fly away, repair, and come right back. You will get run over by armored vehicles and there's nothing you can do about it since it takes 5+ AT shots to kill them. You will die before you can reload enough times to kill literally any vehicle in this game.

The server lag on any game mode outside of TDM makes the game completely unplayable. In TDM, the framerate is fine, no rubber banding, game runs smooth. Play 64v64 conquest games, however, and you start getting a consistent server side lag. You can mostly ignore it in 64v64, but it's still super annoying. The worst is 128v128 conquest... It is unplayable. The server lag is so bad that people pop in and out of existence all of the time, the rubber banding makes movement annoying, and you will consistently die long after you've gone into cover and healed. This is consistent for every 128v128 match.

Everyone was right... this is definitely the worst BF game ever made, and it's not even close. 

For the $2.49 I bought this game at, I had some fun playing TDM. This game isn't worth a penny more than that, so don't buy it unless it's on sale for that amount or less.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2023 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

[b]This game is leaps and bounds better than it was at launch. It still doesn't feel like a real Battlefield game. [/b] 

[b]Things I dislike;[/b]
[list]
[*]Specialists suck. Their commentary is obnoxious, and unable to be muted. Not much more to say about that.
[*]Open classes encourage play that is not aligned with cohesive team play, nor the true Battlefield experience.
[*]Battlepasses blow. It is needlessly difficult to unlock the things obtainable via the BP.  Of course, my complaint is moot. BP's won't go away because corporations are growing increasingly greedy, particularly in this era of the current administration and his fellow politicians bending over backwards to appease the companies who bribe them above and below the table.
[*]The meat grinder maps, Stadium and Redacted, kinda suck compared to Locker and Metro.
[*]Calling in equipment is cool, but being able to call in game changing equipment like tanks is over-powered and potentially gamebreaking. This should only be possible at controlled, uncontested points and main spawns (at least in regards to conquest).
[*]Time between vehicle spawns is way too long. I've always been a tanker main, so I'm not really a fan of waiting 2 or more minutes to get back into a tank!
[*]There should be vehicles on the map and in the spawn. Not a fan of the lack of vehicles that spawn in as a reward for objective control.
[/list]

[b]Things I like;[/b]
[list]
[*]The maps are otherwise pretty good. Not many that I believe will be iconic and remembered highly as the franchise moves forward like you might with maps from BF2-BF1, but overall an enjoyable assortment. I really enjoy the size of some of the maps.
[*]Being able to play against bots is awesome. I don't like that it counts towards you KD and other stats, but being able to run your own server to run bots is a great way to get back into shooters after a long gap (my last multiplayer FPS was BF4, and the few dozen hours of BF1 it took me to realize that WW1 is not the setting for me). I also really enjoyed that I was able to practice helo's and such without ruining other peoples days! I played quite a few hours in my private servers with my friend, and we had an absolute blast with that.
[*]There is a huge collection of guns. I really like the amount of attachments, as well, though I do feel that the unlock order is a little silly. IMO, bipods should be one of the first unlocks, particularly on LMGs.
[/list]

[i]Overall, I am not impressed, but also not disappointed. This is easily my least favorite Battlefield out of BF2, BF2142, BC2, BF3, BF4, and BF1.[/i] 
I must admit, I honestly never would have played this game had it not been for BF Studios putting the free cosmetic items for BF6 in the battlepass. The launch was very off putting after initially being very excited that BF was returning to a modern/nearly modern setting. Finding out the game was a crappy hero shooter missing fundamental features of not only a Battlefield game, but a FPS game in general, was very disappointing. It is evident that it was built as a battle royale first, rather than adding a battle royale mode to a game built for Battlefield fans. All of that effort and they never even put a BR mode into the game! Not that I want it, nor the extraction shooter mode, anyways. [u][I commend Dice/BF Studios/EA for sticking with this game, and evolving it into something relatively enjoyable towards the end of its life. It is obvious that they really put in a lot of work to get this game to the point is at today. It is also obvious that they tried to replicate the Battlefield feel, though IMO the core elements of this game prevent that from being completely possible.[/u]

To be fair to 2042, if this game had a different name, it would have had different expectations so I and many others would likely view it as a good start to a franchise.

üåü Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ

I really wanted to like this. EA had years to iron things out, but somehow Battlefield 2042 still manages to fall flat‚Äîhard.

üëç Pros:

The wingsuit is a fun new addition and brings some fresh tactical options to gameplay.

Portal could have been the standout feature. I managed to create a few cool modes like Fast Rockets Only, Snipers, and Knives.

üëé Cons:

The core Battlefield gameplay feels stripped down‚Äîbasic at best, and missing the things we loved from past titles. Destruction is limited, and team play is almost nonexistent.

Portal mode editing is frustrating. The tool is overly complex, with vague labels and hard-locked variables that limit creativity. I couldn‚Äôt even boost run speed or spawn quads in a version of Quad-Rockets game I thought would be fantastic.

Server hosting is buggy and unreliable. I often couldn‚Äôt shut down my own server to make changes, leading to unnecessary downtime for me and my friends.

To top it off, EA locked Battlefield 6 cosmetics behind this game. Who wants to grind cosmetics in a release that so many already walked away from?

üéÆ Final Thoughts:
There are glimpses of good ideas here, but they‚Äôre buried under poor design choices and technical problems. This should‚Äôve been a course correction for the franchise, not a step backward.

Wow...

Worst matchmaking system in video games' history.
At totally new player (level 22) I have to compete against S472 (whatever that means), with max badges, fully upgraded weapons and extrem movement a mapcontrol... Loosing in 90% of the matches and beeing spawncamped is everything, but not fun.

Slowest "Battle Pass" grindig in video games' history.
I played several shooter games before (CS, R6:S, COD, etc.), but this is crazy.
I barely can get 1 (one) level in a 60-level "Free Pass" in an afternoon.
The sublevel system (that 10 dots / level) is totally inconsistent. Sometimes I get 1 'dot', sometimes I get 3.
Sometimes I got more 'dots' when I play bad (critically bad stats) and my team is loosing, than after a game where I play (relatively) good, with more kills, assists, objective scores, etc... Why?

Worst damage pattern I ever experienced.
For sure, the 80% of the enemies simply 1shot me, but I can kill them for example with RPG by only direct hit. If the RPG exploding next to them in a corridor, or in front of their feet (I mean 20 pixels, not meters), they just run toward and 1shot me with almost any weapon. What the hell is going on? I hit them with a f***ing anti-tank rocket, LOL!

I played BF Vietnam, BF 3, BF 4, but the series lost me between 1 and V (because of bugs and mediocre gameplay). I want to come back to play BF 6, that's why I bought 2042, to tease myself a bit. And, in addition, my friend said "the game is OK now, the devs repaired the game in the last 2 years".
So, this game was WORSE than it's actual state?
Jesus Christ... I cannot, or simply don't dare to imagine that.

I bought the game at a promo for 3‚Ç¨.
Worst spent money in 2025. I know, it is impossible to refund a game after 13 hours of playtime, but I would refund this.

I CAN NOT recommend this game even for 3‚Ç¨ or $3!
Being a newcomer is a real pain in the a**, I never experienced as unbalanced and unfair matchmaking as this game have.
I just want my BF6 rewards ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

I want to give it a just miss score of like 49/100. It feels okay in its current state, but still a slog. There are some nice ideas, but it's not really quite Battlefield. It feels too floaty and loose in many ways. Its progression systems are too arcade like and lightly implemented. 

I really hate most of the skins and the fact that i'm seeing the same skins on both sides of the conflict - it absolutely misses the mark in placing you inside the conflict, but it actually had some solid ideas for trying to give you a "why" for each battle. 

I also cannot stand how they fill up servers with AI that gradually get replaced with players, and the fact that match-made servers do not persist match to match.

I suppose the most damning thing i can say about it is this; I played 60 hours of BF6 in the beta weekend and that went by in a flash. Yet, the 40 hours of BF2042 in the last few weeks felt like hundreds of hours of tiresome grinding.

Anyway, it was only 3 bucks. So based on that perspective, there's sufficient value to be gained here.

I bought this game for $4. I thought there was no way I could regret spending $4, even after reading all the reviews. Within 5 minutes I was coping, within 30 minutes I realized it wasn't going to get better, and within 90 minutes I returned the product. It was not worth $4. 

Later I went to the grocery store and purchased some smoked turkey for $4. I enjoyed one immaculate sandwich, then forgot about the rest, and it went bad. And it still wasn't NEARLY as much of a waste of $4 as Battlefield 2042. I got at least one moment of enjoyment from that sandwich, which is infinitely more moments of enjoyment I got from this game.

If this game goes on sale for even $1 and you are considering it, do yourself a favour: throw your $1 away into a wishing well, and wish for BF6 to be good.

* It has very nice graphics and sound and gameplay, pretty amazing and somewhat realistic and incredible and fun to play.

* You can play against AI bots and it even has unlocks progression and achievements and all which is a big plus that's real fun for hours (at least for me).
_________________________________________

* I did not encounter yet any bugs or major performance issues etc, so far so good, I'm only enjoying it.
_________________________________________

* You cannot go wrong if you buy it when it's sold with discount of 90-95% like I did, for what I paid I am more than happy with my purchase.
_________________________________________

* The sounds and visuals they did in this game with guns and all is capturing the gritty authentic feeling of power of a real gun and the explosion effects are huge and incredibly amazing and detailed.
_________________________________________

I bought this game to play in coop mode with my son.  We did enjoy the game and have played it for a fair bit of time.  That came to an end a few months ago when there was an update to the anti-cheat software.  It now kicks my son out of the game because of several drivers that it has identified as not being the latest version. Among these are drivers for the fan and optical drive which he is not going to uninstall in order to play a game.  These are false positives because the vendor has not provided any updates to these drivers for his computer model.  As well, we only played in PvE coop mode so there was no need for the anti-cheat check anyways.  We waited a while to see if this would be corrected but have now given up hope of that happening and will uninstall the game.  If this is the way EA is going to treat their customers, then we will not be purchasing any games from this publisher in the future.

The game actually isn't terrible, it's passable and enjoyable to an extent, it just feels like more battlefield with some extra stuff here and there, that's not why I'm saying not recommended though.

The performance is the big issue, moreso how intensive it is. I have an older rig, 2080, i7-9700k. 

FOR COMPARISON, I played the BF6 beta perfectly fine, not an issue at all, sure I had to play at low-medium settings but was consistently above 60fps and could use any background app without issue.

2042 However, takes my entire computer hostage. If I have more than 1 background app open? Lag. If I have 2 firefox tabs open? Oh you better believe those are literally impossible to click on or use in any meaningful way.

Hell even if I close everything but Spotify and Discord BF2042 takes up so much of my computer the music in spotify lags and stutters.

I like being able to tab out of games and look at other things in between deaths/loading screens, the fact I can't do ANYTHING on BF2042 makes it an event just to load up the game and nothing else can happen. Lets pray that BF6 being optimized for PC actually means something.

    Apple slices arranged on cake batter in a baking dish.

    Allrecipes / Preethi Venkatram

    Mix 1 cup sugar, 3/4 cup flour, candied lemon peel, cinnamon, nutmeg, and 1 pinch salt in a bowl. Cut in 1/2 cup butter with a knife or pastry blender until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
    Bowl of crumb topping mixture ready for baking.

    Allrecipes / Preethi Venkatram

    Sprinkle over apples. Allow dough to rise for 30 minutes. Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
    Unbaked apple cake with crumb topping in a white dish.

    Allrecipes / Preethi Venkatram

    Bake in preheated oven until cake is golden brown and apples are tender, about 35 minutes.

A Battlefield game, but honestly pretty terrible in so far as Battlefield games go.

All Weapons being available to everyone means 90%+ of your deaths will be to Assault Rifles and Sniper Rifles, some maps are beyond ridiculous in size in that they are mostly empty space (though there are better ones for sure), and the panicked attempt at squeezing the "Specialists" into the old Battlefield mold of a class system (after EA realized they fit the overall formula horribly), coupled with a significant downplay in their "attitude" and characterization, has instead left them as utterly soulless, strange wax figures that will grunt out a comment before a game and then mostly try to stay in the "random soldier" lane.

Who are you Boris, why are you telling others to shut up and pay attention? I really don't care.

Annoyances like being booted back to the main screen for matchmaking after every game and the likes continuously takes you out of the action and robs you of the chance to form relations to your fellow players. People obsessed with K/D ratios will stand on your body and absolutely fu-hucking not revive you, resupply you, heal you, or otherwise engage in team or even squad oriented play - I recognize that medics refusing to revive (and tanks driving away when you try to repair them) is something of a "classic" in BF, but I want to emphasize that I have never before played a Battlefield game so utterly atomized in terms of its team play components being spread thin in favor of individual expression.

Turns out this amount of "player choice" makes for a bunch of headless chickens running in circles even if you try to make 128 of them butt heads.

2042 cost me 3 euros with the massive discount that was. Would I have bought this without the Battlefield 6 unlocks in its free battle pass? Absolutely not, nor could I stomach going further than level 30, which given my hours I guess is me technically "getting my money's worth".

Not the Battlefield We Remember

What we're experiencing here is not Battlefield‚Äînot in any meaningful sense. While it wears the name and leans heavily on the franchise‚Äôs legacy, this title feels less like a continuation of what came before and more like a vehicle designed to serve a very different purpose: monetization.

From the very beginning, this project seemed less focused on delivering a cohesive, immersive FPS experience and more concerned with becoming a platform for live-service content. Battle passes, weapon charms, cosmetics, and character skins dominate the experience, often feeling like the game‚Äôs true focus. It's hard to shake the sense that gameplay and identity were sacrificed to make room for recurring revenue streams.

The shift from a class-based system to one centered around marketable characters exemplifies this. Where Battlefield once prided itself on clarity and team role distinction, we now have a cast of interchangeable operators‚Äîdifficult to read, visually noisy, and clearly built with skin sales in mind. The result is a game where readability and tactical depth have taken a backseat to cosmetic flair.

Map design, too, has suffered. Many of the environments feel large for the sake of scale, but ultimately empty‚Äîbereft of the purposeful design and flow that defined previous titles. Objectives are often bottlenecked through narrow chokepoints, leading to chaotic grenade spam and little strategic depth. There's no real sense of front-line progression or evolving engagements‚Äîjust static, disconnected skirmishes in uninspired spaces. Worse yet, these maps are visually cluttered, with excessive decoration that often hinders clarity rather than enhancing immersion.

What‚Äôs perhaps most disheartening is how little of the original Battlefield DNA remains. The atmosphere, the identity, the focus on large-scale, class-based warfare‚Äîthese elements have been diluted or removed entirely in favor of something more generic, more marketable, and ultimately, less memorable.

It's not just that the game is different‚Äîgames evolve. But this isn‚Äôt evolution; it‚Äôs replacement. What made Battlefield unique has been stripped away and replaced with systems and designs better suited for a live-service mobile game than a flagship multiplayer shooter.

There was a time when Battlefield stood apart‚Äîwhen it offered something distinctive, something with weight and identity. This direction feels like it‚Äôs forgotten that entirely.
