Battlefield 2042 tried to be the next best Battlefield since BF4. But it failed!

I've been playing it a lot lately to get the BF6 pass items, and it's given me a lot of hands-on time now that the dust has settled and the game is in its final state. They improved a lot of the issues with the original release, but those should never have been issues to begin with and were the result of poor developmental choices and poor corporate direction. Put simply, they lost the plot and released a half-baked sourdough that nobody liked.
   What we have now is a shell of Battlefield. The operators bring some interesting nuance to the table, but that interest is unnecessary. Battlefield was never a Hero Shooter, and trying to make it into one was a mistake that symbolizes EA's biggest departure from the classic formula in this title. We didn't want or need a 64v64 Overvalorsmite, we just wanted a badass Battlefield as advertised in the teaser trailer (it's still a badass teaser trailer).
   To add insult to injury, we have mini-narratives when loading into matches and I think Hazard Zone (that I never played) was supposed to add some tension to the setting, fighting on behalf of nations for advantages in the global theater. This, too, was half-baked. The dossier trailers, the visual storytelling in some levels, and some of the art that was released all push toward what could have been a compelling campaign to tell the story of this post-apocalyptic near-future that rocked the world so hard that it shattered countries apart and created "No-Pats." They let this slip through their fingers, and they gave us a generic multiplayer hero-shooter.
   ANOTHER SIN is that they added CoD movement. I play Battlefield for the slower pace, deliberate movement, and loose tactical thought. I don't play Squad or Arma because I don't want a milsim, but I don't play CoD either because I don't want to "git gud" against movement tech kids who will 360 bunny hop combat slide Emperor Palpatine lightsaber spin their way into a headshot against me. I shouldn't ever get slide-tackled to insta-death in a Battlefield game or be trying to track the easter bunny as it pelts me with crossbow bolts, but that is exactly what happens in 2042. Another tonedeaf departure from BFDNA by corporate overlords who just wanted to make something that checks vague "what makes games popular?" boxes.
   The maps are big and empty except for little skirmish zones that have well-constructed set pieces. The issue is when you don't have a vehicle to traverse the meadows between POIs and spend so much time running that your character should probably need to chug an entire gallon of water. The maps would either need more interesting points between these combat arenas or a pare-down of dead space. It's poor level design, except where it isn't and it's frustrating to try and describe.
   The vehicles are either under- or overpowered with no in-between. If you can stay away from Stingers and other munitions, then you can absolutely rock the world of the enemy team with impunity. On the same note, if you try to take down a vehicle by yourself then even a full load of C5 won't kill anything bigger than a jeep on the ground. There's no room for sneaky "take down the tank that's abusing everyone" gameplay. On the flip side, if you and your team and everyone all dogpile one tank, it's dead in seconds. You would think that this encourages teamplay, but most of the time it just encourages people to abandon the objective because their grappling hook can't hurt a tank.

This game isn't worth the price I paid for it back when it launched. If you catch it on sale for like $5 then sure, because it does play decently as a shooter and it might scratch the itch for something with vehicle warfare between now and BF6. I would rather play BFV or even BF4, old as it is, but they suckered me in with the Farewell Pass.
   I played the BF6 beta. It's everything that BF2042 should have been. It does everything right that 2042 did wrong. It has its own flaws, like vehicle routes in maps feeling very on-rails, but it feels like a modernized BF3 and I'm here for it. That's the only reason I'm giving 2042 my time: for the sake of the better game.

   If you decide to play it at all, get it on sale for dirt cheap because it's not worth more than that. It's unbalanced, the maps feel empty, and Hazard Zone isn't even worth talking about. BF 2042 has come a long way from its time it was Battlefield's fan punching bag. 

The Good:
-Portal mode. Gamemodes allowing customization and to implement weapons and rules from BF 1942, BFBC2 and BF3
-Ports of good maps from other games
-Weapon and Gadget variety 

The Bad:
-Horrible server experience. Can't host your own games without spamming Host button for 10+ minutes. Even EA created game modes have server side lag. The game can't handle 128 players without the server lag icon popping up every ten seconds. 
-Awful base-game Maps. Just bad map design. Lack of cover, sniper points everywhere and odd objective placement leading to matches being one sided. 
-Bugs. Falling through maps, inputs not being registered, getting kicked out of servers with no error message. 

Unless you want the BF6 skins, I'd avoid purchasing this. Especially since it most likely will be sunsetted once BF6 drops.

Horrible

- Maps are bad, often forcing you into a slogfest with grenade spam on first or final points. The trophy system cannot keep up with the amount of projectiles.
- Non-authentic skins are prolific and the store is shoved in your face every other time you launch the game.
- The stark lack of engaging and rewarding teamplay means that whatever your squad's contribution is in game is negligable.
- No team VOIP.
- Different vehicles are unlocked through levels in game instead of being able to use any vehicle on just a spawn system. Want to try to use a specific vehicle to level it up? Reach level 50 first. And that's IF you can get it before some 2000+ player hops in it the moment it spawns.
- Speaking of high level players - the amount of flak you will get for trying to fly a jet or helicopter can be overwhelming. A very unwelcoming experience.

I won't say anything that much more qualified people haven't already. I would recommend the game but the general criticism is valid. The maps are way too big even for 128 player lobbies. You can cap a point and if there is no vehicle, you'll be on foot for 90 seconds over largely open ground. Spawning on point you're defending has a tendency to put you well outside the point. Hit reg is still a problem from time to time. The thing I was really disappointed in as a new player to the franchise was the lack of cohesion. I had always heard about the team focused gameplay of battlefield and I agree with others assessment that I chose the wrong game to enter the franchise if I wanted the role based squad play of other entries like BF3. 

I must say, the close quarters conquest playlist is super fun. A limited map pool but just the right size for 64 players to maximize conflict. The maps are what call of duty wishes it was. I would not be surprised that if they keep that playlist moving into BF6, that's where the majority of CoD converts find themselves gravitating to.

Would I have felt the same if I'd payed full price at release? I can't say. For the sale price though, it was a hell of a deal.

Even after a full lifespan of the game it still has bugs, is poorly optimized and has flawed map design even after reworks of the launch maps. Mouse input has and still is bugged at a engine level in this game, portal is all but useless for anything useful. lack of a server browser means you can play the same maps modes ect over and over even if you want variety... forcing you to leave games you don't want to partake in because you've played it 4 or 5 times in a row. This causes lobbies with a large amount of players leaving and then if enough do they are replaced with AI. this also happens on uneven teams causing the losing team to be even more disadvantaged with AI after half their team leaves. Maps and objects in the maps often have glitched hitboxes so when you jiggle peak cover or an enemy is lying behind a rock that doesn't cover his whole body the map will eat the bullets. This game was flawed from its inception and rushed out unfinished years ago yet still today 1 month from bf6 coming out those flaws will shine through and create a bad player experience.

Despite an extremely difficult release, Battlefield 2042 has iterated upon itself continuously over the course of its 4-year lifespan; and today lives as one of the easiest-to-pick-up, easy-to-put-down first person shooters in the scene. 
Massive maps with 64 vs 64 gameplay leads to exciting and engaging combat at (almost) every turn.
Rewarding mechanics and "mostly" balanced gunplay provides a sense of progression without feeling like you are consistently getting destroyed by the same player over-and-over.
A few maps are relatively underwhelming or poorly balanced, but all-in-all this is a great game--especially if you get it on a Steam sale below MSRP!

It‚Äôs almost unbelievable that the studio that once pioneered the epic Battlefield experience could release something this poorly executed. Battlefield 2042 is a masterclass in how not to make a Battlefield game ‚Äî clunky mechanics, frustrating design choices, and a heavy reliance on microtransactions that gut the core experience. The inclusion of gimmicky COD-style sliding and chaotic mechanics feels like a betrayal of what made the franchise unique.

Even at $4, this feels like money wasted. I honestly wish I had just bought another beer instead ‚Äî at least that would‚Äôve been enjoyable. This is easily one of the most disappointing entries in the series.

I‚Äôve been playing Battlefield since BF1942, but I skipped BF2042 at launch and only picked it up recently during a sale. With the ‚ÄúRoad to BF6‚Äù event, I decided it was finally time to give it a shot.

At first, it was frustrating: low-res text in the menus, clunky performance, long loading times both into the game and into matches, plus the awkward character voice lines in the menus. My first games felt overwhelming, and I quit quickly, I just wasn‚Äôt enjoying it.

A week later, still curious, I gave it another chance and that‚Äôs when I discovered Portal. That‚Äôs where the game finally clicked. Jumping into El Alamein, hardcore vanilla servers, or crazy custom modes with wild modifiers reminded me why I fell in love with Battlefield in the first place.

Visually, the game looks fantastic in 4K with Ray Tracing, the gunplay feels satisfying, and the massive maps offer freedom to flank, explore, or just enjoy the chaos. It‚Äôs not perfect, but with new map Iwo Jima the game finally feels alive again.

If you struggled like I did at first, try Portal, it turned BF2042 from a disappointment into something I actually enjoy while waiting for Battlefield 6.

I will be basing it on 3 factors, the worth of it by price (i got it for 90% off or about 3 dollars) compared to other battlefields, 1,5 and 6 and as a game itself

1, for the price, its pretty great! id personally spend at max 15-20 pounds PROVIDED the main servers are still lively, portal thrown in is a fun bonus.

2, Its in my eyes for what it is and the standards you would expect after 1 and 5 its very lackluster vs other battlefields, i haven't PLAYED 4 much, but in terms of the feel of battlefield, it doesn't hit home, and despite portal being more akin they too feel limited and somewhat of a downgrade? in bf1 and bf5 for example, there atmosphere, graphic design and animations of how players move, combined with the vfx feels alot better then this by alot, it does have some upsides, the graphics ISN'T bad persay, but doesn't feel as good as the older games, it feels like in terms of "quality" it rivals 3, but art direction, its the worst in my eyes.

3, as a GAME, now after playing it for a while, including a fair amount of portal, in comparison to what i seen and played a small bit at launch on xbox, its feels like a solid game, it still plays like battlefield and has its own uniqueness (reffering back to point 2 again), the addition of portal allows it to be alot more enjoyable especially being able to play those older maps, and i sometimes enjoy the 128 player mode it offered, however map sizes can be slightly jarring especially if u get left stranded with no car but it has a fair amount of 2042 maps that are enjoyable despite that.

all in all its a 6/10, 7.3/10 if high.

This game doesn't deserve the hate it still gets after 3 years. Sure, it was HORRENDOUS at launch and it's still not perfect. The UI is not very clear especially for vehicles, lacks map variety and its fast-paced combat feels like a COD game. 
But it still feels like a Battlefield game. there's still a lot of fun to be had here. I actually like the different characters with their own unique ability. I like the wingsuit and how fun it is to fly with it across the battlefield. I feel like if they hadn't implemented these things in the game, people would still hate on it by saying "same shit, different maps" or something.

I've always preferred Battlefield to Call of Duty; I don't know why,  as I also loved the early Call of Duty games; however, the first three Battlefield games were for me amazing and far  less scripted than the early Call of Duty games. Don't get me wrong, I loved the early C.O.D. games as well, but  early Battlefield  were  for me the better games.   

Apart from playing a few hours  of BF 2042 shortly after the game was released, I  have only recently really got into the game; partly due to the  upcoming Battlefield 6 being released early October. My reasoning for playing now,  was that the servers will  probably not be  as popular once  number 6 takes off, so it won't be as enjoyable, unless you prefer the two Bot infested Coop modes.  

Anyway, after playing for several hours  a few weeks ago, then over the past two weeks playing over a hundred, I've  found the game  had 'partially' returned to it's roots and I'm absolutely loving it.    I still wish there was a commanders position as that would be the icing on the cake for this game; however, I'm still well satisfied with what we've got.  

Every  session unlocks  additional attachments and  promotions are  given as you gain more experience.  Since six was  promoted, seasons are no longer available, but the team that still supports the game do  give additional  stuff   fairly regularly.

I've still only played  just over 120 hours, so will add more to this short review once I've  become more familiar with the ins and outs of   the game, assuming Battlefield 6, when released doen't take me away from this game permanently. ;)

Got it for $2 so i could get the BF6 skins and still feel like i've been scammed, 
It takes more than 30 hours of grinding to unlock them and you will have to put up with what is essentially the single worst FPS game to have come out in the last 2 decades. BF2042 is not only an insult to the franchise but to the FPS genre in it's entirety. It's vibe coded by DEI hires and there isn't a single thing that works properly even after 4 years of active development.
The netcode is shit, the weapons are completely unbalanced and all have little to no recoil but at the same time you're required to use the current meta ones if you want to perform well consistently as there are some that are literally laser beams and can 2-3 tap at 100m or more. Vehicles do not feel good to use compared to older BF games, maps are ATROCIOUS, 128 player mode is unplayable for both balance and server stability reasons, the weapon selection is decent (after 4 years) but 99% of people just play with real grounded weapons that have been added in the updates and not the futuristic slop. Characters look and sound awful, classes force you to use specific "operators" such as female ones that don't fit the Battlefield universe at all and also reduce your gadget choices because they have hero shooter abilities. Performance wise it manages to rarely stutter even on a 5080 and 9800X3D while running off a 980 Pro and the game likes to just randomly crash.

This game is a grim reminder of what greed does to incredible franchises, and BF6 too isn't safe, it's much better but it's still not the Battlefield that everyone wants.

[h2] Truly, one of the videogames of all time [/h2]
Out of morbid curiosity, I finally took a peek behind the curtains of a game that has fascinated me since before it's release. The story of 2042's production reeks of desperation from publisher EA. After many DICE veterans left for greater pastures, a team of rookies was told to basically "copy Call of Duty Warzone". Even worse, my dearly beloved Criterion Games ‚Äî also a shadow of it's former self ‚Äî would spent the rest of eternity in the Battlefield-mines. From this purgatory, they worked around the clock to minimize the impact of bad choices made years ago, while investors were told the game was "way beyond schedule". In these wretched lands, a big budget will only get you so far.

On many levels, it's an annoying game, yet interesting in how little of the original design survived. At least the setting is engaging enough: a world ravaged by climate change, but still a theatre of war. Amidst the hopelessness and dread, even with our homes destroyed, people's thirst for blood proves the stronger force. It doesn't help that the main characters act goofy and spout quirky one-liners, feeling completely out of place in all the madness. Ultimately, the operator/hero-roles they fulfill are largely pointless, relegated to one of four staple Battlefield classes, with very few differences besides gadgets and awful voice lines. However, there are hundreds of cosmetics to unlock and/or buy, revealing the true inspiration behind their existence.

From a certain distance, the levels are visually appealing. Up close, players will spend time running through empty spaces with poor visibility, promoting the playstyle of not-moving. Destruction is noticeably absent, hurting the visual spectacle the series is known for. The only novelty is the scale of the levels, but this does not pair well with poor navigation and the chaos brought by 128 players.

Ironically, the Plus-system ‚Äî the game's stand-out feature ‚Äî is the least buggy in practice, even though the developers have disregarded it. At any moment, the player can change their weapon's accessoires to suit any situation, defeating the point of Battlefield. It comes across as on over-engineered system with a slick visual presentation, a stark contrast to the barebones and static feel to the rest of the UI. It‚Äôs as if the idea for this system came first, before the Battlefield-mines opened. Clearly, it was designed for the Warzone-esque experience that 2042 was initially meant to be.

Aside from the obvious mistakes, numerous small inconsistencies paint the picture of a game that should have never seen the light of day. In this sense, Battlefield 2042 resembles a genuine B-movie. Created against better judgement from people working in the mines, while leadership, blind to their own flaws, continually pushed forward. The result is a product that may be interesting to a select few, but a complete waste of time for many.

I have been playing COD for seven years and recently quit, given the terrible state of the game and the franchise. I developed an interest in playing Battlefield 6, so I‚Äôve been trying out Battlefield 2042, and for the first time in a while, I‚Äôm actually enjoying myself. I‚Äôve heard from the Battlefield community that this is one of the worst games, but if this is considered bad, then Battlefield 6 will be a blessing for this community. I love that there is no bunny hopping or ‚Äúmovement demons‚Äù in this game wearing clown skins. If you slide around or drop shot, it gives you a disadvantage, which I love. The game is simple and is more about having awareness, positioning, and actual gun skill rather than spamming the jump and slide buttons every match. The SBMM also feels significantly lower compared to COD. Every game feels a bit different, rather than having the same experience over and over again, which is excellent. If this is one of the worst games and I can still have fun, then I cannot wait until Battlefield 6 comes out. I hope EA does not snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.

The hit registration on top of the horrible netcode and 45hz servers make the experience unbearable and just plain frustrating. Save your money and get literally any other game instead. If you want to have more fun go play BF4. Somehow as time goes on the servers and hit registration on games just continue to get worse with these companies. Uninstalled today, will not be playing again, and after seeing the BF6 beta and knowing they haven't fixed this game I will not be purchasing that either. Find a different game you'll enjoy even if you only play through it a few times and spend your money better there.

On top of that if you don't have a specific newer motherboard with TPM 2.0 you just straight up can't play the game without running the risk of bricking your entire computer. Was not able to play with my friends because making people brick their PCs to maybe have the possiblity of playing is more important to EA than fixing anything about their game that has been out for 4 years.

Honestly, it's a really fun game; DICE managed to turn it around. It's among the better FPS games I've played in the past 9 years, and that says something, because I think most were terrible. FPS games have really been stagnating, and this one was a diamond in the rough. I have a few criticisms below, but please understand, I really like this game.

The gunplay feels great, so I wish there were modes with more infantry focus. Most of the maps are optimized for really large-scale 64x64 games; there are smaller-scale versions of these maps, and they're ok, but there's a distinctive lack of cover in some. I don't personally like the over-appeal to casuals and campers, and I love that you can counter-snipe as an aggressive player in this game, but we need more small and competitive game modes. I don't understand why there are so few persistent game modes: Conquest, Breakthrough, and TDM... What happened to all the other BF game modes? Why's Rush on a rotator? Why was the destruction toned down? Where's SQDM? Where's the campaign? Where are the ADS leaning mechanics? It seems like BF6's re-implemented these, but I wish they were in this game as well. Also, I really think that there should be some map voting system. Some of the maps are truly awful to me. I get that this game's player population was low, but these things do really help for longevity/replayability; portal should not be the only customization here.

It's not clear to me when the support for this game truly ends (SKG moment). It seems like despite the recent content drops, this game was slated to be on minor patches only. It'd be nice if some of these BF6 things were backported, but I highly doubt it'll happen. I think both this game and BF6 would benefit a lot from something like free weekends/demos; that way people that previously tried the game and refunded it could actually see the improvements (without having to repurchase; the post BF6 beta sale's a good example of this). The BF6 beta was far too short.

I'd guess that this game was created on the back of some incompatible engine version, and a lot of the BF-isms from the past took too long to be ported by the set release date. Some still haven't been, so there's a feeling of it being unfinished. Despite this, I do recommend this game. It has great-feeling gunplay, TTKs, movement, and balance, and it performs well too (hopefully BF6's minimum performance will match, as that's not how it was in the beta).

Bought this game on sale, and with all the hate this game been going through, I... understand (also might be justified)

Pathetically enough my first battlefield game was Battlefield 6 on Beta, I loved FPS games, and I watched people played Battlefield 3 and 4 on youtube when I was at school and it was amazing (never had the chance to play it because I don't have any PC back then). Then the beta ends, and I picked up Battlefield 1, and it was amazing! The only thing going through my head was "What have I been missing?"

So one of my friend loved this game (Battlefield 2042), but I had my doubts because of the reviews, in the end of the day it goes on for sale, then more and more of my friends started playing it, and invited me to play, so my thought was... "Why the hell not? BF6 and BF1 was that awesome, might as well give this one a try)

And I gotta say... It's bad, not necessarily awful, but bad as in (How did the same people that made the masterpiece (BF1 & 6), managed to fumble that hard to create this PoS? What happened at the time?)

The thing that bothered me so much isn't necessarily The COD Movements that people are talking abt, or the Cartoonish Specialist, or Brain Rot skins, etc. (I just took it as a different flavor, like pineapple on pizza thingy)

IT'S SIMPLY HOW INCOMPLETE THE GAME FELT WAS!

- The Net-code
It was awful, with how fast the character and stuff are able to move in this game were they not taking into account how much of a strain it would give to their server bandwidth? I'm not much of a tech guy.. but almost half the sources I read abt the problem I was having in this game always mentioned this. People are teleporting around in the 128 player mode (could be caused from client side CPU bottleneck, but still..), Gun suddenly stopped firing in the middle of a full-auto fights, and world assets be acting weird throughout the game (not in a funny way..)

- The map design
The size and design really does resembles the short, hectic, chaotic play that really is COD, or other fast shooter game type. I know I mentioned that those part are just different flavor but please, do they not take into account stuff that they implemented here? Like battlefield have tanks, airships and helicopters, not to mention this one also have quite the chaotically flaring specialist abilities. The big maps are way too open in a way, it's rather predictable the cover that everyone would take... It's battlefield, we got tanks, airplane bombers and stuff, maybe make more cover that are able to be flattened just like the special butter battlefield game always have, give us the false sense of security that could be taken away at anytime.

- World Physics
The fact that the world component/assets destruction were comical, houses, desks, doors, could still be standing firm after taking 10 tank shots... is just off-putting. no wonder BF vets were so happy for the game physics in bf6 even though I was there thinking "wasn't this always how battlefield was?" heck even bf1 could still pull this off with so much less systems demand!

I know I might be missing a lot here, but in short to include for those TL;DR people is..

"The game fails short in all the fundamentals there is, the map design doesn't support the gameplay, the server and coding doesn't support the modes and amount of players, the physics is comically bad that it fails to please older title players"

Realistically speaking I might not have much of a say for the 128 players mode since I managed to confirm that my client side was the one messing it up, and felt like DICE/EA might be able to pull this off with better net-code execution on Battlefield 6. Also would love to see 5 Player squads back on later titles as well (or maybe even 6? <3)

It is still a bugfest. I¬¥m running the game on a 7950x3D, 64GB of ddr5 6000mhz ram and a 7900 XTX Vapor X. 
Serious gamefreezes, unresponsiveness during gaming. I tried all the worarounds (process Lasso, Poll rate changes on mouse and keyboard, bios settings... I mean I just payed 3 bucks for the game just to get the free stuff for BF6.. But hell man it takes more hours to do workarounds and tweaking than actually playing this freakin game.. WTF

It says here that I have 13 hours on record at the time of writing, but I'd say I have been able to play around 2 or 3 of those hours. Besides, outside of those 13 hours I spent about 10 to 15 more outside of the game troubleshooting, watching Youtube videos, updating the BIOS for my motherboard, installing and reinstalling and full DDU'ing my graphic drivers multiple times, deleting the cache of the game every time, lowering everything from high/ 3840x1600/ 144hz all the way to everything on low/ 1920x1080/ 60hz+vsynch, trying borderless and windowed, endlessly restarting the game after gpu hang errors.

At some point I thought it was my pc, so I checked other demanding games like Warzone and GTA V enhanced at fully pumped up settings on my 9070XT, and they worked flawlessly.

Ultimately I can't say much about the game itself, as there wasn't a minute without freezes and slowdowns, but for the grand prize of ‚Ç¨3, this whole experience of mine comes totally unrecommended.

i came back just to get the bf6 rewards and i cant even force myself to do it. i have put 30 hours into this game over the last two weeks and i have not enjoyed a single second i have spent on this game. i played on release and i thought to myself maybe after almost 4 years maybe it got better but nope it did not. from the immersion breaking of seeing the exact same characters on both teams in every single squad to bad map design it seems to me like dice designed this game to be a mix of COD,Battlefield and a hero shooter and it did not succeed at any of them so what we are left with is an amalgamation of a game with no identity of its own. 
     But what kills this game the most for me and it is something i hope they remove entirely in the full release of bf6, is open weapons. open weapons was possibly the worst decision they made and i know it was to just sell cosmetic weapon skins since if weapons were class specific it would create a class imbalance if people wanted to run a certain skin. but nothing pains me more than just seeing 90 percent of the kill feed being assault rifles,most of my deaths come from assault rifles i might see a sniper rifle or an lmg here or there but most of it is assault rifles. there is absolutely no variety in matches like there was back in previous titles i dont see supports running lmgs to hold down points or smgs to be a frontline medic. i barely even see recons using dmrs or snipers, ill maybe die to a sniper rifle once every other game and its all because people are running assault rifles and i cant blame them because they are really good and if you have the option to why wouldn't you?
     all in all this game just is not an enjoyable experience and if you can suffer through the battlepass to get the bf6 rewards then hats off to you because i just couldn't

Would I recommend Battlefield 2042?

For full price? ‚Üí Definitely no. It‚Äôs just not worth it.

On sale for something like 4‚Ç¨? ‚Üí Sure, why not. At that price, you can‚Äôt really go wrong.

But honestly, the only reason I‚Äôd recommend it at all is because of Portal. That mode lets you relive parts of BF1942, Bad Company 2, or even BF3 without needing to own those classics. Without Portal, this game would be a hard pass.

The standard BF2042 experience feels‚Ä¶ empty.
It‚Äôs lackluster, emotionally dead, and just doesn‚Äôt click. I can‚Äôt even put my finger on exactly why, but after a short time I simply don‚Äôt want to play anymore. Maybe it‚Äôs:

the weird TTK balance,

the ‚Äúhero‚Äù style classes (which don‚Äôt really fit Battlefield),

the fact that every specialist can use every gun, which kills class identity,

or the movement that just lacks that bit of smoothness.

Whatever the reason, BF2042 never felt truly rounded or satisfying to me.

Battlefield‚Ñ¢ 2042 is okay.  There are lot flaws starting with introduction of specialists. It is the least teamwork oriented, encouraged battlefield ever and it shows. Nearly everyone will be an engineer and it makes sense too. There is little incentive to play as assault or support. 

BF2042 is not as good as any of the previous battlefields and easily the worst in it's series. On its own it is just okay and there is fun to be had, the shooting is still good. Some of the graphics effects are very nice like the shock-wave after effect from an explosion. There is no Levolution or major map changing effects. It just does not improve on anything in a big way. The weather effects just don't do it.

Iwo Jima is the best map that has been introduced at a time when the next new battlefield game is arriving tells everything. The rest of the maps are okay to just not good aside from the other classic maps. 

In this scenario where there are specific maps a player wants to play, having a server browser or the choice to select which map to play was vital. However there is no option and only matchmaking into random maps, so the likely hood of playing in a specific map becomes very difficult to achieve and will just wait endlessly without luck. Using the Portal server browser to play or create will also be out of luck as it looks like it is out of capacity from all the afk grind maps currently being hosted. 

Iwo Jima was presented as highlight a map and so it was easily playable during it's introduction but now it is lost in matchmaking hell. For that reason this game is not recommended and will go back to being dead after everyone collects the bf6 skin rewards.

Games good, Had a bad start I guess but anyone hating on it now just simply likes to bitch to bitch. Is it like other battlefields? Not entirely, but it is still a good shooter.

This isn't just a bad game; it's an offense, a concentrated burst of rage, disappointment, and bitterness that has utterly consumed me. Battlefield 2042 stands as a monument to DICE and EA's colossal failure, a betrayal so profound it has shattered a fan's heart.

The launch was an absolute catastrophe: endless bugs, embarrassing performance, non-existent netcode, and constant crashes. This was not an AAA title; it was a broken, unfinished beta sold at full price, a brazen slap in the face to anyone who paid for it.

But the true betrayal, the one that ignited the deepest bitterness within me, was at the game's very core: Specialists. They brutally butchered the iconic class system, transforming Battlefield into a generic, soulless 'hero shooter.' Squad cohesion died, replaced by ridiculous aesthetics that utterly disrespected the franchise's legacy and its gritty warfare tone.

The maps were vast and empty, vehicle-dominated, lacking any meaningful destructibility, and came riddled with unforgivable absences like a server browser or basic voice chat. It was an insult to player intelligence, compounded by spongy, frustrating gunplay that made every weapon feel unsatisfying.

And the most bitter pill to swallow? I wasted almost 200 hours on this abysmal mess. Not for enjoyment, not because the game was good, but due to cynical, calculated manipulation: the promise of next-game rewards in this season's Battle Pass for Battlefield 6. They held me hostage, forcing me to endure countless hours of soul-crushing frustration, clinging to the faint hope of a better future. It was nothing short of emotional blackmail.

Battlefield 2042 is a total regression, a profound disappointment, and a testament to shattered trust. It wasn't a purchase; it was a costly, infuriating lesson. Avoid it like the plague.

Fun game
Don't let people tell you this game is good. It is far from it.

When it works right (IF it works right), it's very meh compared to what BF6 was for the brief time I played it.

I had no issues running BF6 with GeForce RTX 5060, AMD Ryzen AI 7 350 w/ Radeon 860M (2.00 GHz), 32.0 GB ram... but this game runs so poorly that I noticeably frame drop whenever I get close to someone, even at lowest settings.  The cause seems to be awful optimization, to the point where I have to tailor my gameplay to either bullet hose or stay well away to get responsive mouse movement.  Otherwise aiming feels like I'm moving my viewpoint around like the power steering went out on it.   

The classes are OK, but in practice it's really engineers VS vehicles for the most part, and then snipers 800 miles out.  You can see this when you go into conquest 64 or 128, it'll be like 4 assault, 28 engineer, 8 support, 10 recon.  It's necessary because of the constant stream of vehicles (and helicopters) you'll be dealing with.  I don't know whether that's a balance issue or a spawn rate issue, but you'll spend the majority of your time either shooting people down in vehicles, or trying to blow up said vehicles (if you're running to the points).  

About the engineers, some of them are more useful than others.  

Using Viktor...it makes you wonder what they were thinking with the sentry.  I'm sure they envisioned something like the tf2 engi's sentry gun to be used, then thought it was too powerful, and got rid of anything that might make it useful as a sentry gun.  It is a comically bad piece of equipment in its current state, with enemies using their pistols to destroy it in a few seconds.  It will take two seconds from spotting an enemy to actually firing upon them (making an extremely loud ENEMY DETECTED beeep-boop), at which point it seems to do ~6 damage per shot.  I have resorted to using it as a detection device and being surprised if it manages to do anything else.   The achievements related to the sentry gun are now only feasibly accomplished by using bots to farm it out, which just seems sad to me.  

I get the feeling Viktor isn't the only character who's specialty item is or ever was entirely useless, making some of these characters completely ignored by people who wish to win rather than deal with useless novelties.  Frankly, I mostly see the girl with the rocket launcher specialty being used.

The characters for said classes are like bizarre caricatures of what humans are.  Especially when you open the game and they say their weird wooden line, like the medic guy going "Now is the time".  It's so weird and awkward.  I guess EA wanted to get in on the hero shooter thing that was big when this game came out, but it is so out of place and wooden in this one.

I guess it was an OK purchase for $3, but for the frustration and poor optimization and just general lack of feeling like it's a battlefield title I can't really recommend it.  God help you if you got this pile for $60.  Like a sucker, I went back to this for the bf6 cosmetics.  I can't say I think it's worth the grind.  Curb your enthusiasm and just get BF6 when it comes out.

The actual gameplay is fun whenever it decides to be, but I cannot stress enough how Sisyphean this game feels. I'm rolling a boulder up a hill, the only man at C2 with 14 enemies on me, just to take out 12 of them and the boulder to roll back down to the bottom after getting sneaked by a random dude prone on the fucking floor. Unlike the myth of Sisyphus, though, I cannot imagine myself joyful watching my progress be completely undone especially considering how fucking bad the friendly AI is in this game. I'm literally directing you to attack C2 and 3 dudes go, the rest just hold C1 as if I didn't click the button specifically to command them towards C2. I should not have to go 304 - 32 just to end up losing because my team is too busy suckling on their thumbs and banging their heads against a wall that isn't even there because they're too fucking blind to even kill themselves. I understand that these games are intended for public multiplayer, but I've always felt like the AI modes give Battlefield the cinematic touch it deserves. In this one, though, I can't help but feel like I'm trying to help a group of 24 fifth graders cross the fucking Sinai Peninsula, watching them slam tanks into bushes and run into walls in the process. The game itself isn't bad, but holy shit it's good at making you angry.

If you have the time or patience to spare, I implore that you read the entire review. Everything I say here is simply my personal opinion. If you want, you can leave a comment, whether you agree or disagree with me, I'm down for reading whatever you say, as long as you're civil. Have a good day. :3

tl;dr: Maybe I thought about the "herd-mentality" haters much too harshly... Battlefield 2042 truly does feel to me like a disappointingly sub-par, uninspired 80gb heap of mediocrity, trodding around, wearing the Battlefield trademark. In my opinion, it wasn't even worth it for $3. However, I don't think that negative reviews, whether from others or my own, should dictate your opinions about this game. If you want to go ahead and try it out, we shouldn't be the ones to stop you. If you have fun, go ahead and have fun.

Battlefield 2042, overall, even after years of live service support trying to get it up to slightly above bare minimum standards, still feels... meh. And not the "It'll do, I guess" meh, it was 100% an "This truly fails at providing fun for me" meh. I experienced no *noticeable* bugs, and there were plenty gamemodes and servers to play... I just didn't have fun.

I got past the pretty annoying 'tutorial', played a few matches, both solo and MP, and then uninstalled and refunded. It just wasn't fun to me. Even with the class system brought back later on, I still felt too much like a one-man army and was disassociated from my squad, who I would usually communicate with... I tried my best, believe me, but I genuinely do think that this game feels too much like just some CoD Ground War match, just with 64/128 players.

I'm one of those few that don't think THAT badly about the operators. Yes, they were a massive departure from the Battlefield formula that DICE had been building over a dozen games for over two decades. Yes, they were a stupid trend-chasing attempt gone horribly wrong. Yes, it 100% ruins the squad-based teamwork that Battlefield has been known for. I understand everyone's qualms and hatred against operators. I personally, just, don't really care. I think that having operator-exclusive gadgets is an... alright... idea. They can be really fun, but from what I've seen, they don't really encourage teamwork, one of the main things Battlefield's loved and known for by many.

But, I digress. Let's talk about the weapons first. One of the most important parts of a first-person shooter game. Their animations are usually distractingly weightless and clunky, especially by modern standards, and worst of all, they don't really feel good to shoot. In my book, if you have a game about shooting with guns, the shooting with guns part better be good. But, it's not really good here. I mean, It's alright, I guess... but even the undeniably aging Battlefield: Bad Company 2 has better feeling weapons to me, and more importantly, that game FEELS like Battlefield.

Now, onto the game's artstyle. The overall artstyle lacks most of the grime and roughness that previous Battlefield games put on proud display. Even on the Iwo Jima map, a map set on the war-torn, muddy beaches of... well, Iwo Jima... it still feels much too clean and "pretty". All of the maps I played suffered with this exact issue. Too clean, too pretty, and too, for lack of a better term, cartoony. Battlefield 3 had extremely great looking maps that contrast directly towards 2042's. There was lots of dirt, grime, Michael Bay-esque lens flares, and the unique contrast and tint that create that subconscious but unshakable feeling that you're on a, well, Battlefield (HE SAID IT, HE SAID THE THING!). Battlefield 2042 lacks these things, and it makes the experience feel much too different than what I think a Battlefield game should be.

Everything feels so sub-par, uninspired and just not like Battlefield. I couldn't even keep playing for the Battlefield 6 rewards. I still wanted my refund, despite buying the game for $3. You'd be better off snagging Delta Force: Hawk Ops, and honestly, it's just the same shit but a different game. The only saving grace is that it's free to play, but be wary of Tencent/Team Jade's scummy practices, broken promises, and the absurd amount of microtransactions.

If you think differently than I do, I respect your opinion. I think that if you want to quickly try this out, you can 100% go ahead and try this out and refund if you didn't like it. I and the other people leaving negative reviews shouldn't be the ones to completely sway your opinion. If you like the game and think it's plenty fun, then you like the game and you think it's plenty fun. I don't want to spread hate or cause arguments because we have different opinions about something.

Thank you for reading. I'm glad you had the patience to go through here and read all of my ramblings. And, again, have a good day. <3 <3 <3

[h3] It's still kind of ahh [/h3] 
While I was actually one of those seven people who really liked the art direction of this game, the gameplay regressed way too much, especially considering the previous iteration - bfv, arguably had some of the best gameplay loops in the franchise.

Some noticeable problems were that movement felt worse (combat roll, crouch sprinting and laying on the back were sorely missed), gunplay was less precise and punchy, attrition and fortification system were removed, etc.

However, the worst tragedy that could happen to this game has to be the maps. They‚Äôre just generally terrible: big yet empty, with almost no cover between points. The biggest offender is definitely hourglass, you really have to experience it to see how bad it is. Exposure, on the other hand, worked pretty well in some of my conquest matches.

Now, for some positives (or at least neutral points):

I liked the near-apocalypse setting of the game and wish they had done more with it. The art style was neat and matched the empty maps well, though that was often more of a curse than a blessing.

I also didn‚Äôt mind features like on-the-fly attachment adjustments, tactical sprint, or specialists. I just see those as unique quirks of each bf entry.

The industrial soundtrack, which feels like a natural evolution from bf3 and bf4‚Äôs dubstep themes, was definitely the highlight of bf2042. It‚Äôs extremely atmospheric and distorted, which fit the setting perfectly.

In general, though, the gameplay left me with a sour experience despite the solid(?) presentation. Based on what I experienced in the two betas, bf6 already feels miles ahead of this one. Here‚Äôs hoping it stays that way.

Honest Quick Review
I'm new to the Battlefield franchise so i'll be review from a new player perspective from 30/08/2025 (2 days playing)

Is it good?
Yes. if compared to other BF games maybe not but coming from other games like COD, CS:GO/2, Fortnite, etc. .... it works just fine, it is a new experience unlike anyother i've played before, i like how different snipers behave here compared to the other games. this game is a tactical mess, meant to be Fun over Competitive.

Why people complain then?
most complains come from both the release of the game and in comparison to other BF games (BF3 and BF4 specifically)

Is it worth the price?
I paid 2.99, so yeah absolutely, 59,99 maybe not it's good but with battlefield 6 coming it is just not worth it.

would I recommend?
Yes but only and exclusively if under 9.99

Let's be real. It doesn't feel like Battlefield. I've played almost all of them as far back as BF2. One of my favorite games was BF2142, then Bad Company 2, and then and still BF1. (If that game had bots, I'd probably never play another bf game honestly). I did really like a lot of BF5. I liked a lot of the mechanics in that one. I wished they'd make BF1 but with bots and mechanics of 5, but oh well. This game is a lot of fun and swapping weapon mods on the fly is super cool. The big selling point for me and my friends were the bots. They don't like playing with other players for the most part and I'm getting too old to be playing sweaty games lol. I just don't have it in me anymore, especially after chasing my kids around and working all day.

Would I recommend it? Yeah, I would. I think if you have a very specific case for it, it works great and it is a lot of fun to play. Playing online with people though makes it feel like COD, and I left those games a long time ago. Those games were basically spray and pray, run and gun, and DLC out the ass. I would be lying though if I said it wasn't the BF6 stuff that pushed me to click the buy button and it being on sale for dirt cheap.

Oh yeah! And someone made a zombie mode!

[quote]
[h1]Battlefield 2042 | By Wholf (Short Version)[/h1]
[list]
[*] The matchmaking in Battlefield 2042 feels terrible. You constantly run into max-level players who can kill you from miles away, while planes lock onto you and wipe you out in less than a second. Campers are everywhere, the movement and controls feel clunky, and flying aircraft has noticeable input delay. Gunplay feels unbalanced, you die instantly, yet it takes a full magazine to drop an enemy.

[*] The game looks great, but most of the player base seems to be veterans who already know every spot, weapon, and vehicle, leaving new or returning players at a huge disadvantage. It just doesn‚Äôt feel fun or fair. A possible fix could be level-capped servers (like max level 25 or 50) to create a more balanced experience. Right now, even as someone who has played Battlefield before, this just isn‚Äôt it.
[/list]
[/quote]

My game has crashed 3 times in the 45 minutes I have been playing...

Still pretty shit compared to other battlefield titles but specifically the amount of power they give to vehicles is rediculous.
Every vehicle in the game can survive 3 rockets, assuming you can hit them in the first place through flares and an infinitely toggle-able 'stealth mode', they all have unlimited ammo and can just fly around doing whatever. A decent enough pilot can make a vehicle last an entire game without dying especially if you have even just one dude with a repair torch.

It has fun moments and the guns are pretty neat. The ability to change attachments on the fly is something I wish they'd bring back in future titles. I'm a big fan of the railgun in particular, unfortunate that it doesn't exist anywhere else because it's really satisfying to use.

But the glaring overreach the vehicles have to literally anything is stupid. Also, granted this is a problem in every battlefield game, sniping just isn't fun to do nor worth it to do because your job can be done better by literally any DMR,

I played Delta Force a lot when it came out, and I obviously see that they blatantly copied BF2042, however sometimes they actually did things better. I think both are good (not great) games, but obviously one being free to play and the other one costing 60 bucks.

I think it is insane that they released this game in the state that they did and thought: "Oh yeah, this is going to be a game people are going to enjoy."
People have been begging for years and years for a game that is grounded and feels similar to BF3 and BF4.

They did some of this in this game in BF3 portal modes, but that's pretty much it. It is unfortunate that they leaned into this agent/hero kind of game when it was already past their time.

Battlefield was always known for the destruction, massive maps and chaos all around. Some of the epicness obviously stays and I have felt genuine enjoyment out of this.

But again, it was 2.95 euro. If I paid 60 bucks for this game back when it released I'd be pissed.

BF6 seems to finally go back into the direction we were looking for, but let's see how they mess it up.

You must claim your Battlefield 6 rewards by March 31st, 2026 ‚Äì otherwise, all your efforts will be in vain.

Like many others, I was thrilled and excited when I saw the opportunity to earn weapon skins as rewards ‚Äî both from missions in Battlefield 2042 and from the public playtest of Battlefield 6. I was especially happy knowing that I could claim these rewards now and wait to purchase Battlefield 6 later when it goes on sale. I usually buy each Battlefield title at a 50%‚Äì80% discount instead of at launch, because I know that early releases often come with bugs that take time to fix.

However, after completing the reward missions, I found out that there‚Äôs a strict time limit ‚Äî you must log in to Battlefield 6 by March 31st, 2026 to receive the rewards. I think this is something many players may not be aware of.

A lot of people have spent significant time grinding for these rewards, some even farming XP in Portal mode just to complete the challenges. But like the official page says: If you don‚Äôt log in to Battlefield 6 by March 31st, 2026, all your efforts will be wasted.

"BF2042 is good now!"
no... after playing BF4, BF1, and the BF6 Open Beta, BF2042 doesn't even hold a candle to any of those games.

My opinion is heavily influenced by a specific issue that I has plagued my experience since launch. BF2042 can't read a multi-GPU setup. This had been an issue since launch and hasn't been fixed as of this post. This results in BF2042 ignoring graphics settings and selecting the weaker of the two options. This also prevents the game from being set to full screen for some reason. While this only affects some players and has a work around, those "fixes" don't work in my situation.

It is reading my CPU's Integrated Graphics as a GPU and ONLY uses that instead of letting my discrete GPU work. The common solution to this issue is to disable every other GPU except the one you want to use for the game (which is awful). This doesn't work as while disabling my GPU allows the game to full screen, I am playing with Integrated Graphics. This results in the need to downscale my game to 1280x720p and even then I am playing with less than 30fps. Disabling my CPU is more stupid as the game fails to launch without crashing.

Again, this problem doesn't occur in any other BF title and this has been a known issue since launch. Even ignoring this issue. The game is plagued with bad map layout and balance. The gimmick mechanics are just that, gimmicks. The Specialists hero characters are obviously trying to be "cool", but come off as cringe and pretentious. The vehicles feel both powerful and weak at the same time. Maybe it is a skill issue. Maybe it is because I am playing with less than 30fps. Or maybe this is the worst Battlefield title ever.

Let me skip to the end briefly: I've refunded my 2,99‚Ç¨ copy of BF2042. Let me tell you why.

I've only recently bought the game at an incredibly discounted price since there was a free season pass containing cosmetic content for the upcoming Battlefield 6 set to release on October the 10th this year. The last tier 60 is a quite good looking operator skin that I would have loved to get.
I was lucky I had the time to take part in both open beta weekends for BF6 and though there was a lot that I didn't like about the game, in the grand scheme of things they were minor details. Truth is I had a blast and now had to wait painfully until the full release of the main game.

This brought me to BF2042.
I closely followed the marketing and the release of the game in '21 and quickly determined there was nothing for me here. As a legacy BF fan I especially loathed the operator concept that replaced the unnamed soldiers of the old class system which even for the more open minded players quickly became a source of annoyance by means of incredibly cringe worthy voice lines you couldn't turn off.
The launch was plagued with technical difficulties, little content, low player numbers (they had to prop up their servers with bots to make them feel populated) and only a few and badly thought out maps.

I've been told the game had something of a renaissance since and by the looks of it it did retain a not too small constant player base. At least considering the appalling launch of the game.

However in my opinion it is still an absolute mess. There are dozens of better options out there to play at the moment and have been since '21. And I am not speaking of the absolute horror that the COD franchise has embarked on in recent years.

BF2042's state is a sad one. The maps are incredibly poorly designed, poor visibility, unintuitive terrain and routes as well as angles from which to be assaulted. They seem cluttered in places that need simplicity for gameplay reasons and simplicity that could do well with a bit of clutter for optical reasons. Most of the maps feel and look unfinished and empty. They have no character or soul like the legacy maps so loved by the community.

The gunplay is boring and unrewarding same as feeling a little random at times. There is not much to say about it and in this case thats not a good thing.

At least in my time of playtime I didn't notice blatant problems with the netcode.

Loading times where weirdly long, and the game seemed not at all well optimised.
The menu is a bloody mess. Apart from the colour grading of menu and UI (personal taste) which I detest it is difficult to navigate and hard to understand. Options for graphics and visuals surely could benefit from an example next to it to show off what the settings were manipulating. Basically a common feature nowadays.
The edit classes menu is horrendously bad to navigate, editing and equipping weapons seldom was so frustration inducing to me as it is in BF2042.

I disliked every minute I spent in this game and there is no battlepass in the world no matter how many nice skins for BF6 were in it that would convince me to ever touch this piece of waste of space on my harddrive again. Not if they would pay me for it.

As someone who has never touched the game due to the reviews on launch, I thought after 4 years--they would have cleaned the game up a little. Looking into it, this apparently isn't the first, second or third time this has happened since its release in 2021, but I cannot jump into the 2042 Free-For-All game mode. It just loads and loads like a bukakke film. I also can't get over the clipping issues where your character will land on the ground from wing suit jumps, or even when you hide to cover really quickly, I am literally staring straight through the geometry at times. Its far worse getting into elevators where your character cannot keep up with the speed of the lift. Gun play and hit registration is just the worst I have ever seen in a video game. I encouraged my friend to download this game because I figured maybe I wasn't having fun because NO ONE revives and the teams are always terribly matched with players that have never left the battlefield series on one side, and casual fps players on the other. This, however, was not the case. All of what I mentioned and more just break the immersion of the game and it doesn't help that this game released with an already less-than-stellar look, visually. People hyped this game up and said it was much better than it was when it initially came out. I would hate to see what it looked like in 2021.

The infantry gameplay is alright I'd say but the vehicle gameplay is pretty meh compared to like Battlefield 4's vehicle gameplay.

The maps are pretty mixed, Some of them are okay but other's are just no fun especially when it feels like a walking simulator on the bigger maps to then finally arrive at the objective and get killed.

I absolutaly cannot stand the voice lines of the No-Pats, It would have been a lot better if they were just silent or at least have the option to disable it.

The free season pass just feels too much of a grind for me, The battlefield 6 skins should have been at lvl 40 at max and not level 60.

Overall I just cannot recommend this game and recommend people to just play Battlefield 1, 4 and 5 instead while waiting for Battlefield 6.

Battlefield 2042 is a broken and frustrating game, plagued by more bugs than a picnic in July and random crashes that feel like a personal attack. It's a huge disappointment, with empty, poorly designed maps that have lost the immersive feeling of previous titles. The core gameplay is fundamentally flawed, with weapons feeling as weak as a wet noodle. Piloting a tank feels less like a steel beast of destruction and more like a stationary pi√±ata for every enemy engineer. Teamwork is almost non-existent, making it a frustrating experience to play with random teammates who seem to lack any awareness of objectives or the minimap. This unfinished experience feels as though it was released without a proper beta phase, which begs the question of how a game like this can be released with such a lack of content. It's a betrayal of the franchise's legacy and is certainly not one to recommend. This isn't the Battlefield we wanted, and it's a miracle if you can find a competent squad to play with. Ultimately, the game is not worth getting even on sale.

Apple pie interior preparation:
1) Chop the apples and mix with the granulated sugar.
2) Add the cinnamon and cook until the juice draws.

Apple pie making:
1) Mix all ingredients except flour in a bowl.
2) Slowly add the flour and knead until a consistency does not stick to the hand.
3) Separate the amount of dough from which you prepare to make a cage.
4) Roll out the dough to form a round.
5) Add the apple mortar over the dough you opened.
6) Make small strips with the last dough and cover the apple pie in a cage.
7) Bake in preheated 356 ¬∞F oven for 25-30 minutes until golden brown.

Pros:
- Supports dual inputs. So I can drive with a gamepad and when I go on foot I can use my MKB
- Genuinely fun when you are in a good match.
- Nice big open battlefields for land capturing battles
- The classes are fun and create unique experiences

Cons:
- This game is a scam
- I tried to purchase the Battlefield coins, it kept saying purchase canceled and I didn't get any coins. I tried 3 times. Then it gave me the coins for those 3 times and charged me 3 times. I wish I could tell you about the large-scale battles, the futuristic weapons or the ‚Äúnext-gen‚Äù experience Battlefield 2042 promised us. Unfortunately I can‚Äôt because the game doesn‚Äôt even let me play.

From the moment I hit launch it immediately crashes to desktop. No error messages, no real explanation. Just silence. I tried troubleshooting, checked drivers, reinstalled, even looked into the bizarre ‚ÄúBIOS setting fixes‚Äù some players mentioned  but like many others I found absolutely nothing that worked. And honestly in 2025 why should a AAA title require players to tinker with BIOS just to get past the start menu?

It‚Äôs not just a bug. It‚Äôs a betrayal of trust. We paid full price (or not) for a game that feels less like a product and more like an experiment dumped on the community. The worst part? The forums and social spaces are full of similar complaints and yet the silence from the developers is deafening.

Battlefield has always been about epic scale, immersion and unforgettable moments with friends. Battlefield 2042 instead has become unforgettable for the wrong reasons: broken promises, endless crashes and players locked out of even experiencing the game.

At this point Battlefield 2042 isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúlive service.‚Äù It‚Äôs a ‚Äúdead on arrival‚Äù service. Until the developers acknowledge these issues and deliver a real fix this title deserves to be remembered not as a groundbreaking shooter but as one of the most disappointing releases in modern gaming.

Verdict: 1/10 - Not a battlefield just a crash site.

TLDR; it's a fun game in it's own right, worth it while on sale at the very least. Like a third-party take on the Battlefield genre. Does not have a campaign.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It has the elements of a battlefield game; large scale assault with vehicles, opportunities to have fun moments.
When you actually take a look at the infantry gameplay and compare it to other battlefield games, you can see they tried to take some notes from CoDs playbook. 

Infantry move faster with more movement-based gameplay compared to other battlefield games with tactical sprint, sliding and some operators even having grappling hooks or wingsuits. Many of the guns themselves also feel more toy-like with worse gun sounds and forgiving recoil compared to the other entries of the series. 

I touched on it there, but they have operators instead of the strict class system that we know and love. I do not like it.
A lot of the more tame abilities of these operators could honestly just have been class-locked gear you could equip: spotting drone, mini-map interference "pylon" etc. Meanwhile, others could have been pick-ups around the map like they had with the explosive shotguns back in BF4 ("Lissile" the TV guided missile, minigun emplacement etc.)
Other than that, it also doesn't make me feel like it's Russia vs USA since they both apparently decided to purchase the same PMC group to wage war against itself. 

The operators also all have skins to unlock or buy if you're feeling that your wallet is becoming too heavy. Which doesn't help with the loss of identity since suddenly a masked cyberpunk dude is launching rockets at me. Also had battle passes, but now you can buy some of these skins through the store directly since the seasons are over.

The vehicle grind is just like any other battlefield game where you need to get kills in the vehicles before you can even have a viable vehicle to play. I decided to grind in Solo games trying not to waste the vehicles on me in actual live games, but suddenly realized that the unlocks don't carry over to the Russian vehicle counterparts, even though they have the same exact abilities, with the country-unique gunships being the exception. 
The big issue here is that when playing Solo they decided to make you play US on every map. It wasn't like this before, where you would on some maps play Russia, but now they force you to grind the Russian counterparts in actual live games. 

All in all I can't say it's a [i] bad [/i] game, but it's not exactly an amazing [i] Battlefield [/i] game. It feels EA had an identity crisis when directing this game. It is still a lot of fun though, at least for me since I do enjoy some more fast-paced shooters.

TLDR: This game is still fucking shit, a polished turd if you will. The current player base is fucking terrible at this game.

Despite the numerous updates this game has received it still has terrible issues that plague it from being fun.


Those being:

- This game probably has the most unskilled playerbase in the history of battlefield. Prepare for a lot of engineers not destroying vehicles, medics reviving you in fire, recons being useless, and assaults acting like this is call of duty. I am an average gamer who has only returned to gaming from a 2 year hiatus and can easily find myself in the top 5 - 8 on a team.
- Specialist system is still in place. This means that there will be a large number of players that look exactly like you because they are using the same specialist. Specialists are not only very trouble some as a concept, they are also poorly designed both gameplay wise and aesthetically.
- Maps fucking suck. They are far too big even for the 64 player mode, so there is a lot of dead time. Kaleidoscope is the worst offender and will make you feel like you're in a dead game (don't worry, you are) with how empty the map can feel.
- Guns have the worst feedback in any battlefield title. Sound design lacks any punch, the recoil is non existent, the guns bloom in accuracy like crazy, the reload animations suck, the modification system is terrible. To top it all off, nearly all the guns are original designs which make no sense and are hideous.

BF2042 compared to BF6 Beta is absolutely terrible! More than half of the time I played, I felt frustrated at how silly the map design is:

1) Some maps are too wide, resulting in non-stop flanking, which requires you to keep rotating your mouse 720 degrees, as there is no certainty of where the enemy can be.
2) Some maps also have multiple levels, with 2-3 storey housing peppered all over the place. This creates passive gameplay, where both sides end up camping the houses and waiting for kills to arrive - not interactive.
3) Some maps too narrow and have only 3-4 chokepoints that can be pushed, meaning both teams are throwing gazillion of nades and spamming bullets into the chokepoints, which are then immediately replenished by the Support class gadgets. In this way nothing happens for 20 minutes.

I am yet to play a map that feels good or has some logical design.

Try it for yourselves if you have nothing else to do - there's a reason why this game is on -95% discount sale.

Or just wait for BF6!

Well, it's 95% off. I bought this just for the battle pass to unlock stuff in BF6, which I will get eventually. Anyway, this has to be the worst Battlefield I've played. Even at 95% off there are times where I just don't really feel like playing it. It does introduce some cool systems that I hope future games adopt, like customizing your gun on the go (Assuming you set it up properly beforehand). 

Minimal performance issues on my end. Ryzen 7 5700X and RTX 4070 with 32GB  3600 cl16 ram. Stutter happens only at the start of the round if it's on a map I've never played before, so just general shader building stuff.  In the 7 or so hours I've played, I only had one issue where I couldn't move my mouse after getting rezzed. Was fine once I died and redeployed and it never happened again.

Audio is garbage. Reviewers weren't kidding when they said the music in here is fucking shit. The guns also do not sound anywhere near as good as BF1, 5 and 6. Footsteps sound fine. Better than 5 even if I'm being honest.  Also why does the main menu not have music? BF1 and V had some of their best tracks playing there. Granted, after what I've heard of their score so far, I guess we should be thankful that the main menu has no music lmfao.

UI is horrendous. You'll know what I mean when you're scrolling through your guns. Needless scrolling and  clicking. 

Gameplay is a bit mixed, leaning negative. I like the customization and I think it's the deepest customization Battlefield has ever gotten. However, the process of actually shooting the damn gun, whether infantry or vehicular, leaves a lot to be desired. It's lacking that punch that past titles had. Most guns I've used, which were the starter guns, tended to have laser accurate shots too, so kills are a tad less satisfying.

Building on the gameplay, the maps are gigantic, more suited for 64 v 64. At the same time, 128 players can get messy as all hell. It also doesn't feel like Battlefield anymore when everyone's sliding around and twitch shooting. Really feels like a Call of Duty game most of the time I'm playing. There's just too many bone headed aggressive plays I've made and had them work to not draw the COD comparison. If I played the same way in 1 and 5 I'd just get murdered. Oh also, I notice the very distinct lack of building destruction. In fact, I'd go so far as to say there is no building destruction. Lame.

I am leaning positive towards the specialist system, but to my understanding it was different at launch and the game had no classes at all. Nevertheless, having them contribute differently can give players more stuff to do in the long run while also opening up more ways to play the game. But seeing as specialists aren't really the "heart" of Battlefield as some call it, just carry forward the special tools choice selection without all the cringe characters and voicework.

Still, at 95% off it's hard to say no. I've spent more on a bad meal and I'm sure you have too. Just buy it and try it out. It'll almost be the gateway to a different Battlefield if you like the formula and have never tried a single game in the franchise.

If I had to give this game a final score, it's probably a 3/10 or 4/10 for me. I'm only 7 hours in and I'm kinda already fed up with the game lmfao. It's extremely unlikely I'll return to it after I'm done unlocking stuff on the free season pass. But again, it's 95% off.

Pricing really dictates the value of the purchase for this one. In my eyes the battlefield series, even at its worst is better than the last 5-10 years of call of duty, with some exceptions here and there. Battlefield 2042 at times reminds me why i think so strongly about which game series i prefer out of the two, however in regards to the quality of the peak battlefield games, this game does not get close consistently. At times it feels close to the quality of battlefield 4, and then others it feels like something similar to battlefield hardline, not so much in how it plays but more so that it feels like a black sheep. 

The good:
the game runs very well

sound design is great 

graphics are really good 

moment to moment gameplay CAN BE fantastic

There's a decent amount of content in there, and there's also little to no microtransactions which for ea is mad

the controversial ability to change attachments in game is great in my opinion. I love the idea that i can flank an enemy team, distracted by my teammates, and switch to having a suppressor right then and there, then clearing out a bunch of enemies, and taking the silencer off again and attaching an acog scope to my gun, to go loud and shoot enemies at a distance with maximum damage. It's a cool concept and one that i felt worked, however i understand that this feels to easy to some

The bad:
map design ranges from pretty decent to outright poor, and I feel like there's more of the latter than the former. The big problem in the games map design is how almost narrow things can feel. A lot of these maps can bottleneck your team or the other, leading to things feeling very unbalanced in your favour or against you. I sometimes come out of games feeling like i was handed the win, however if i start on the other side of certain maps, i feel like the games already over before its started. I feel like this issue could have been partially averted through the means of SBMM. If the game was to analyse players most recent matches to determine their skill level, you could partially fill out teams (depending on who starts on the unbalanced side of the maps) with some of the best players in the lobby. This would ensure that whilst one team would still face an uphill challenge, they'd at least have a fighting chance.

Timed modes. Hate this. This live service style of only giving you game modes or playlists when the game deems it acceptable. Rush is arguably my favourite mode in battlefield, and the second most popular mode only to conquest, and yet it's now became a timed match type, so whilst i can play breakthrough or team deathmatch whenever i want, i have to wait a week or so for the modes to change again, and hope that rush is featured this week. I hate that, because i happen to be busy the week my favourite mode makes it appearence. I may have to wait another week or so before i get the chance to play it again.


soldier classes have been changed in a way that makes all classes feel pointless. In older battlefield games i would have to make a decision as to which class i wanted because classes used to have their own specific gun type that the other classes couldn't use. If i want to be a medic, who carries health that not only heals me but my teammates, I'd have to go with the support class, but the support class soldiers would only use SMG's, so i'd have to forfeit the ability to use the LMG or assault rifle, or sniper rifle. If i wanted to be the class that carried around ammo boxes to restock myself and teammates, i'd have to be the heavy class who was restricted to LMG's and so on. 2042 changes this and makes it so all classes can use all gun types, meaning there's almost no sense of sacrifice, or encouragement to experiment. I feel like this leads to weapons not feeling as intriguing. I don't have the motivation to try guns i may never have used, when i can just pick any class and carry on using the weapons i've already gravitated to. this design philosophy is part of what gave battlefield it's identity and losing it makes the game feel less like battlefield and more like every other shooter online game. 

server browser is relegated to portal mode as opposed to the main game modes which i absolutely despise. Essentially server browser has been an incredibly useful tool that ensured that as the game begins to lose its playerbase, you'd still be able to easily join a borderline full lobby with ease. It also ensured you could play the maps you wanted and the mode you wanted it to be. This is now gone, meaning it's never exactly what you want. Fans have complained about this since the games release, however dice has responded by doing the exact same thing for battlefield 6, so that's annoying. 

At it's best battlefield 2042 is an 8.5/10 but at its worst its a 5. I'd say overall the game sits anywhere from a 6.5/10 or a 7/10. it is pretty good and for the price, if you can get it under ¬£10 its worth the cost. it's also the most active battlefield at the moment. However if you're looking for the best battlefield games you can still play online today with varying active communities, i'd recommend games like battlefield 1, battlefield 4 (which is older than battlefield 1. Makes no sense but yeah) and battlefield 3 (also older than battlefield 1) they are the peaks for battlefield online in my opinion. That being said you'd have to buy dlc if you bought those games to get all ther content. One decent thing about this game is that the majority of added content was free, maps included
There are just too many people cheating (aim-bots) in the game, basically you're just cannon fodder for the cheaters... so unless you get it on sale for $2.99 I wouldn't waste money on it.

What do all Battlefield players have in common?

When a new Battlefield game comes out, everyone has something to complain about. EVERY Battlefield game was always released too early; the product still has to mature some time. That's how it's always been, and that's how it will be with Battlefield 6.

But we're talking about Battlefield 2042 here. I've been there since the beginning, and it was a really difficult start. But DICE never gave up on Battlefield 2042. All the maps were reworked, and the classes came back halfway. All in all, a lot of work was put into it, and today Battlefield 2042 is a fantastic game! Even if all the haters are spinning in circles again. 

For a measly 3 euros, absolutely anyone can check it out and have fun without having to badmouth the game.

Negative review due to new requirement to activate "secure boot" in BIOS.

Absolutely disgusting behavior of the publisher/developer. 
To impose manipulations with the BIOS for a 4-year-old game under the pretext of fighting cheaters (*I, by the way, am not at all sure that I have seen them before in either BF1 or 2042. If they exist, it has never been excessively annoying). 
Your anti-cheat already works at the OS kernel level, so now you also have to make changes in BIOS and risk the stability of the entire system for the sake of solving a problem that does not exist.
