Holy crap guys! We finally did it! A positive review of Battlefield 2042 in 2025! They mostly DID fix the game! I can't believe it! Anyways, let's review this game like any other. The first thing I want to get out of the way that I noticed the second I got into a battle is that the optimization is not the best. It's surely playable on a Nvidia Geforce RTX 3070 TI (which is what I have) but it does lag a bit during intense moments. Moving on, the UI is actually really nice. The menus are easy to navigate and I had no problem with them. The guns play a lot like Call Of Duty, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. There is things like tactical sprint and sliding but it's not as extreme as Call Of Duty. The specialists kinda make this game a hero shooter but only to a certain extent. I do like the original class system better but it is what it is. The maps are kinda bland at times in certain areas and some of them are a bit larger than they should be. But some of the maps are actually really nice! Overall I would give this game a... Drumroll please... As of now this game is a... 6/10! Wow guys! They really fixed this game up!

For this promotion where we can currently get the game for just 3$, my biggest thanks go to the entire team. Even though the start and overall Battlefield 2042 didn‚Äôt deliver the most impressive experience, it was still significantly improved in the end, be it performance, cheaters, etc. I think the team has recognized the mistakes they made and will avoid them in the new Battlefield 6. That‚Äôs what we need as a shooter community, especially when CoD is getting more uninteresting day by day with their unicorns farting at people and increasingly focusing on skins rather than making real changes to the game. For years, nothing but cheater and hacker issues that never get fixed and performance is absolutely terrible. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm even more grateful that Battlefield exists, at least one publisher that makes an effort for its players. Thank you.

[h3]Launch Review[/h3]

Do not buy Battlefield 2042

DICE\EA know how to make a ‚ÄúBattlefield‚Äù game.
DICE\EA made trailers that promoted this game.
> DICE\EA inserted all the ‚Äúonly in Battlefield‚Äù moments in to the Trailer
DICE\EA knew that this game is missing all of the below features.
DICE\EA still released this.

A lot of the missing features come from a reddit post, I added a list of my "Broken" experiences. I only wanted to use this list to prove my opening statement.
Battlefield 2042 subreddit and Jellyswim_


No offense was intended, I just wanted to leave my review this morning on the cut content and what a poor "Battlefield" this was.

Missing Core Features
> No standard server browser
> Fewer standardized game modes
> Fewer base game maps than any other title (even including portal the map count is only 13)
> No persistent lobbies You have to matchmake after EVERY round
> Fewer in-game assignments None outside of cosmetic unlocks
> Less character customization options (than BF5)
> No profile progress/stats page in the menu
> No battle log/stats tracker for other players
> No global leaderboards
> No end of round assignment progress screen
> No custom emblems
> Fewer achievements
> No medals
> No swelling crescendo of dramatic music near the end of a match. Static Noise does not count
> Less destruction
> Only a small handful of destructible buildings on each map
> No map altering levolution
> No spectator mode
> No permanent community servers (would be useful for clans and events)

Missing from Infantry Gameplay
> Fewer guns Even including all the portal guns, BF4 still had more at launch
> Fewer infantry gadgets
> No manual leaning
> No diving while swimming
> No high wall vaulting
> No crouch sprinting
> No backwards prone
> No explosion knockback
> No rolling after falling from heights
> No ammo or health pickup off teammates
> No scope zeroing
> No thermal optics
> No indirect fire gadgets
> Less anti-tank launchers
> No lock-on launchers The M5 works with the SOFLAM but that requires 2 people
> No AP mines/claymores
> No static weapon emplacements
> No fortification building
> No resupply stations
> No suppression mechanic This one I don't mind but it was a staple and now it is gone

Missing from Vehicles
> Fewer vehicle types Separate vehicle progression per faction even though they are functionally identical.
> No naval vehicles Except I guess the hovercraft technically
> No vehicle gunner direction indicator
> No lock on direction indicator
> No vehicle enter/exit animations
> No tank turret decoupling This was in BF4
> Less vehicle driver/pilot customization options
> No tank zoom customization options
> No tank gunner customization options
> No helicopter gunner secondary weapons
> No separate helicopter/fixed-wing controls
> No control input while looking behind/free looking in aircraft

Missing from Scoring System
> No squad wipe scoring
> No player damage points
> No vehicle damage points
> No vehicle kill assist points
> No headshot bonus
> No long-range kill bonus
> No assist counts as kill bonus
> No squad objective play bonus
> Oversimplified teamplay scoring (i.e. healing a teammate always gives you +5xp rather than the amount of health you give)
> Squad and Teamwork
> No commander
> No special squad call-in abilities
> No squad field upgrades
> No in-game VOIP
> Fewer factions (with almost nothing to give the 2 factions any distinction)
> No cross-team chat
> No "create new squad" option
> No clans
> No view of squadmates while in the spawn screen
> No "Medic incoming" indicator in downed state
> No rank names/icons, just a number.

Missing from UI and Quality of Life
> Less control customization options
> Less UI customization options
> No HUD/icon opacity customization
> No HUD scaling customization options
> No gunsight reticle customization options
> No network performance graph
> No individual player scoreboard
> Less detail in the 'who killed you' screen
> No ultrawide monitor support. Cannot move UI elements to suit screen size
> Very poor friend joining system

BROKEN
> 45 tick rate servers
> Rubberbanding
> Deploy bugs, revive bugs. Downed state bug that prevents you from being revived if you clip through anything. There times where you have no countdown and cannot respawn
> Janky animations
> Performance is horrible on PC. Unplayable framerates from what looks like CPU bottlenecking
> Unlock three different silencers for the same weapon that have no effect on the stats of the weapon
> Exact same attachment on two different guns having an opposite effect
> Hovercrafts are able to scale vertical surfaces, as well as fly in the right circumstances.
> In rare cases, a player will become unable to damage enemies. This player will also lose their nameplate, causing them to appear as hostile to allies. This is fixed by dying and respawning.
> Broken Bullet Registration
> Broken Bullet Spread
> Broken Weapon Balance
> Broken Vehicle Balance

Do not buy this game

Not sure if it's my computer, but the dumb ass game is constantly, and pretty inconsistently, crashing on me. Sometimes I can play a full match or two with no problems, while other times, I can't even get through half a match all evening. I read that it could be the anti-cheat (the Battlefield 6 beta did a bit of this, too, but 2042 has been a lot worse). It even takes 2 or 3 minutes to just get me into the menu, tf?

Besides that, from a casual gamer standpoint, the game isn't bad. The aesthetics are mostly pretty vibrant and interesting, and the combat is exciting. Shooting feels ok, if not slightly lacking in power. Feels more like a free-to-play game, though, if I'm being honest. There's not even a campaign. And (and this is just my personal taste), I'm not big on these "slightly futuristic" worlds -- it lacks the grim and grimy feel, but also isn't something sleek and otherworldly like Halo. Feels sort of like... nothing. Certainly not Battlefield.

Anyway, the crashing is 100% my biggest reason for not being able to recommend it. But if you find the game looks interesting, for a few bucks on sale, I say why not try it?

I really hate the fact they added cosmetics to grind out for BF6 within BF2042, I really have to push myself to keep playing it for those cosmetics

Honestly overall BF2042 had a lot of potential but the execution is just horrid even 4 years post release while the majority of bugs are fixed (still a few remaining) the game just isn't fun

Battlefield is normally known for its great audio. As in great sound effects, great directional sound quality and great music. In all aspects BF2042 is a failure, the music is annoying, the menu background sound is annoying and the sound effects are annoying. They consist out of a bunch of random beeps some of which I honestly still haven't figured out what they mean. I feel like sometimes BF2042 just randomly beeps for no reason. While the overall audio just sounds very muffled and it makes it generally hard to figure out the position of the enemies even with my directional headset which performs insanely well on Apex Legends, BF6 Beta, CoD, R6 Siege and even Marvel Rivals. Yet in BF2042 I struggle to figure out where the footstep sounds are coming from as the quality of the directional sound is just horrid in this game

Bad sound aside, the gameplay just is very boring and repetitive a big part of this comes from the absolutely horrid map designs. Here I was thinking CoD maps are bad, BF2042 makes even the worst CoD maps seem like GOTY maps. Fortunately BF6 maps are substantially better and even my least favourite maps in the beta are far more enjoyable than the best maps in BF2042. I really just don't know what they were thinking with the map designs on BF2042 and clearly they underwent little to no playtesting and if they did then only thing I can figure is that it was tested by non-gamers and they were like yeah this is fine, not like we have any comparison point but these maps are absolutely fine

The poor gun handling and broken hit reg was infamous at launch. Hit reg is mostly fixed there are occasions where hit reg still goes absolutely wonky. The main issue is the guns just generally don't feel nice to shoot which is kind of a core thing on FPS games and part of why CoD has remained so popular as even with their worst entries the one consistent factor is that the weapons are very satisfying to use. In BF2042 you just constantly feel like you are fighting your own guns rather than enjoying them and it isn't even the TTK/TTD as BF2042 has an even faster TTK than BF6 beta did but it just is the way the guns feel is just very unsatisfying and somehow annoying

Lastly vehicles play a big part of the BF franchise and yet another thing this game somehow manages to completely botch. All the vehicles feel very floaty. They lack weight/mass and generally look weird when they move around regardless if you are in a vehicle or seeing someone else in a vehicle be it enemy or ally

The scales are also all messed up, some vehicles that should be much larger than others are somehow smaller and vice versa. While jets normally are a challenge to deal with in Battlefield here they fly so slow that it yet again looks downright bizarre but also means they are very easy to take down especially with anti-air guns. But it looks like the jets are literally moving in slow motion and in fact some of the game's helicopters are actually faster than the jets lol!

Here and there you do find moments of Battlefield fun but they are very rare. I think if I had to pick one thing that would have made this game much more fun it would be the maps. I don't actually believe that operators ruin this game and oddly enough it is one of the few things I actually enjoy about BF2042 as it sets it apart from the other BF games. But the main issue is really just the maps are horrid

The second main issue is the gunplay but better maps really would have made this game hit much better with the fanbase I believe as it is really the maps that honestly makes it so much more painful to push through the free pass for the BF6 cosmetics

On a side note, if you ever want to know what GamerGate is really about. It is about gamers criticising mainstream video game critics for taking bribes to write positive reviews. PC Gamer gave this game 80/100 and mind you that was not now after years of updates that was based on the launch product which was completely broken and unplayable across all platforms. Ironically enough look at all the recent articles from PC Gamer about BF2042 they all say how bad the game was and remains to be. GamerGate on full display there

(Yes I know there is a claim that GamerGate is the collective harassment of female journalists, but where do you think that narrative came from in the first place? Perhaps from the very same websites that were being criticised for faking their review scores for under the table bribes. The bulk of the reviews that were criticised were written by men, not women!)

Overall, the game is okay. It's not the best Battlefield game, has a lot of issues, but also has some pretty cool ideas.

I shockingly enjoy the specialist system. While I prefer Battlefield to make me feel like just another soldier in the war, 30 of the same distinct looking guy running around is distracting, and the cringe voicelines (that have thankfully been removed) were cringe, the utility they bring to the matches is pretty sick. I love being able to wingsuit around on bigger maps, drop a turret, or shoot team mates with a heal gun. I'm honestly going to miss some of these abilities come BF6. 

Some of the maps are cool, others are awful. Some of the guns feel bad, some feel amazing. The futuristic art direction feels a little underwhelming. The destruction isn't nearly as impactful as prior entries. 

Overall, it's pretty middle of the ground game with some good ideas, saved by the fact that the core gameplay of battlefield is always fun in the same way pizza always tastes good. I just wish it would stop crashing.

I'll be honest, I'm having a lot of fun here, but man this game has a lot of issues.

Battlefield 2042 just feels misguided, like DICE was so focused on chasing trends and trying to do what COD was doing instead of just focusing on making a good Battlefield game. Most of the maps suck, the gunplay feels weird, the Specialists feel out of place, Secure Boot is a requirement to play, like dang there's a lot wrong with this game.

But man when it's fun, it's a lot of fun. The Battlefield moments are still here and they are still great. Some positives I can give is that being able to call in vehicles as infantry and swapping attachments on the go is great, and honestly I like the weather system. Having an active tornado in a match can be pretty funny.

The game's bad, yeah. I don't think it's as bad as everyone says thou. It's still a lot of fun. Like you can enjoy bad things, nothing wrong with that. You will definitely get your money's worth when it's on sale, but I do not recommend this at full price. DICE definitely could've made a banger with this one but they missed the mark.

I was hesitant because of the reviews, but now that I have played it, it has become one of my favourite.
This game is actually so very fun, to extreme degrees.
It plays so smoothly and feels great.
There's so many different choices of weapons, equipment and classes.
And it works really well, it doesn't have the squad connectivity issues that we had on Battlefield 1, which I also love.

It's getting so many negative reviews, but it seems like the reasons while being valid, aren't that the game is not fun
The reasons are that the game used to have issues at launch, and despite them being fixed, lots of the reviews remained unchanged.
And another reason seems to be that many are giving negative review because of the anticheat, and it needing secure boot on.

I understand that many don't want to be restricted, though on a windows system you can easily run with secure boot on and enjoy the very fun game.
I wish it wasn't needed so that people wouldn't have problems.

But despite the bad launch, and the anti-cheat needing more strict measures which can be good from some aspects, I have to admit and put it out there that the game is very much worth playing. 

If you like a shooter with lot's of customisation and futuristic aspects, I 100% would recommend this. 
And it's so much better than something like CoD that I see very little reason someone would buy those instead of this.

My review is based on how the game is playing now as of August 2025, and I haven't played the game before this, or at launch. So my opinion isn't affected by that as it should not be either.

Battlefield 2042 brings large-scale battlefields, large maps, modern vehicles and massive battles that create the epic feeling typical of the series. The visual effects, sound and chaos on the battlefield are really impressive, especially when playing with friends. However, the game has encountered many bugs, optimization issues and the controversial Specialist system, making the experience not complete. After many updates, the game is more stable, but still lacks the perfection that fans expect. However, if you like large-scale and dramatic battles, Battlefield 2042 is still a choice worth trying.
Hopefully the game also manages the hack/cheat issue more, I play for a long time and encounter quite a few QwQ

Never thought I'd play this because of all the hate its received over the years. Played the BF6 beta and had a blast, reminded me of the BF3 and 4 days, and I was itching for more BF, then this went on sale for $3, and myself and a few of my friends all decided to try it. Granted it's only been about 7 hours that I've played so far, but we are all having a great time. First sitting, I played for about 5 hours straight and thoroughly enjoyed it all. Progression is fast with a steady stream of new weapons and attachments being unlocked, tons of cosmetics are easily obtained with no money, the game runs silky smooth at 5k ultra on a 4090, getting a solid 200+ fps. Guns all feel good to use, and the change EA made to the operators to make them more like old school BF is nice (I never played early on when they were more like heroes). Vehicles don't feel too overpowered, maps are mostly fun (there are a couple I'm not a fan of so far), and all the classic BF modes are present and enjoyable. All in all, the game is great fun for BF fans and definitely worth the three bucks to have something until BF6 comes out. Definitely going to be pumping more hours into this over the next few weeks.

I played this game on the EA app at launch and logged about 150 hours. While its true that this game is much better than the product delivered at launch, this is not what I want to expect when I think of a Battlefield title. It's obvious that EA had some other kind of hero shooter/br planned before we got whatever this is. 

My review might have been swayed to positive if the matchmaking in this game delivered on any level whatsoever. Lack of a server browser with persistent servers is just a shame. Even if there was no server browser besides the portal browser, (which is just full of xp farms btw) persistent servers would at least let me play the game without running the same map 3x in a row. On top of that, within 2 hours of playing I joined 3 matches that were within 5 minutes of ending, and then got kicked right back out to the main menu to wait another minute to play on the same map.

The map reworks and class system, that were added far too late into the games lifespan, do help appease some of the bigger issues this game had at launch, and I've found myself enjoying the newer maps and vehicles, especially with a squad. But the lows seem to overtake the highs enough for me to quit mid match.

Ultimately, this game will most likely die within the next year, so I salute the devs for their commitment and hard work to a product that executives doomed to fail from the very start.

This game doesn't feel like a Battlefield game. I have played BF1, BF4, and BF5, and each of those games [i]feel[/i] like Battlefield games. This game feels closer to Call of Duty, but I don't want to play Call of Duty, I want to play Battlefield. Aside from failing the vibe check, there are a variety of other issues.

The UI is a nightmarish chore to navigate. How do I unlock X operator? No idea, I can't hover it to find out. Instead I have to google it and hope to find a rough answer (I can't even look up the specific character because you can't see the names of locked characters). 

Speaking of unlocking things, this game's weapon progression [i]sucks[/i]. You unlock guns in a seemingly random order by just levelling up in general, unlike in previous Battlefield games, where you unlock weapons for a class by playing the class, which was much better‚Äîpeople are going to have their favourite class or two, and that system made it so that each weapon you unlocked while playing felt like something to actually look at, rather than this one, where I have to unlock several guns that I will likely never use in order to get X weapon that I want.

I hate the maps in this game. They just feel bad to play on, and they look... lazy...
In the previous games, the maps felt like places that would have actually served a purpose for the people using them‚Äîlittle towns, resorts, military bases... in 2042, I can hardly tell what a place was supposed to be and/or how it got to the state that it's in. Like the sports arena almost entirely submerged in sand at an angle. That doesn't at all feel like a real context which could emerge twenty years from now (also playing on the map sucks).

I won't say that this game is bad, but I also won't give it the Fallout 4 "good game, bad Fallout." Battlefield 2042 is an average shooter game and it's a Battlefield game in name only.

Played on multiple occasions
This game isn't as half bad as people make it out to be.
After some fixing here and there, this game is actually decent and fun.

The gunplay is smooth and snappy

The character movement is smooth and allows for more accessibilty in some of the more open maps and thanks to it, controlling your foot soldier is a streamlined experience.
Vehicle movement is an actual improvement from the previous installments of the franchise and personally I strongly believe that the overall movement is a strong point of this game, because you fight the enemies and not the janky rubberband'ish controlls like in many other shooters.

Graphics/Audio-wise it's pretty much a classic Frosbite-Battlefield standard since the Battlefield 1.

It's a mix of a classic Battlefield experience with a somewhat modernistic approach to the title.

If there was something that I didn't like, it probably would be the weird setting implementation, but otherwise its a pretty fun "kickback and fool around" shooter game.

This game ought to be studied - how not to make a game. Every single aspect of this pathetic excuse for a game is an infuriating mess, culminating in the largest flaming turd a triple A studio could ever hope to produce.

I cannot fathom the incompetence EA managed to scrounge together for this title. There is no cohesion, no flow, no joy to be found, not even a glimpse of what makes Battlefield so great to be clawed from the depths of this heap of garbage.

The lengths I had to go to just get this game started. First the EA anti cheat didn‚Äôt work and then I had to go change my boot order in my bios, just to fuck around in a few matches of Battlefield. This might all be a norm now, I don‚Äôt know, but it didn‚Äôt leave a good first impression. When I finally got it to launch, it took its sweet ass time loading in. They added some very annoying unskippable cutscenes for those who launch for the first time and it is so slow at loading in between them. I waited more than 10 minutes from hitting play till I ended up in the menu. But I did get it to work in the end, I guess.

When loading into games it felt like every second server crashed and it was really slow at loading when a game wouldn‚Äôt connect to the server. Queue times are quick though, even for the 128 player conquest, it is usually less than a minute queue per match, so that was good.

The game does feature an ingame store with microtransactions and battle passes, though I didn‚Äôt feel like it was something that was thrown in my face. I actually did have to go look for it to check it out. So I guess that is another positive?

I spent more time on fixing issues and in loading screens than I have actually spent playing, so I don‚Äôt see myself ‚Äúplaying‚Äù anymore of it and therefore I refunded it.

As a battlefield fan this is underwhelming, however it was 3 dollars at the time I bought it. mixefield, battlemid, big call of duty, and y'know filling the Spirit Halloween niche for mtx skins as opposed to like Snoop Dogg and Rick Sanches hopping into squad. This game is sorta-at the end of its life and with BF6 around the corner and I'm not going to lie the current -free battlepass- offered giving skins for that game did entice me to give it a shot. 

 To solidify the opinions of me and my other dollarstore brother-in-arms that I purchased the game along side (within my friend group) it's fun, it's not particularly groundbreaking but it's fun with friends. We don't really go for hero shooters so the partitioned gadgetry and the silly costumes in concert with the characters that just-blend together kind of makes the experience all-sorta bland, occasionally I'll see a jet or a tank zip by with some immersion challenging color or novelty camo and it sort of just takes me right out, nevermind the endless sea of skull-facemasks and candy-coated tacticoolarmor, the guy who just t-bagged you has a gold-plated m1911 with a billion attachments and pearl furniture.  For anyone who's skeptical that it is a hero-shooter variant to Battlefield The engineer with the sentrygun wont stop calling out how an "enemy hero"is in the AO when I soypog point and spot an enemy.  

I understand we're a far-cry from Bad Company 2 multiplayer and with the beta of 6 fresh on the mind it's nice to see the roots I enjoy sort-of come back. I know we're on a timer here until some really whack cosmetics come and knock things out of the things I like about the game. 

The guns feel fine, the vehicles are fine, the character kits while oddly partitioned are fine. Just because I hopped onto a life-raft and scaled the Titanic to hear the band play one last song doesn't mean you should join me, you could get like a couple of sodas or like a snack from a gas-station for that price, Ask yourself is the mild-annoyance of grinding a battlepass for a gasmask on one class worth your favorite candybar?  If yes? see you there, welcome to battlepass hell.

The most important thing I learned playing this game is that Battlefield and COD are nothing alike. There's no point comparing them and it would be unwise to cross-shop them. In Battlefield you are are fragile, vulnerable, and there's only so much you can do on your own. You can't change the course of a game yourself, you can't go on a sick killing streak by running and gunning. In battlefield you have to be able to find joy in the tiny success of moving 20 steps without getting spotted and immediately shot from 5 different directions. There's nothing wrong with liking that sort of gameplay, but comparing it to COD is nonsense; this is for a completely different type of player.

I got the game for a gift by a friend, it was $3 on sale. And ya know what, it's actually really fun! This is my review after playing for 24 hours over the span of a few days.

Holy hell, if you told me two years ago, that in 2025 I would be playing BF2042 all day long like I played BF3 and 4, I would call you a son of a b**** and a liar. I'd curse your family. But here I am having a blast. I haven't had this much fun in a Battlefield game since BF4. I have had a great time playing the various Conquest modes, Breakthrough, and AI bot matches. There's even some servers that run 16 players vs hordes of AI. It's a meatgrinder and it's seriously fun. That was the kind of stuff I loved about the oldest Battlefield games, 1942, Vietnam, 2, and 2142. The gunplay is solid, the maps are fun, the sounds effects are punchy, the movement is slick and intuitive, the UI is tolerable with custom colors (I use solid Blue vs Red instead of Cyan and Orange, and a Half-Life amber for the HUD.) It also kinda feels like a GI Joe game with the slightly futuristic vehicles. I just wish each team had completely different looks for the Specialists. That would have been really cool. Honestly, I also wish DICE would allow us to use the AI Bots skins for our player, they look amazing and really immersive. I think it would make the multiplayer way more appealing. As it is now there is no 'faction readability.' So it can be confusing to recognize enemies in the chaos.

And when it goes on sale it's 3 bucks. You can't beat that value. I'll enjoy it for a few months as I wait to BF6, and I won't regret it.

A lot has been said about Battlefield 2042 and how it isn't a real Battlefield and that it's a bad game, but as someone who loves BF1 and has played 2042 from its Beta and the initial first year on PS5 and now 10 hours again on PC. I believe Battlefield 2042 has a lot of what i love about the franchise: While destruction has taken a step back in the wrong direction and the characters are out of touch cheesy, none of that takes away from the cinematic chaos and stressfull cooperation while bullets fly, i also adore the bigger 128 player maps with huge variety in the different zones. And the addition of things like tornadoes and wingsuits takes the Battlefield experience i fell in love with and dials it to a Tenet level 11. I love it, and i will sorely miss those parts as we switch to Battlefield 6. That game looks amazing in different ways though, and it proves to me how flexible the genre is while keeping the core of what i fell in love with: The all out scale and chaos of the battles.

Look, I don't know what kind of futuristic magic DICE used to make this game, but every time I hop into Battlefield 2042, I feel like I'm starring in my own action movie‚Äîexcept the plot is mostly just me accidentally parachuting into enemy tanks.

The world‚Äôs largest maps? Check. The most ridiculous gadgets that somehow work in my favor? Check. And don‚Äôt even get me started on the storm clouds of doom‚Äînothing says "living on the edge" like being in the middle of a firefight and suddenly realizing you're caught in a literal tornado.

Every time I think I have a grip on the game, I get sniped from the sky by a helicopter pilot that‚Äôs clearly practicing for Top Gun 3. But that's the beauty of it, isn‚Äôt it? It‚Äôs chaotic, unpredictable, and even when things go terribly wrong, I have a blast (pun intended).

So, if you love big guns, massive explosions, and accidentally ending up in the wrong place at the wrong time‚Äîthis game is for you. If not, well, you're missing out on some of the most fun you can have in a digital warzone. Highly recommend!

I bought this game yesterday for 3eur and somehow it launched on first go, I had an arguably decent first round and turned it off and walked away. Yet my mild enjoyment must have been clearly signalled to the platform and EA sought immediate remedial action to correct this untenable situation. Come a few hours later. I try launching again and the whole drama begins. "Error, it may be something on our side, please check account" - you're god **** right it was. After 2 hours of trying to launch the game and troubleshooting that literally kept sending me round in circles between EA, Steam, a dozen of logins, reinstalling the game, claiming ownership on either platform and finally my bleeding BIOS because of some secure boot BS, I decided to put an end to this insanity.

What happened to gaming? Why does the launching and everything leading up to the gameplay feel like I'm opening a bank account with a north korean passport?? Seriously, this needs to end. EA and its garbage need to dissolve on the surface of the sun and be joined by similar games/studios.

After playing BF 6 Beta... I came back to this after 2 years and I can't believe how bad the game still is. The vehicles I didn't get in previous Battle Passes were locked, then they unlocked, but I couldn't use them. Battle Pass missions also have a problem in that they sometimes don't even show up. You go to the missions page and don't see any tasks at all. When it appears and you complete Tier I and are already doing tasks in Tier II, for some incomprehensible reason it locks again and tells you that you must first complete Tier I, where the mission is "play 1 round," and you are already playing 4. What the hell... Then there are problems when the camera bugs during a round, meaning you can't use vehicles or technology that changes the camera from a soldier to something else. For example, in RPG, after a shot, the camera remains somewhere under the texture. The same applies to vehicles. It will only be fixed in a new round.
I hope BF 6 doesn't mess this up, because the beta looked very good.

Tbh I don't understand where all the hate is coming from for this game besides it having a rough launch.. most battlefields had a rough launch so I don't understand the difference? But I actually enjoy this game quite a lot. I have way more fun than frustration or annoying moments and this will be a good hold in until Bf6 comes out! Is it a GOOD battlefield? Honestly it still does feel like battlefield but only in terms of vehicles included on large maps with chaotic "battlefield moments" this game still has that so IMHO yes in a way but.. This game definitely has an identity crisis for a battlefield but imo.. I am enjoying it still it's fun for what it is you just can't go into this expecting it to be like Bad Company, BF3 or 4 or even like 5 or 1 this just feels like the battlefield they wanted to go another direction with and imo I think they did okay in that aspect.

NOW.. for my gripe with this game.. holy the TTK is INSANE for EVERY gun.. not a terrible thing.. this just means every gun can be good BUT this also means no gun really has an identity in that class of guns and I can see how this can get really dry. The only real difference is 1 or 2 bullets to kill, slight mag size difference, the fire rate and SLIGHT recoil/accuracy differences. Like you can just grab any gun in a specific class put a scope on it and it won't feel much different from most of the guns in that class. I honestly have to say this is probably the EASIEST battlefield with the gunplay which can be a good or bad thing.

The hero system for characters I am not gonna lie I HATED it at first I still kind of do deep down but when you view this game as the "different" battlefield and you see the balance for how the game is built around this system it isn't really that bad even if it's really odd for a battlefield. I much prefer if battlefield would go the route of having the bf5 style customization (why doesn't more have that?) and then maybe have the special class abilities on top of each player customized character instead of hero's THAT would have been tons better imho.

Honestly when this game is on sale I say get it why not? At full price I don't think it would be super worth it unless you are craving this kind of game. If you have played Delta Force (this is just a better Delta Force honestly) or enjoy faster paced larger scale fps game's this is still a pretty okay game and fun!

This game is really boring.
Specialists, even after the rework still ruin class dynamics and you're more likely to continue maining just 1 or 2 of them for their gadgets.
Gunplay still feels inconsistent, with the 2042-era guns not feeling very good. Funnily enough, the legacy guns from BF3/BC2/1942 feel like how I remember them.

Literally only playing it for the BF6 items but since I'm dumping my time into it, I might as well give the same time for a review.

This game is bleak, boring, and the reason Battlefield as a brand almost died.  Let's hope nobody from this mess is helping with the Battlefield 6 game.  My overall score for this title is a 4.0/10, my lowest to date on any review of a major game release.

Graphics:  7/10

The game looks fine, aged decent enough I guess, It's nothing really to write home about, the guns look detailed, the "operators" ugly faces are all detailed, sound design is passable, environmental destruction is some of the weakest I've seen in a Battlefield title.  There's nothing to praise here, but also nothing to really dig in on, so this portion gets to be short.

Gameplay: 3/10

Most Boring Battlefield Ever.  Operators is a terrible idea removing the anonymous soldiers that once roamed the franchise's maps, now you get to be "Boris" or "Dozer" and feel absolutely zero personal attachment to your character.  Customization options are just reskins, characters are bland, boring, and 'diverse', meaning every race and gender is represented in the most dull, boring, corporate way possible.  The gunplay is weak, occasionally giving you a taste of nostalgia with BF3 guns ported in, but the 2042 base weapons are either awkward, weak, or just dull.  The best maps of the game are ported in from older games, vehicles are basically worthless, and the infusion of 'futuristic technology' only serves to take away from the fun, rather than add to it.

Multiplayer:  6/10

Online lobbies are standard, the game is still sorta buggy, netcode is terrible and you'll get shot behind cover, through the earth, or as soon as you spawn.  Many maps offer large open lanes which favor Recon more than anything, but when the fighting does go urban or compact, fear not, because the netcode is so poor you can hold a corner and die to an enemy before they even round it on your end.  Prepare to spawn on your teammates to get instakilled because the "Combat" detector isn't working properly, or just join the grind, spawn as a Recon, grab a spotting drone, and grind points the entire match flying around.  As a BF3 and BF4 Veteran, this is some of the weakest multiplayer I've participated in to date.

Overall this game is just a sad excuse in an expensive jacket.  It's not fun, it's not engaging, I felt zero dopamine despite winning matches with 40+ kills, destroying vehicles, or getting multi-kills.  I don't know how they managed to accomplish this, honestly.  If you're like me and you're only after the Battlefield 6 content, don't spend more than the $3 you have to.  If you're not here for BF6 content, don't even waste the $3, take that money and go to 7-11 and buy a soda, that way your brain can at least enjoy some dopamine when the sugar hits you.

I'll unfortunately continue grinding this game out, but Battlefield 6 better learn from the example this game set forth on what not to do.

I don't know if I never game this game a proper chance or they've just updated it since the beta that I played to be better. I have additional hours on the EA app.

The summary is this:

It's a weird, weird Battlefield like the other weird Battlefields that came before it. 128 players is where it shines, the one defining feature like all of the other weird Battlefields and their defining features.

Every generation we get a Battlefield game that does something different and alienates the majority of the community. There was Vietnam, there was Battlefield 2 Special Forces, which some of the community didn't like because of its small scale and infantry focus (like Battlefield 6), there was 2142, there was Bad Company 1 and Bad Company 2 (considered by many not to be a real Battlefield), then Battlefield Hardline. 2042 definitely fits that niche of off the beaten path Battlefields.

I'm addressing the community's negatives first:

-The heroes: Completely bullshit and as everyone says just a vehicle for skins, but I actually like the mechanic in itself. Rather than the game just having the classic 4 basic classes you've essentially got 16 of them in function. If you're the type of player that likes different type of support styles, there's an ammo focused one, one capable of immediately healing, one that can build barricades. All of the classes function in this way. AND IT WORKS.

-The open weapons: Considered a major sin, I think the series actually *needs* open weapons because for decades now Battlefield has been stuck with the problem that different weapons are objectively better, or that the classes themselves get pigeon holed in certain combat roles based on the weapon they're assigned. No more being stuck with a weapon you don't like to play or doesn't work for the map because of your class.

-The lack of destruction and levolution: It is what it is. It can absolutely be a deal breaker but at the same time you don't have to worry about all of the cover being destroyed 5 minutes into a round like the other games in the series. There are supposed to be severe weather effects but I haven't encountered any besides some typhoon weather that didn't seem to influence the match at all.

-The aesthetic: It's a blend of near future modern and weird sci fi bullshit. It doesn't work for me at all. You have dark colors with bright LEDs and an ugly ass, bright HUD. Horrible.

But besides those things, I think the game does some things right:

-128 players is something the community has wanted for decades. This mode is interesting because the maps are way too big (like the people complaining about Battlefield 6 want). Sometimes it works horribly, but when it works it provides a unique experience that I don't think another Battlefield is going to capture again. There is a plethora of vehicles. There are so many people playing each class that it you don't need to pick one because there's an imbalance (which is still the least picked class it seems). And the best part is that is what you do individually doesn't matter at all because at this scale there's very little an individual player or even squad can do to influence the game. This is the first time I've played Battlefield and felt like I can just relax. It also creates moments like no other Battlefields before it - you'll have parts of the Battlefield with 64 players just rushing the objective like Normandie.

- The Portal: People love it, I don't know why, but there's a Bad Company 2, a 1942 mode, and a Battlefield 3 mode. I tried it, it's fine. The community is pretty dead right now and seem to flock to AI matches.

- This ties into the open weapons but there are SO MANY weapons, vehicles, attachments and upgrades. It goes beyond the rest of the franchise. Being able to adjust them in match is a nice touch, though stupid and pretty divisive. Ghost Recon did it and it wasn't great,

This hot mess is not even worth the 3 bucks. 
You might think you want those BF6 rewards but prepare for hours of awfully dull matches.
Reconsider and get a cup of coffee instead, you'll find more enjoyment anywhere else.

Everything feels extremely off. It was probably made by the lowest bidder. It's objectively bad through and through.

Battlefield 2042
Bought it for $3. Worth about $2.50.

Maps are endless parking lots where cover doesn‚Äôt exist, and every corner is part of a sniper‚Äôs early retirement plan. Pretty sure the layouts were designed by a 60-year-old grandma at EA who thinks ‚Äúfun‚Äù is drawing squares in Microsoft Paint.

Cross-play is mandatory, which just means being farmed by 30 twelve-year-olds with aimbot while you wonder why you didn‚Äôt just boot up Minesweeper instead.

And the theme? 2042 apparently means cargo ships rotting in deserts. The entire game looks like it was designed by a confused intern who watched Mad Max once and thought, ‚ÄúYeah, but what if there were more boats?‚Äù

Somewhat fun for $3, but if you paid full price, seek therapy and financial restitution.

2/10 ‚Äì Battlefield: Grandma‚Äôs Open Parking Lot & Sniper Retirement Plan Edition.

On sale you cannot go wrong, especially considering at the time of writing there's a free battlepass that also has rewards that transfer over to Battlefield 6.

On another note, this is less battlefield, more hero shooter with vehicles. Huge dissonance between the specialist (operator, whatever you want to call them) quips and skins and the vibe that the natural disasters, the intro movie and the phenomenal soundtrack try to convey. Silly shooter stuff doesn't work well with a heavily experimental industrial soundtrack and the maps which show how devastatingly these climate disasters ravaged through them. If there was a campaign I feel like that dissonance could've been avoided.

With the fixes and improved performance it's worth picking up again until BF6 releases.

I played this game for a bit over an hour and I understand why DICE locked in so hard for Battlefield 6 because this is genuinely somehow not worth it even at $3. 
Maps are awfully designed, being way too big, almost entirely empty of cover anywhere but the points, and with each area of action so far apart from each other you end up spending half the game just running around looking for people. 
Everybody dies in a quarter second so you can mow through people brainlessly without any interesting challenge, then die out of nowhere with little to no time to react, then hope you have somebody to spawn on near the action or you have to spend multiple minutes running back. 
Every gun I tried felt like they fired the same and had the same recoil pattern, giving them no personality and making the gun play uninteresting.
The lighting is terrible, colors are muddy and shapes blend together even at max settings so you can barely tell things apart.
The amount of different operators is overwhelming to try and parse through and some of them just seem terrible in comparison. 
Overall it feels like they tried to make this game mechanically like a CoD style arena shooter but in a Battlefield design frame and it does not work.

Another case study in wishing there was a "Mixed Review" on Steam. I purchased this game for $3.

BF2042, now at the end of life, is a decent game. It's a step down from BF1 and BF5, and will likely lose many players forever to the upcoming BF6, but at its core, it's an above average combined arms based FPS. 

However, it's a bad Battlefield game. The specialist system doesn't work, even at the end of life will all tweaks. Some are hilariously OP still, and some seem completely worthless. The gunplay works, but the maps still feel empty and lifeless. The last of specialists, only totaling a dozen, also speaks to the short support cycled for development, and how unfinished it is.

Ultimately, for under $5, you'll get your money's worth. 50ish hours is likely all I'll spend with it, but those fifty won't be greuling, aggonized suffering. Instead, after about 50 hours, I think I will have seen all the game has to offer. Get it at cheap, or not at all.
